div2.head: Chapters 1-24: The tenth year of the war
div2.p: The Athenians for religious reasons drive the Delians from their island.

ai( spondai\ diele/lunto: the truce was at an end, but no warlike operations are recorded until Cleon led the expedition to Thrace, after the Pythian festival (Metageitnion, Ol. 89, 3, i.e. Aug., 422 B.C.). See App. —e)kexeiri/a|: here and in c. 2. 2; 49. 14, the truce in consequence of the festival. See App.

i(erw=sqai: pf. pass., depends upon h(ghsa/menoi. It refers to the purification and consecration of Delos which had taken place four years before (cf. iii. 104). The Athenians now thought that the Delians had at that time been consecrated (again) to Apollo when they were not yet entirely purified and cleansed from an ancient pollution; that is, that the re-consecration had taken place too soon. But besides (kai\ a(/ma), they thought that the manner of purification (by removal of the coffins) had not been sufficiently thorough.
h(=| pro/tero/n moi dedh/lwtai: upon this depends the indir. disc. w(s . . . e)no/misan poih=sai: “In which I have before related that they believed,” etc. See App.

poih=sai: inf. aor. after e)no/misan, refers to past time like nomi/santes . . . poih/sasqai in vii. 17. 9: they believed that in removing the coffins they had acted rightly. GMT. 23, 2; H. 854.—*)atramu/tteion (not -tion; here and in viii. 108. 19 with Vat.): an important place on the coast of Mysia, near the foot of Mt. Ida.

*farna/kou: Pharnaces was at that time still satrap on the Hellespont. He was succeeded in this office by his son Pharnabazus. Cf. viii. 6. 3.—w(/rmhto: with ellipsis of oi)kh=sai. So we might say as each man chose. Cf. ii. 67. 10; iv. 48. 26; 74. 4; viii. 23. 2.

The expulsion of the Delians is regarded by Boeckh (Abh. d. Berl.
Akad., 1834, p. 6 ff.) and Curtius (Hist. of Greece, III. p. 200) as an unjust and tyrannical measure. But perhaps the scrupulousness in matters of religion which is expressed in the beginning of the treaty of peace (iv. 118. 1), and which caused the Delians to be brought back the very next year (c. 32. 4), was really the motive of the action of the Athenians.
Cleon goes with fresh troops to the coast of Thrace, where the siege of Scione still continues, and attacks Torone by land and sea.
*)aqhnai/ous pei/sas: some persuasion appears to have been needed to induce the Athenians to begin the war again after the truce of the preceding winter.

sxw\n e)s: steering to. Cf. Hdt.vi. 92. 6, e)/sxon e)s th\n *)argoli/da xw/rhn. —*skiw/nhn e)/ti poliorkoume/nhn: the beginning of this siege is mentioned in iv. 131. The Athenians had built a wall of circumvallation and left a guard, but their main force had been withdrawn. Cf. iv. 133. 15.
au)to/qen...tw=n frourw=n : refers to the guard left at Scione, the e)p' au)th=| fulakh/ of iv. 133.
*kwfo\n lime/na: see App.—tw=n *torwnai/wn: in the territory of the Toronaeans. The harbour of Torone is not mentioned until 11.

ai)sqo/menos u(p' au)tomo/lwn: an exceptional const., ai)sqo/menos being treated as if it were didaxqei/s. The more natural prep. would be para/, not Krüger's a)po/. For this unusual use of u(po/, see on i. 130. 3, w)\n e)n mega/lw| a)ciw/mati u(po\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn. Kühn. 442, 1, 2 a.
oi( e)no/ntes: of the garrison, as iv. 104. 2; viii. 84. 14. A freq. use of e)nei=nai.
th=| pezh=| : epexegetical addition to stratia=|. Cf. i. 95. 11, u(po\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn tw=n a)fiknoume/nwn; iii. 54. 4.—e)s th\n po/lin: against the city. Cf. ii. 18. 2, a)fi/keto e)s *oi)no/hn.
e)s to\n lime/na : see App.

to\ peritei/xisma: Brasidas had united the suburb with the city (e)nto\s
poih/sas, cf. i. 62. 3; ii. 83. 5; vii. 5. 14) by breaking down the old wall on this side, dielw\n tou= palaiou= tei/xous, and building a new one to enclose city and suburb alike. This is the peritei/xisma o(\ prosperie/bale th=| po/lei.

kai\ dielw\n kte(.: the rel. pron., which would here be in a new case (dat.) must be supplied from the preceding o(/. G. 156, N. Usually a dem. or pers. pron. is introduced, as in i. 74. 8; 122. 14; ii. 4. 24. H. 1005.—tei/xous: gen. of the whole depending upon an unexpressed word denoting the part broken down, as in ii. 75. 24. G. 168, N. 2; Kühn. 416, 1, N. 2.—au)th/n: agrees in gender with the pred. noun and refers to city and suburb.
Cleon takes Torone in spite of the brave resistance of the inhabitants, who are treated with great severity. The Boeotians take Panactum, an Attic border fort.
*pasiteli/das: Pasitelidas. Cf. iv. 132. 19, where he is called Epitelidas. See note ad loc.
e)s au)to/: into this advanced peritei/xisma, which (6 and 17) is called simply tei/xisma, and from which he afterwards (7) retires into the city.
e)bia/zonto: pass., as in i. 2. 4; iii. 94. 10.
See App.
fqa/swsi labou=sai: equiv. to pro/teron la/bwsi. G. 279, 4; H. 984.

oi( de\ *)aqhnai=oi oi(/ te a)po\ tw=n new=n kai\ o( pezo/s: cf. ii. 95. 5; iii. 13. 19. With these two subjs. distributing oi( *)aqhnai=oi agree respectively the two parties. e(lo/ntes and cunespesw/n, the latter being limited by e)pispo/menos, while both belong with fqa/nousin. G. 279, 4; H. 984.

au)toboei/: which is generally used in connexion with e(lei=n (ii. 81. 21; iii. 113. 29; viii. 62. 8), is here joined with cunespesw/n which practically implies e(lw/n. Cf. iii. 74. 8, au)toboei\ krath/seien, and viii. 71. 12, au)toboei\ lh/yews ou)k a)\n a(martei=n.—to\ dih|rhme/non: (cf. c. 2. 14) the breach made by Brasidas in the old wall.— 12. e)n xersi/: in actual battle. Cf. c. 10. 49; iii. 66. 10; iv. 96. 14; 113. 6; vi. 70. 1. A similar expression is
e)s xei=ras i)e/nai, to come to blows. Cf. ii. 3. 21; iv. 72. 15, e)lqei=n e)s xei=ras; 96. 7.

a)posxw/n: denotes at once actual distance (definitely expressed by tessara/konta ma/lista stadi/ous) and his failure to attain his end (which is negatively expressed in mh\ fqa/sai e)lqw/n, cf. c. 25. 12). With the last phrase, cf. ii. 77. 19, e)laxi/stou e)de/hse diafqei=rai, where, however, mh/ is omitted. GMT. 95, 2 and N. 1; H. 1029. He was only about forty stadia removed from getting there before (the Athenians).

ei)/ tis a)/llos *xalkide/wn: stands in opposition to the au)tou/s, i.e. the men of Torone (cf. Hom. A. 4), who were also Chalcidians. The Athenians were esp. angry with those who had formerly been their allies.—cu/mpantas: as in iv. 129. 15, all together, expressing the sum total.

au)toi=s: i.e. the Athenians. Dat. of interest, as in i. 48. 9, *korinqi/ois de\ to\ me
 decio
 ke/ras ai( *megari/des nh=es ei)=xon; 89, 15, e)peidh\ au)toi=s oi( ba/rbaroi a)ph=lqon; 101. 6, oi( *ei(/lwtes au)toi=s a)pe/sthsan; iv. 42. 20; iv. 67. 24. G. 184, 3; H. 771.— to\ me
 *peloponnh/sion, to\ de\ a)/llo: neut. sing. used as a collective noun. Cf. ii. 45. 5; iii. 39. 29, pe/fuke . . . a)/nqrwpos to\ me
 qerapeu=on u(perfronei=n, to\ de\ mh\ u(pei=kon qauma/zein; iv. 61. 19, pe/fuke ga to\ a)nqrw/peion a)/rxein me
 tou= ei)/kontos, fula/ssesqai de\ to\ e)pio/n. —e)n tai=s...a)ph=lqe: were set free in the treaty; cf. c. 18. 35. The expression refers at once to the clause in the treaty and its execution.
e)komi/sqh: were carried away in exchange. Cf. i. 113. 14.
a)nh\r a)nt' a)ndro\s luqei/s: a)nh/r is here in partitive partic. appos. with to\ a)/llo. Cf. ii. 103. 4, tou/s te e)leuqe/rous a)/gontes, oi(\ a)nh\r a)nt' a)ndro\s e)lu/qhsan. Kühn. 406, 8, N. 11.
*pa/nakton: Panactum was a fortified place (tei=xos) east of Eleutherae and nearly north of Phyle, close to the Boeotian frontier. On its further fortunes, see c. 39, 40, 42.
w(s e)pi\ th\n *)amfi/polin: i.e. to get it away from Brasidas. For the account of the capture of Amphipolis by Brasidas, see iv. 105 f.
Phacax is sent from Athens to Sicily, and tries without much success to form a coalition of the other Sicilian Greeks against the Syracusans.

*fai/ac: at that time one of the most noted Athenians. Cf. Plut. Ale. 13, where he is mentioned as a rival of Alcibiades.—tri/tos au)to/s: with two others. Cf. i. 46. 7; viii. 35. 3, *dwrieu\s o( *diago/rou tri/tos au)to/s.
*leonti=noi ga\r kte(.: continuing to 16, a short account of Sicilian affairs, since the time when they were last mentioned in iv. 65.
a)pelqo/ntwn *)aqhnai/wn: in the summer of 424 B.C., after Hermocrates had brought about the peace among the Sicilian Greeks. See iv. 65.

poli/tas te e)pegra/yanto: they enrolled new citizens in order to strengthen the democratic party, and for their benefit a new division of land was to be made.— th\n gh=n a)nada/sasqai: cf. a)nadasmo\s gh=s, Hdt.iv. 159. 8, and the Attic oath of the heliasts, Dem. xxiv. 149.
ai)sqo/menoi: with no expressed obj., refers to what precedes. Cf. i. 95. 22, oi( de\ ai)sqo/menoi a)ph=lqon; 118. 9; 126. 21; 131. 1; 134. 1; ii. 25. 8; iii. 22. 22; iv. 67. 8, and often.

e)planh/qhsan w(s e(/kastoi: they (i.e. the dh=mos) were scattered in every direction. The aor. referring to continued action in the past because this is regarded as a single historical event. GMT. 19, N. 2; H. 822 c. Cf. i. 6. 7; 8. 3; ii. 2. 2; iv. 56. 2. The ellipsis after w(s e(/kastoi is to be supplied from e)planh/qhsan. — 9. *surakosi/ois, *surakou/sas: see App.—e)klipo/ntes kai\ e)rhmw/santes: the fact that the city was left without inhabitants is emphasized.

e)pi\ politei/a| w)/|khsan: they settled (aor.) there upon the assurance of citizenship. Cf. i. 13. 5, e)pi\ r(htoi=s ge/rasi patrikai\ basilei=ai; iii. 114. 14, cummaxi/an e)poih/santo e)pi\ toi=sde. The dat. with e)pi/ expresses the condition upon which anything is done.

a)re/skesqai: being contented,
with and without dat. Cf. c. 37. 19; ii. 68. 7.—a)polipo/ntes e)k: as in iii. 10. 8, a)polipo/ntwn u(mw=n e)k tou= *mhdikou= pole/mou. Kühn. 447 c.

th=s po/lews ti xwri/on: apparently a suburb of Leontini, the name of which points to a connexion with the Ionic Phocaea (see Holm, Gesch. Siciliens, I. p. 198), while the fortress of Bricinniae was prob. at a greater distance from the city, though in the Leontine territory (e)n th=| *leonti/nh|. Holm, II. p. 9).
o)/n: agrees with the pred. e)/ruma. Cf. i. 10. 1. G. 135, 3, N. 4; H. 610; Kühn. 369, 3.
w(s au)tou/s: i.e. to join them.— katasta/ntes: i.e. after they had established themselves and made preparations for defence. Cf. i. 59. 7; ii. 1. 3; iv. 75. 8.

e)k tw=n teixw=n: from the (two) fortified places.—e)polemoun: they carried on war against the Syracusans. The impf. denotes the condition of hostility, not definite events. —a(\ punqano/menoi kte(.: returns to the beginning of the chap.

ei)/ pws...diasw/seian kte(.: in case they should persuade, etc., and so save the dh=mos. An idea of purpose is implied as an apod. The whole is equiv. to a clause expressing intention. GMT. 53, N. 2; H. 907.—tou\s...cumma/xous : referring to the conditions which existed before 424 B.C. (iv. 65). See iii. 86.
koinh=|: with e)pistrateu=sai, the motive for a joint campaign being the continual (pres. partic. peripoioume/nwn) aggressions of the Syracusans.

a)ntista/ntos au)tw=| tou= pra/gmatos: since his undertaking did not prosper. As in c. 38. 20, w(s de\ a)nte/sth to\ pra=gma, in accordance with the well-known meaning of pra/ssein, undertake, or carry on an undertaking. Cf. i. 128. 13, ta\ pro\s basile/a pra/gmata pra/ssein; iv. 1. 4, e)/pracan de\ tou=to oi( *surako/sioi.
ai)sqo/menos : see App.

dia\ tw=n *sikelw=n: the Sicels in the country behind Syracuse. —e)n th=| paro/dw|: on the march from Gela to Catana. This also goes to
prove that Bricinniae lay some distance inland from Leontini.
Phaeax, after negotiations with several cities of Italy, returns to Athens.
th=| parakomidh=| kai\ a)naxwrh/sei: the two corresponding nouns with but one art., as in i. 120. 10, th\n katakmidh\n kai\ pa/lin a)nti/lhyin, and ii. 64. 27.

e)xrhma/tise: lo/gous prosh/negke, Schol. This is used in like manner of conducting public business in c. 61. 6; i. 87. 17. With the dat., here only. Of the conduct of money matters, the mid. xrhmati/zesqai is used in vii. 13. 13.

fili/as toi=s *)aqhnai/ois: cf. i. 63. 9, toi=s *poteidaia/tais bohqoi/; iii. 66. 17; iv. 23. 4. The dat. depends upon the verbal force of fili/as (G. 185; H. 765 a) in spite of the fact that file/w takes the acc. Kühn. 424, 2.

e)kpeptwko/sin: the attrib. partic. is not infrequently put by Thuc. after its subst. when the latter is further limited by other words. Cf. i. 11. 19; 90. 6; and often. Perhaps, however, Cobet (Mnem. 14, p. 4) is right in omitting e)poi/kois as a gloss.— th\n *sikeliwtw=n o(mologi/an: the terms of this agreement between Athens and the Sicilians (424 B.C.) are given in iv. 65.
stasiasa/ntwn *messhni/wn: Messene was disturbed by factions from its foundation to the latest times. See vi. 4. 24 ff., and A. Holm, Gesch. Siciliens, I. p. 198 ff.

tw=n e(te/rwn: doubtless the Ionic portion of the population, which had been subjected by Anaxilas (vi. 4. 34 ff.). These people, from the moment of their first appearance in Sicily, had had dealings with the Epizephyrian Locrians (Hdt. vi. 23).—e)cepe/mfqhsan: i.e. by the Locrians to Messene in accordance with the invitation (e)pagagome/nwn).
kai\ e)ge/neto: joined to the rel. clause in loose grammatical connexion. Cf. c. 2. 14.
[toi=s komizome/nois]: see App.
e)gege/nhto ga/r: on his way to Sicily, Phaeax had made a preliminary arrangement with the Locrians, who had hitherto been averse to the Athenian alliance.

ou)k e)spei/santo: they made no treaty, wishing to be free to take advantage of any opportunities which
might be offered them, such as the occurrences at Messene above referred to.
ou)d' a)\n to/te: sc. e)spei/santo.
*)ipwnie/as kai\ *medmai/ous : see App.
Cleon and Brasidas collect reinforcements, and take up positions opposite one another near Amphipolis.
to/te: refers to c. 3. 27. to/te often refers in this way to a time which is supposed to be well known to the reader. Cf. i. 101. 8; iii. 69. 2; iv. 46. 5; v. 4. 14; and see on i. 101. 8.

*stagei/rw| (Strabo vii. frg. 35 and Steph. Byz. have *sta/geira): north of Acanthus, on the Strymonian Gulf. Cf. Hdt.vii. 115. 6. The birthplace of Aristotle. St. now reads here and in c. 18. 25 (not iv. 88. 9) *sta/giros, acc. to the inscriptions.
*galhyo/n: between the Strymon and the Nestus. Cf. iv. 107. 12; Diod. xii. 68; Strabo, vii. 35; Steph. Byz. s.v.
kata\ to\ cummaxiko/n: the alliance had been renewed, iv. 132. 2.

tw=n (with Vat. for to\n) *)odoma/ntwn: cf. ii. 101. 12. This tribe is mentioned by Hdt.vii. 112. 7. Its home was apparently in the plain between Strymon and Nestus.—a)/contas: with Linwood (Jahrbb. 1862, p. 200) for a)/conta, for this intention must be ascribed to the envoys, not to the foreign chief.—misqou=: gen. of price, as in iv. 124. 22; vii. 25. 34. G. 178; H. 746; Kr. Spr. 47, 17, 3. Cf. Ar. Ach. 144.
*)hio/ni: cf. iv. 106. 17 and 18.—a)nteka/qhto kai\ au)to/s: refers to h(su/xaze (sc. o( *kle/wn) of the preceding line.

*)argili/wn: in the territory of Argilos, but on the right bank of the
Strymon.
ou) polu/: about 20 stadia.

au)to/n: Cl. and one Ms. for au)to/qen, the repetition of which is useless. This renewed mention of Brasidas makes his intention in occupying Cerdylium more prominent, and makes the connexion of the following prosede/xeto and pareskeua/zeto easier. (St. and Schütz, with three Mss., omit au)to/qen.)
e)pi\ th\n *)amfi/polin...a)nabh/sesqai : explaining the preceding o(/per . . . poih/sein. Cf. iii. 59. 18, o(/per a)nagkai=on . . . toi=s w(=de e)/xousi, lo/gou teleuta=n.
th=| parou/sh| stratia=| : without waiting for his expected reinforcements.

*qra=|kas te kte(.: to be taken with parakalw=n, not with pareskeua/zeto, which is used abs. as often elsewhere. Cf. ii. 11. 22; iii. 46. 9; vii. 34. 4; viii. 10. 4. The te . . . kai/ admits of no other const., and, moreover, the opposition between tou\s *)hdw=nas pa/ntas and the definite number of the other Thracians is made more evident in this way.
*murkini/wn: Myrcinus, also an Edonian city, had been for some time in alliance with Brasidas. Cf. iv. 107. 9.
i(pph=s *(/ellhnes: to distinguish them from the Edonians of 18.—tou/twn: part. gen. It depends upon the obj. of e)/xwn implied in e)s pentakosi/ous kai\ xili/ous. About 1500 of these.
meta\ *kleari/dou: he was stationed at Amphipolis. Cf. iv. 132. 19. —e)teta/xato: this form (or the pf. teta/xatai) occurs also in iii. 13. 18; iv. 31. 7; vii. 4. 34. G. 118, 5, N.; 119, 3; H. 464 a.
Cleon is forced by the impatience of his men to march out and reconnoitre.
e)/peita: after e)/peita, when me/n precedes, de/ is sometimes found, and sometimes not; examples of both uses are about equally numerous. Here the Mss. omit de/.

th=| e(/dra|: like ii. 18. 19, th=| kaqe/dra|. th=| prosmonh=|, Schol. Cf. Hdt.ix. 41. 4.—tw=n stratiwtw=n a)nalogizome/-
nwn: cf. oi( stratiw=tai a)nelogi/zonto, viii. 83. 10, where the expression is used in the same sense as here.

th
 e)kei/nou h(gemoni/an: proleptic. Cf. i. 23. 26, ai( d' e)s to\ fanero
 lego/menai ai)ti/ai ai(/d) h)=san e(kate/rwn, a)f) w(=n lu/santes ta\s sponda\s e)s to
 po/lemon kate/sthsan; ii. 21. 3, memnhme/noi kai\ *pleistoa/nakta o(/te e)sbalw
 e)s *)eleusi=na a)nexw/rhse.—pro\s oi(/an...meta\ oi(/as: the pron. is repeated with the same effect of emphasis as in vii. 75. 37. The opinion of Thuc. about Brasidas as well as Cleon remains the same, even after Cleon's success at Pylos. See on iv. 28. 24 and 39. 11, and Introd. to Book I., p. 45.
a)nepisthmosu/nhs: does not occur elsewhere in Thuc. The adj. occurs in ii. 89. 31, and freq. elsewhere.

oi)/koqen: placed first in its clause, even before w(s, for emphasis. Cf. i. 77. 4 ff. —cunh=lqon: corresponds to e)ch=lqe, c. 8. 7. See App.—kaqhme/nous: remaining inactive, as in iv. 124. 24. See App.

w(=|per...eu)tuxh/sas e)pi/steuse/ ti fronei=n : (the manner) by which he had been successful at Pylos, and thus had acquired confidence in his own wisdom (fronei=n ti as in ii. 53. 19, a)polau=sai ti, to have some enjoyment), i.e. his method of reckless attacks.
kata\ qe/an: to reconnoitre. Cf. c. 9. 10; 10. 8; vi. 31. 5. Const. with tou= xwri/ou, i.e. Amphipolis.

kai\ th\n mei/zw kte(.: kai/ is the confirmation of what precedes: “and in fact (ii. 2. 26; iv. 1. 9) he was waiting for the reinforcements (mentioned in c. 6. 5 ff.), not that he might gain the victory (perisxh/swn as in vii. 105. 4) without risk if he should be forced to fight (h)\n a)nagka/zhtai, sc. ma/xesqai), but with the intention of forcing the town to surrender by surrounding it.”

bi/a| ai(rh/swn: take by force of arms. This is merely opp. to o(mologi/a| parasth/sasqai, acquire by agreement, and does not mean take by storm. See on i. 102. 7.—e)lqw/n te: and accordingly he went. Expressing conse
quence. te is here not a correlative of kai/.

e)pi\ th=| *qra/|kh| : in respect to the surrounding Thracian country. An indefinite description of its situation as i. 105. 6, e)p' *ai)gi/nh|; ii. 86. 11, e)pi\ th=| *(ri/w|; vi. 2. 6, e)pi\ th=| qala/ssh|. St. omits these words as an interpolation.

a)pie/nai te e)no/mizen: not to be separated by any stronger punctuation from what precedes. He examined the situation at his leisure, and believed that he could go away without a battle whenever he chose.— 18. ou)/t' , ou)/te: used as if both belonged to one verb, e)fai/neto, although e)ch/|ei is irregularly added in the second clause.
w(/ste kai\...e)do/kei : i.e. he was even sorry that he had not brought his storming machines with him.—ou)k a)nh=lqen: refers to a)nabai/nein, 11. See App.
e(lei=n a)/n: sc. e)do/kei. His thought was e(/loimi a)/n or perhaps ei(=lon a)/n. GMT. 53; H. 964.
Thereupon Brasidas re-enters Amphipolis, and determines to attack the Athenians in two divisions commanded respectively by himself and Clearidas.

kai\ au)to/s: these words indicate reciprocity in the movements of the two parties. Brasidas returned to the city which Cleon had approached. Cf. c. 7. 8 ff. eu)qu\s w(s ei)=de kinoume/nous tou\s *)aqhnai/ous is the natural consequence of katefai/neto pa/nta au)to/qen in c. 6. 12.

dediw\s th\n au(tou= paraskeuh/n: ou) qarrw=n th=| i)di/a| paraskeuh=|, Schol. His force consisted mainly of mercenaries. Cf. iv. 80. 22.—u(podeeste/rous: refers in accordance with frequent usage to paraskeuh/n (G. 138, N. 3; H. 615 a), and is therefore not to be changed (with Portus) to u(podee/steros.

a)nti/pala : without reference to a definite subj. Cf. i. 7. 8; ii. 56. 4; iii. 88. 4; iv. 117. 13.—a)ciw/mati: almost with the meaning of excellence, efficiency (th=| duna/mei, Schol.); but their reputation, with the respect arising from it, is also expressed by this word.

kaqaro/n: ou)xi\ sugklu/dwn ou)de\ e)pikou/rwn, a)ll' au)tw=n tw=n politw=n, Schol. Cf. xrhstoi=s katalo/gois e)kkriqe/n, vi. 31. 28. Similarly Hdt.i. 211. 3 and iv. 135. 10, to\ ka-
qaro\n tou= stratou=. Plut. Aem. P. 8, au)tw=n tw=n *makedo/nwn a)reth=| kai\ h(liki/a| to\ kaqarw/taton.—*lhmni/wn kai\ *)imbri/wn: Attic cleruchi, often mentioned together as trusty followers, iii. 5. 5; iv. 28. 18; vii. 57. 8.— 8. te/xnh|: by artifice. Cf. c. 18. 16. Const. with e)piqhso/menos, which is fut. partic. without w(s expressing purpose after pareskeua/zeto. Similarly ii. 91. 8; vi. 54. 18; vii. 17. 2; viii. 59. 2.
a)nagkai/an ou)=san: barely sufficient, such as had been obtainable under the circumstances. Cf. vi. 37. 17. A similar use of the superl. occurs in i. 90. 21; 82. 10.

au)tw=n: objective gen. referring to Brasidas's own forces. a)/neu proo/yews au)tw=n is equiv. to ei) mh\ au)tou\s proi/doien. What follows carries out the same idea, the emphasis upon the consequence which was to be avoided being made stronger by the use of mh\ a)po\ instead of a)/neu (for similar phrases, cf. i. 91. 28; iii. 40. 28, 30; iv. 130. 26; vii. 15. 12; 70. 49). kai\ mh\ a)po\ tou= o)/ntos katafronh/sews is equiv. to kai\ ei) mh\ tou= o)/ntos (i.e. their real weakness which would then appear) katafronh/seian. “If he showed his weakness to the enemy, he thought he should be less likely (ou) ma=llon for h(=tton) to gain a victory than if they did not see his forces and learn to despise them.” This explanation is adopted from that of Schütz, Ztschr. f. d. Gymn. Wesen 12, p. 406, and St., Symbola Philologorum Bonnensium, p. 387 f.
prosta/cas: prosta/ssein, hand over to, place under the command of. Cf. vi. 42. 8, kata\ te/lh strathgw=| prostetagme/noi.
a)polabei=n : cut off, get into his power, as in ii. 90. 20; iv. 14. 19.
tu/xoi e)lqou=sa: equiv. to tu/xh| e)/lqoi.
fra/sai: tell accurately. Cf. i. 145. 4 and note; iii. 42. 10 and note.

div2.head: SPEECH OF BRASIDAS TO HIS TROOPS.
div2.p:
It is sufficient to remind you briefly that you are Dorians opposed to Ionians. § 1. Next listen to my plan: we must surprise the enemy while they are off
their guard and not expecting an attack. Wise use of the mistakes of others is the surest means of success. § 2-5. I, with my chosen troops, will attack their centre. Then you, Clearidas, in the moment of their confusion, will fall upon them with the rest of our forces; and if all do their duty, as I expect, then all will be sure of perpetual freedom from the yoke of Athens. § 69. I myself will prove that I can not only advise, but act. § 10.

o(/ti: namely; explanatory, in the particularization of what precedes. o(/ti . . . e)leuqe/ras (sc. h(/komen a)po\ xw/ras) bridges over the transition from the interr. oi(/as to o(/ti *dwrih=s, etc. —to\ eu)/yuxon: the noblest expression for manly courage. Cf. ii. 39. 7.— *dwrih=s, *)/iwsi: the same distinction of races is expressed with the same pride in i. 124. 5; vi. 77. 11; vii. 5. 17.— 3. a)rkei/tw dedhlwme/non: corresponds nearly to the Lat. monuisse sufficiat. But the partic. modifies the double subj. of a)rkei/tw, a)po\ me\n oi(/as kte(. and o(/ti *dwrih=s kte(. GMT. 112, 2, N. 1.
th\n de\ e)pixei/rhsin: const. with poiei=sqai, although this has at the head of the sent. almost an abs. position. See on i. 33. 16; 32. 18.
i(/na mh/ tw| to\ kat) o)li/gon kte(.: lest our exposing ourselves in detachments and not all together seem poor tactics and cause discouragement to any one. See App.

kai\ ou)k a)
 e)lpi/santas w(s a)
 e)pece/lqoi: and since they would not have expected that anybody could (possibly) come out against them. ou)k a)
 e)lpi/santas is equiv. to o(/ti ou)k a)
 h)/lpisan. w(s with e)lpi/zein, also in viii. 54. 4.

kata\ qe/an (cf. c. 7. 11) tetramme/nous: tetramme/nos pro/s (or, as here, kata/) is the proper expression for a predominant inclination in one direction to the neglect of other things. See on ii. 40. 4. Cf. ii. 25. 11; 51. 13; vii. 73. 16. a)ta/ktws is to be taken with tetramme/nous as well as o)ligwrei=n, which last is used abs. (“be careless”), as in ii. 62. 20; vi. 91. 40.
kai\ a(/ma: kai/ connects the adv. modifier pro\s (cf. i. 6. 15; 10. 8) th\n e(autou= du/namin with the partic. i)dw/n, which also limits the meaning of the verb.

poiei=tai: indic. in general prot. GMT. 51, N. 3.—mh\ a)po\ tou= profanou=s ma=llon kte(.: profanou=s is in the same const. with a)ntiparataxqe/ntos, “not so much with regard
to what is to be seen and to the forces which stand arrayed against one another.”
e)k tou=...cumfe/rontos : according to what is advantageous under the circumstances.

ta\ kle/mmata: ta\ strathgh/mata, Schol., from the specially Lacedaemonian expression kle/ptein for military stratagems (cf. Xen. Anab. iv. 6. 11 ff., where kle/ptein is used of taking a mountain by stealth).—a(/ (sc. kle/mmata): with a)path/sas, a sort of schema etymologicum or cognate acc., since kle/mma a)pata=n is equiv. to a)pa/thn a)pata=n.

a)/n : for its repetition, cf. i. 36. 14; 77.20; 136. 17; iv. 114. 21. St. denies that this is a repetition, because the first a)/n belongs to a)path/sas, the second to w)felh/seie. But a)path/sas is equiv. to ei) a)path/seie, of course without a)/n. GMT. 42, 3, N. 1.

tou= me/nontos: an excellent example of Thuc.'s liking for neut. partics. instead of infs. Equally striking is e)n tw=| mh\ meletw=nti, i. 142. 22, with which e)n tw=| a)neime/nw| below may be compared. GMT. 108, N. 4.—fai/nontai: with a pers. subj. where we should expect w(s fai/netai, as in c. 75. 12, e)do/koun; c. 113. 3, dokei=te.
cuntaqh=nai : see App.
h)/dh proskei/menon: already engaged, after the first attack has been made.

tou\s meta\ seautou=: opp. to toi=s met' e)mautou=, 21, the 2000 Peloponnesian hoplites of c. 6. 21 (less the 150 which Brasidas kept for himself, c. 8. 13). To these are added the Amphipolitans and other allies. —tou/s t' *)amfipoli/tas kai\ tou\s a)/llous cumma/xous: must be joined without intervening punctuation to the preceding tou\s meta\ seautou=. It is the less usual arrangement by which te introduces the second member, and kai/ the third, as in i. 13. 5 f.

e)pekqei=n kai\ e)pei/gesqai: the only case of the use of the inf. in the sense of the second pers. imv. in Thuc. G. 269; H. 957; Kr. 55, 1, 5. For the
third pers. vi. 34. 55 f. is adduced, but with doubtful propriety.

ma/lista au)tou/s: St. writes ma/list' a)\n au)tou/s; but this use of the aor. inf. without a)/n with e)lpi/s and similar words is very common. Cf. ii. 80. 11; iii. 3. 15; 32. 15; iv. 28. 28; 80. 3; vi. 87. 18; and see on ii. 3. 8. G. 203, N. 2; H. 948 a, 952.— 28. to/ e)pio/n: like tou= paro/ntos and tou= maxome/nou neut. sing. in personal signification, as in ii. 45. 5; iii. 39. 29 f.; vii. 43. 44.
nomi/sate tri/a ei)=nai, to\ toi=s a)/rxousi pei/qesqai: see App.

th=|de th=| h(me/ra|: cf. ii. 12. 14, h(/de h( h(me/ra toi=s *(/ellhsi mega/lwn kakw=n a)/rcei; Ar. Pax, 435, eu)xw/mesqa th
 nu=n h(me/ran *(/ellhsin a)/rcai pa=si pollw=n ka)gaqw=n; Xen. Hell. ii. 2. 23; Plut. Lys. 15. In closest connexion with this stands only u(mi=n . . . u(pa/rxein depending upon nomi/sate: “be sure that on this day there awaits you either—or —.” This alternative which belongs with u(pa/rxein extends to the end of the period, in the first term with the subjs. e)leuqeri/an and *lakedaimoni/wn cumma/xois keklh=sqai, in the second only with gene/sqai and its predicates, *)aqhnai/wn dou/lois and kwlutai=s e)leuqerw/sews toi=s loipoi=s *(/ellhsin. The words kai\ doulei/an xalepwte/ran h)\ pri
 ei)/xete are an emphatic addition to *)aqhnai/wn dou/lois (not to be joined with u(pa/rxein) “and that in a harsher bondage than the old one.” In consequence of this and the other inserted clause (h)
 ta\ a)/rista . . . pra/chte) the regular connexion of *)aqhnai/wn te dou/lois with a following kai/ is interrupted, and instead of this we have the more emphatic toi=s de\ loipoi=s kte(. A similar case occurs in i. 11. 4 ff. The difficulty of the passage is increased by the fact that the second h)/ (35) is without any explanatory words corresponding to a)gaqoi=s genome/nois. Brasidas avoids saying kakoi=s genome/nois or any words to that effect, but makes the consequences so much the more prominent by the expressions doulei/an xalepwte/ran and kwlutai=s e)leuqerw/sews. For another understanding of the passage, see App.— 35. keklh=sqai: pf. of recognized appellation: “bear the (honourable) name of allies of the Lacedaemonians.” Cf. ii. 37. 4; iii. 82. 51. GMT. 18, 3 b, N.; H. 849.

dou/lois: refers to being subjects of Athens, a)ndrapodismou= to actual slavery.— 36. h)\n ta\ a)/rista...pra/chte : “even if you fare in the best possible way,
and are not sold as slaves or put to death.” ta\ a)/rista (adv.) pra/ssein, sup. of eu)= pra/ssein, which occurs in ii. 64. 8; vi. 75. 17.

malakisqh=te: as in ii. 43. 27, a)lgeinote/ra ga\r a)ndri/ ge fro/nhma e)/xonti h( meta\ tou= malakisqh=nai ka/kwsis h)\ o( meta\ r(w/mhs kai\ koinh=s e)lpi/dos a(/ma gigno/menos a)nai/sqhtos qa/natos.
e)/rgw| e)pecie/nai : opp. to parainei=n or simply lo/gois, as in i. 84. 16; 120. 27.

Cleon, having heard of Brasidas's intention, tries to retreat to Eion before it can be carried out. But Brasidas, after a short address to his men, makes the attack as agreed, and Clearidas comes up at the right moment. The Athenian army is thrown into confusion, which soon becomes a rout. In the heat of pursuit, Brasidas is mortally wounded, while Cleon is killed in his flight by a Myrcinian peltast. The rest escape after heavy losses to Eion. Brasidas dies after receiving the news of the victory.

tosau=ta: so much and no more, esp. after short speeches. Cf. ii. 12. 1; 72. 1 and 13; iii. 31. 1; 52. 14; iv. 11. 1; vii. 49. 1. So Plat. Prot. 318 a, tosou=tos o( h(me/teros lo/gos.— 2. *kleari/da: Dor. gen. as i. 103. 6, *dio\s tou= *)iqwmh/ta; v. 25. 4, *pleisto/la.
*qra|ki/as tw=n pulw=n : acc. to Leake in the northeast side of the wall, on the road leading to Drabescus. See Weissenborn, Hellen, p. 156.
ei)/rhto: cf. 9. 22 ff.—e)peci/oien: after he had himself made his e)/codos, 1.

fanerou= genome/nou: personal (as in c. 9. 18, fai/nontai), with the three partics. kataba/ntos, quome/nou, pra/ssontos. The action of first (kataba/ntos) was naturally noticed (aor.) by the Athenians as soon as it took place (c. 8. 2); how that of the other two was observed (quome/nou kai\ tau=ta pra/ssontos, present with reference to genome/nou) is explained by e)pifanei= ou)/sh| e)/cwqen (as in c. 6. 12, katefai/neto pa/nta au)to/qen).

au)tou=: sc. *brasi/dou.— 6. quome/nou: mid. used esp. of sacrifices made for the purpose of observing the omens. Cf. Hdt.v. 44. 13; vii. 167. 7; 189. 9; ix. 10. 13; 33. 2; 62. 5; Xen. Anab. ii. 2. 3; vi. 2. 9. This purpose accounts also for the
use of tau=ta pra/ssontos referring to the sacrificial ceremonies mentioned in vi. 69. 16.
to/te: he had just gone out for the reconnoissance mentioned in c. 7. 11.—a(/pasa: “it was evident that the troops were all collected.”

u(po\ ta\s pu/las...u(pofai/nontai : under the gate (in the space between the gate and the threshold) they were seen a little, i.e. as far as was possible (u(po-) in this way. So, too, po/des . . . w(s e)cio/ntwn refers to the forces drawn up in readiness to march. This all shows accurate observation on the part of the scouts. But see App.
e)ph=lqe: i.e. he went nearer to see for himself.

oi(: with h(/kein, like the dat. with e)lqei=n in i. 13. 12; 27. 1; 61. 1; 107. 27; iii. 70. 2; vi. 46. 12; vii. 73. 5; viii. 96. 1. Plat. Prot. 321 c. Cf. also vi. 96. 2. In all these cases the dat. is the ‘obj. for which’ coinciding with the limit of motion.
fqh/sesqai a)pelqw/n: that he would get away in time, i.e. before being attacked.

toi=s a)piou=sin: the art. indicates the successive execution of the a)naxw/rhsis as commands were given: hence Cl. with good Ms. authority writes parh/ggelle (used esp. of military orders, cf. c. 58. 16; 71. 18; 73. 11) for parh/ggeile. “To the departing troops, i.e. as the separate divisions started, the command was given to turn to the left upon the road to Eion” (St. omits toi=s). The idea of gradual departure is also contained in u(pa/gein. The emphatic connexion of the two verbs e)ke/leuen and parh/ggelle by te a(/ma and kai/ gives an intimation of Cleon's efforts to hasten the departure, which in the following au)to\s e)pistre/yas to\ decio\n kte(. lead to pernicious haste.
w(/sper mo/non oi(=o/n t' h)=n: sc. in order to reach Eion.
sxolh=|: see App.

e)pistre/yas to\ decio/n: in his impatience, he causes the right wing to turn and advance (cf. ii. 90. 18) before its proper turn, thereby exposing it to attack.—ta\ gumna/: the unprotected side (iii. 23. 19; v. 71. 6), i.e. the right side, the left being covered by the shield.
o(/ti: often used to introduce a dir. quot. Cf. i. 137. 22; iv. 38. 16; viii. 53. 20.
dh=loi de/: (not dh/ with Kr.) epexegetical, as in i. 46. 3; 55. 9; iii. 34. 1.—th=| kinh/sei: hints at a restless movement toward hasty departure, not toward meeting the enemy.

a(/s ei)/rhtai: sc. a)noi/gein. He had chosen for his sally not the Thracian gate, but two others (ta\s e)pi\ to\ stau/rwma). By ta\s prw/tas tou= makrou= tei/xous to/te o)/ntos an outer gate in the long wall built by Hagnon (iv. 102. 18) seems to be meant. This wall was afterwards destroyed. Changes made by the Lacedaemonians in the fortifications of Amphipolis are referred to in iv. 103. 18.

to\ karterw/teron tou= xwri/ou: the higher parts of the ground, which Cleon, acc. to c. 7. 15, had seized. Brasidas directed his attack against this point in order to strike at the main force of the Athenians while still undivided.
i)o/nti: the dat. denoting the person in respect to whom the statement is made is used most freq. of partics. denoting motion, estimation, or judgment. Cf. i. 10. 34; 24. 1; G. 184, 5; H. 771 b.
kata\ me/son to\ stra/teuma: with prosbalw/n.
tre/pei, kai/ o( *kleari/das e)pefe/reto: the connexion is close. “Just as Brasidas was forcing the Athenians to retreat, Clearidas fell upon them.” The impf. is used of contemporaneous action.

cune/bh te kte(.: “and so it came to pass that by the unexpectedness and suddenness (of the attack) from both sides at once the Athenians were thrown into disorder.” So cumbai/nein of several events occurring at once in i. 29. 21; v. 14. 20; 37. 20; vii. 75. 7; viii. 64. 17; 82. 15. —kai\ e)capi/nhs: pleonastic strengthening of a)dokh/tw|. The art. tw=| belongs with both. St. (Adn. Crit. VI.) takes it as consequence of a)dokh/tw| and connects it with qorubhqh=nai, which, in
view of the close connexion of cause and effect, seems inadmissible (in the new ed. St. omits kai/). A similar connexion of two unlike adv. expressions occurs in iii. 4. 4 f., a)para/skeuoi kai\ e)cai/fnhs a)nagkasqe/ntes polemei=n.

to\ pro\s th\n *)hio/na: which was already on the way to Eion in 15 f.— 37. e)pipariw\n tw=| deciw=|: “pressing forward (e)pi-) and turning against the right wing.” Cf. i. 61. 3, w(s h)/|sqonto kai\ tou\s meta\ *)ariste/ws e)pipario/ntas.

peso/nta au)to/n: that he had fallen. The partic. aor. with ai)sqa/nesqai to express what has happened immediately before is found in Thuc. only here and in viii. 102. 3. In the 24 other passages always partic. pres. or pf. In c. 30. 3, the partic. pres. stands in connexion with the partic. aor. where the difference between them is plainly marked. The part. is equiv. to o(/ti e)/pesen.

to\ de\ decio\n e)/mene ma=llon : after the fall of Brasidas, by which the violence of the attack was diminished, the right wing, although hard pressed, still stood its ground for a while. Cleon, to be sure, who had (cf. 17) made an ill-advised movement with the right wing, and hoped to escape with the whole army (a)ph=ge th\n stratia/n), took to flight immediately; but the hoplites, who had formed in close order (custrafe/ntes, as in ii. 4. 23; iv. 68. 25; vi. 91. 6) where they stood, defended themselves bravely for a while, though on the one hand Cleon was urging them to retreat, while on the other Brasidas was attacking with the utmost vigour. See App.
w(s to\ prw=ton ou) dienoei=to me/nein: as he had from the first had no intention of standing his ground, with reference to c. 7. 10.

e)pi\ to
 lo/fon: apparently interpolated to explain au)tou=; for that au)tou= must be understood as an adv. of place is evident from its position. It points expressly to the place from which Cleon had just fled. Some copier, thinking of c. 7. 15 ff., thought wrongly that the close order was formed e)pi\ to
 lo/fon, and added this explanation of au)tou=, but after a)ph=ge th
 stratia/n, 18, it is not probable that they were still e)pi\ lo/fou karterou= of c. 7. 15.

kai\
di\s h)\ tri/s: although he, etc. Cf. i. 82. 12, dielqo/ntwn e)tw=n kai\ du/o kai\ triw=n and note.
*murkini/a: cf. c. 6. 18, where, however, only peltasts from Myrcinus are mentioned.

ou(/tw dh/: see App.—to\ stra/teuma pa=n fugo\n...trapo/menoi...o(/soi mh\ diefqa/rhsan oi(...loipoi\ a)pekomi/sqhsan : the subj. is divided in the course of the period, and undergoes progressive modifications. Similarly ii. 4. 3 ff.; 65. 3 ff.; iv. 68. 3 ff.
e)n xersi/n: cf. c. 3. 12.
e)/ti e)/mpnoun: also in i. 134. 15.
h)/|sqeto: i.e. he received the news while still in command of his faculties. Cf. c. 26. 5, where ai)sqano/menos is used in a similar sense.
nekrou/s te: the omission of the art. is occasioned by the close connexion with kai\ tro/paion.
Brasidas receives a public funeral at Amphipolis, and is honoured by the Amphipolitans as a hero.
The Athenians return home.

pro\ th=s nu=n a)gora=s ou)/shs: referring to later changes, as in c. 10. 26. Other cases in which the honour of burial within a city was conferred are mentioned in Xen. Hell. vii. 3. 12; Cic. ad Fam. iv. 12. 3.
perie/rcantes: see App.

h(/rw|: see App.—e)nte/mnousi: of sacrifices made to the dead, dia\ to\ e)n th=| gh=| tw=n sfagi/wn a)pote/mnesqai ta\s kefala/s: ou(/tw ga\r qu/ousi toi=s xqoni/ois. Schol. The word does not occur again before Plutarch and Lucian.—dedw/kasin: ‘pf., as well as the pres. e)nte/mnousi, is the expression of one who is present in the neighbourhood and sees the yearly repetition of this custom.
Thuc. writes while living on his Thracian estates’ (Cl.). See Introd. to Book I. p. 15. Thuc. probably did write part of his history while in Thrace, but the tenses here employed might be used by any contemporaneous writer.

prose/qesan: aor. is, on the other hand, merely the historical mention of the fact: “they attributed the town to him as founder.” Arbitrary adoption and change of ‘oecist’ is mentioned in vi. 3. 13; 5. 16.—*(agnw/neia oi)kodomh/mata: the public buildings dating from the settlement of Hagnon (iv. 102. 13 ff.), especially the heroum, which was probably erected after Hagnon's death (Müller-Strübing, Aristoph. p. 718). That Hagnon was dead appears from 13.

ei)/ ti mnhmo/sunon kte(.: “whatever was likely to remind them of, etc.” Such reminders would probably be continually met with in recurring festivals and in public proceedings and documents.— au)tou=: refers to Hagnon implied in *(agnw/neia.—e)/mellen perie/sesqai: “was likely to remain in future as a reminder.” A comprehensive expression.

kai\ e)n tw=| paro/nti a(/ma: connected in somewhat loose const., with swth=ra/ te sfw=n gegenh=sqai: the services already rendered by Brasidas are placed in opposition to the present interest of the Amphipolitans in the alliance with Sparta, but both appear as the result of Brasidas's action; so the opposition of to
 me
 *brasi/dan and to
 de\ *(/agnwna is preserved.

kata\ to\ pole/mion tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: “in consequence of their hostile attitude towards Athens.” Cf. iii. 56. 7, ei) ga\r tw=| au)ti/ka xrhsi/mw| u(mw=n te kai\ e)kei/nwn polemi/w| to\ di/kaion lh/yesqe.— 13. o(moi/ws: sc. as formerly, while their relation with Athens was a pleasant one. Cf. i. 99. 6; 124. 15 (not, “as Brasidas”).—ou)d' a)/n h(de/ws ta\s tima\s e)/xein: not to be taken with the Schol. (and Jowett) as referring to sfi/si. “Hagnon himself would not receive honours paid him after the town had become an enemy of Athens, either with benefit to the citizens or with pleasure to himself.” Such action and feeling after death was ascribed to the ‘oecist’ who was worshipped as a hero. See Hermann, Gottesd. Alterthümer, 16.

toiau/ths cuntuxi/as: refers to the account in the preceding chapter, esp. to cune/bh te . . . qorubhqh=nai,
33 f., of which the reader is here reminded by proekfobh/sews (the panic before the fight began). Even taking these things into account, the difference in the losses of the two sides is very great.
oi( me/n: the Athenians.
kaqi/stanto: here and in c. 12. 5 the impf. esp. of political regulations intended to be permanent. Cf. ii. 6. 3; iii. 28. 17; 35. 7; v. 82. 3.
A reinforcement under Rhamphias, sent by the Lacedaemonians to Thrace, is detained at Heraclea in Trachis.
*(ramfi/as: Rhamphias is the father of Clearchus, who is well known as a participator in the expedition of Cyrus. Cf. viii. 8. 14, *kle/arxos o( *(ramfi/ou.

boh/qeian h)=gon : were on the way with reinforcements. A similar attempt had failed the year before. Cf. iv. 132. 5 ff. — 4. *(hra/kleian: Heraclea was founded by the Lacedaemonians in 426 B.C. Cf. iii. 92 f.
o(/ ti...e)/xein : Heraclea was not prosperous owing to the misconduct of the Lacedaemonian governors and the hostility of the Thessalians. See iii. 93. 12 ff.
And, upon hearing of the battle at Amphipolis, returns home.
*pieri/ou: Pierium; its position is uncertain. Liv. xxxii. 15 has Pieria or Pierium.

kwluo/ntwn tw=n *qessalw=n: as they always tried to do. Brasidas alone succeeded in passing through by his tact and ingenuity, iv. 78 f. Ischagoras had been stopped, iv. 132. § 2, 3.—kai\ a(/ma: introduces, as usual, an important reason: and besides since Brasidas was now dead. Almost like a)/llws te kai/. See on i. 2. 9.— 4. w(=|per h)=|gon: dat. of the ‘person for whom’ coinciding with the limit of motion. Cf. iv. 37. 4, boulo/menoi a)gagei=n au)tou\s *)aqhnai/ois zw=ntas.— 5. ou)de/na kairo\n ei)=nai e)/ti: an abs. expression: “it was now no longer the time,” “the favourable moment
was past.” The connexion is made plain by the inf. dra=n ti . . . e)peno/ei, which belongs to a)cio/xrewn. Herbst, Philol. Anz. 1871, p. 51, connects dra=n ti with kairo\n ei)=nai, and takes a)cio/xrewn as abs., as elsewhere in Thuc. But the position of the words and the emphasis upon au)tw=n seems to demand the connexion of dra=n ti with a)cio/xrewn. In the rel. clause w(=n ka)kei=nos e)peno/ei, kai/ has its freq. observed proleptic force. Cf. i. 74. 25; 83. 7; 117. 16; ii. 86. 5. “Since the Athenians, in consequence of a defeat (h(/ssh| expresses the reason more distinctly than meq' h(=ssan) had gone away, and they themselves were not prepared to carry out on their own account any part of what he had had in mind.”

ma/lista de\ a)ph=lqon ei)do/tes tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous kte(.: Thuc. here lays peculiar stress upon the state of public feeling which prevailed at Sparta. This has been kept in the background throughout the narrative of Brasidas's successes, though plain reference was made to it in iv. 80 and 108. 35 ff., in contrast with Brasidas's eagerness for action. But now that Brasidas is dead, the weaker members of the war party feel the full force of the desire for peace which they well know prevails at home. With this accurate presentation of the reasons which induced the Lacedaemonian generals to return home without having accomplished anything, Thuc. closes his account of the actual events of the ten years' war, and prepares thereby a transition to a retrospective glance in the next three chapters at the general course of the war. In these chapters he also shows, as he proceeds, the inclination of both sides toward peace, and then, in c. 17, tells of its conclusion.
The desire for peace gains ground both in Athens and in Sparta. The reasons for this.

cune/bh te: used to conclude and sum up what precedes, as in c. 10. 33. But the great importance attributed to the following presentation of the altered circumstances in the two hostile states, occasions first the use of the significant introductory particle w(/ste, and then the completely independent position of the second member of the sent., pro\s de\ th
 ei)rh/nhn ma=llon th
 gnw/mhn ei)=xon kte(. This second member reaches with its subdivisions and explanations into the following chapters, and contains those observations which seemed to the author of most consequence in connexion with this important division between the two periods of the war. The first member of the result clause, pole/mou me
 mhde
 e)/ti a(/yasqai mhdete/rous, is prefixed as a statement of fact (in the aor.) upon which depends the truth of the succeeding statements. This explains how the force of eu)qu/s before meta\ th
 kte(. is felt only in connexion with the second consequence (pro\s de\ th
 kte(.), and not with the first (mhde
 e)/ti a(/yasqai mhdete/rous), the neg. character of which
is alone sufficient to preclude any relation to eu)qu/s. — 3. w(/ste: an emphatic transition (though not after cumbai/nein), also in i. 28. 18; 76. 17; 119. 7; iii. 75. 7; iv. 132. 17; Hdt.iii. 14. 24.

pro\s de\...ei)=xon : the repetition of the same words from the close of the preceding chap. is intentional. The state of mind there attributed to the Lacedaemonians is here expressly extended to both sides as the underlying reason for their subsequent conduct.

oi( me\n *)aqhnai=oi: the reasons are given as far as genh/sesqai in partics.; then in the finite verbs e)dedi/esan and meteme/lonto.—e)pi\ *dhli/w|: cf. iv. 100 f. See Grote, VI. p. 173 f.—di) o)li/gou: after a short interval. Cf. i. 77. 22; v. 69. 19.
pisth/n: in pred. position receives the chief emphasis of the sent., so that h(=|per refers to e)lpi\s pisth/.— pro/teron: cf. iv. 21. 5 ff.; 41. 16 f.— 8. kaqupe/rteroi: also in vii. 56. 7.

tou\s cumma/xous...e)dedi/esan...mh\...a)postw=si : proleptic as in ii. 67. 23. Not only was their confidence in their own strength diminished, but they feared more general (e)pi\ ple/on) desertion by their allies, if they continued the war without success. See App.
meteme/lonto: elsewhere const. with the partic. (iv. 27. 13; v. 35. 17; vii. 50. 21), is here used with o(/ti to avoid the awkwardness of two parties. side by side.

parasxo/n: pare/sxen and parasxh/sei (in Hdt. also pare/xei, iii. 73. 2; 142. 11) are used impers.: “the chance offers.” Cf. iv. 85. 8; vi. 86. 22, most freq. the partic. abs. as in i. 120. 18; iv. 85. 8; v. 60. 25; 63. 3.

oi( de\ *lakedaimo/nioi: sc. pro\s th\n ei)rh/nhn ma=llon th\n gnw/mhn ei)=xon, the reasons for which are given partly in the gens. abs. a)pobai/nontos pole/mou, lhsteuome/nhs th=s xw/ras, au)tomolou/ntwn tw=n *ei(lw/twn and prosdoki/as ou)/shs, partly in the inserted clause with the nom. peripeso/ntes.
o)li/gwn e)tw=n : gen. of time as in i. 3. 11; vii. 3. 5.— 14. ei) th\n gh=n te/mnoien: by the system of e)sbolai/ adopted in the first years of the war.

e)n th=| nh/sw|:
Sphacteria. Cf. iv. 29 to 39.
e)k th=s *pu/lou: iv. 41. 5 ff.—kai\ *kuqh/rwn: iv. 54. 19. — 17. au)tomolou/ntwn tw=n *ei(lw/twn: iv. 41. 11.
prosdoki/as ou)/shs mh/: as in ii. 93. 14.— toi=s e)/cw: those who were beyond the border. Cf. iv. 66. 8.
w(/sper kai\ pro/teron: in the great revolt of the Helots, called the third Messenian war, mentioned in i. 101. 6.
cune/baine de\ kai/: “an additional consideration was,” or, more literally, it happened together with this also. Cf. c. 10. 33 and note.

triakontou/teis: after the analogy of i. 23. 19; 115. 3; ii. 2. 2; v. 27. 1 (the Mss. vary here between triakontae/teis and triakontaetei=s). The truce came to an end in the next year (cf. c. 28. 8) and had therefore been made in 451 B.C.—ei) mh/ tis: a similar use occurs in ii. 37. 2; iii. 67. 33; iv. 68. 28, ei)/ te mh\ pei/setai/ tis, au)tou= th\n ma/xhn e)/sesqai.—th\n *kunosouri/an: disputed territory on the borders of Laconia and Argolis. See on iv. 56. 12. Cf. c. 41.

w(/st) a)du/nata...a(/ma polemei=n : the emphasis rests upon a(/ma; “it was clearly impossible to carry on war against both at once.” The neut. pl. as in i. 59. 4, where meaning and expression are very similar, except that instead of a(/ma as here, the same effect is there produced by te . . . kai/. See App.

tw=n te e)n *peloponnh/sw| kte(.: the general feeling against Sparta in the middle states of Peloponnesus, which came to a head after the conclusion of the peace (c. 27. 1 ff.; 29. 17 ff.), was gaining ground on account of the inclination to peace which had prevailed among them for some time. If the double war had arisen, Sparta would have been in the greatest danger.
o(/per kai\ e)ge/neto: cf. c. 29.
Especially strong was the desire of the Lacedaemonians to obtain the release of their citizens who had been captured at Sphacteria. They thought the Athenians, too, might now be ready for peace.

a)mfote/rois au)toi=s: the reference of tau=ta to both sides collectively is emphasized by the addition of au)toi=s, after which the subsequent separate mention of the Lacedaemonians is all
the more remarkable. Cf. iv. 20. 1, h(mi=n a)mfote/rois.

kai\ ou)x h(=sson : as often equiv. to kai\ ma/lista. Cf. i. 82. 18; ii. 52. 3; iii. 45. 27; v. 26. 26. While, as has been shown above, the general state of things occasioned by the unexpected course of the war was discouraging to the Lacedaemonians, they were esp. influenced toward peace by the desire of obtaining the release of the prisoners.

komi/sasqai: added as an explanation of e)piqumi/a| tw=n a)ndrw=n, as in Plat. Crit. 52 c, ou)d' e)piqumi/a se a)/llwn no/mwn e)/laben ei)de/nai. Cf. iv. 108. 37, boulo/menoi ma=llon tou/s te a)/ndras tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou komi/sasqai. —oi( *spartia=tai au)tw=n: the Spartiates among them, about 120 in number. Cf. iv. 38. 29.
kai\ o(moi/ws sfi/si cuggenei=s: see App.
h)/rcanto...pra/ssein : they immediately began negotiations, mentioned also in iv. 41. 14.
a(/lwsis: not elsewhere used of the capture of persons; but here this is easily explained, since the capture of the men coincided with that of the island.

ou)/pws: see App.—eu)= fero/menoi: “as long as they got on well.” Cf. c. 16. 9; ii. 60. 7, kalw=s me
 ga fero/menos a)nh to\ kaq) e(auto
 diafqeirome/nhs th=s patri/dos ou)de
 h(=sson cunapo/llutai. —e)pi\ th=| i(/sh|: elliptical, though no particular subst. is to be supplied; on equal conditions. See on i. 27. 3.— 9. paraxrh=ma: belongs primarily with gno/ntes. The Lacedaemonians perceived immediately that the defeat at Delium (iv. 89 ff.) would incline the Athenians to make concessions. The conclusion of the truce was brought about somewhat later. Cf. iv. 117. 1.—e)ndecame/nous: see App.
th\n e)niau/sion e)kexeiri/an: cf. iv. 117. 15.—e)n h(=| e)/dei...bouleu/esqai : cf. iv. 118. 50 ff.; iv. 119. 11 f.
Now that Cleon and Brasidas were dead, the disposition to peace was encouraged in Athens by Nicias, and in Sparta by King Pleistoanax, about whose return from exile evil stories were circulated.
o( me\n...o( de/ : chiastic order, as in 10 ff.

dia\ to\ eu)tuxei=n te
kai\ tima=sqai e)k tou= polemei=n: “because he owed his great successes as well as his reputation (not at Sparta only, but among all the Greeks) to his previous activity as general,” and could therefore only hope to retain his influence by a continuance of the war.

kakourgw=n: with katafane/steros, as diaba/llwn with a)pisto/teros: “with his rascalities, with his (continual) calumnies”; and therefore diaba/llwn is necessary instead of diabalw/n of good Mss. In these words a severe judgment of Cleon's general character and conduct, special traits of which have been mentioned before (cf. iii. 36. 26; iv. 21. 9; 27. 18 ff.; 28. 26 f.; 39. 11; v. 7. 3 ff.), is unequivocally expressed.
to/te de/: see App. —e(kate/ra| th=| po/lei speu/dontes ta\ ma/list' au)th/n: urging it (sc. th\n ei)rh/nhn) most vigorously for each of the two cities, i.e. trying to bring it about. See App.

plei=sta: adv. — 11. h)ciou=to: in other words, e)n a)ciw/mati h)=n, as in i. 130. 2 f.; not elsewhere found in this signification.—e)n w(=| kte(: “now while his good fortune and influence were still at their height, he wished to take care that they should remain unimpaired.” (diasw/sasqai, aor.)
pepau=sqai: pf., “to have attained his end,” “to have come to rest.” GMT. 18, 3 b, N.
katalipei=n o)/noma: reputation; also in vi. 33. 29 f.
diege/neto: had reached his end. Like diesw/qh, iv. 96. 33. Closely connected with ou)de\n sfh/las: without having injured the state. diagi/gnesqai in this sense does not occur again before Plutarch.
kai\ o(/stis: i.e. kai\ tou/tw| o(/s.—e)la/xista tu/xh| au(to\n paradi/dwsi: the same expression is employed by Nicias in vi. 23. 11 about himself. e)la/xista like plei=sta, 9.

peri\ th=s kaqo/dou : his return from his exile after the unsuccessful campaign of 446 B.C. Cf. i. 114. 9 ff.; ii. 21. 8 f. —e)s e)nqumi/an proballo/menos: pers. const. The explanation follows in the
words w(s dia\ th\n e)kei/nou ka/qodon paranomhqei=san tau=ta cumbai/noi. e)s e)nqumi/an proba/llein is “to cast as a reproach,” “to cause to weigh upon the conscience.” Cf. proballo/mena, i. 73. 13; to\n proballo/menon lo/gon, vi. 92. 19. See App.
o(po/te ti ptai/seian: explanatory modification of a)ei/, 19.

paranomhqei=san: attrib. partic. placed after its subst. On account of his illegally accomplished return. Thuc. freq. places the attrib. partic. after its subst. when other modifiers are added. See on i. 11. 19.

a)delfoi=: see App.—w(/ste: const. with pei/qein. Cf. ii. 2. 23; iii. 70. 21.—e)pi\ polu/: temporal, as in i. 7. 6; ii. 16. 1. Lit. for a long time, i.e. repeatedly, to which the pres. partic. a)fiknoume/nois corresponds. “Every time messengers came (on other business) to Delphi.” See on a)fiknoume/nwn, i. 91. 3.

*dio\s ui(ou=: so here the Mss. For ui(ou= see Foucart, Revue de philol. 1, p. 36. *(hrakle/ous, to\ spe/rma, to
 a)po/gonon, eu)la/kan de\ th
 u(/nin *lakedaimo/nioi le/gousin, eu)lacei=n (this form also in the text, with Schol. and Plut. de Pyth. oraculis 403 B, instead of eu)lakei=n)de\ a)ro/sein, a)rgure/a| eu)la/ka| eu)lacei=n tou=t' e)/sti limo
 e)/sesqai kai\ pollou= sfo/dra to
 si=ton w)nh/sesqai w(/sper a)rguroi=s e)rgalei/ois xrwme/nous. Schol. On eu)lacei=n, Cobet, Mnem. 6, p. 155, justly observes that the Dor. form of the fut. must be written with the Dor. accent.
xro/nw| de/: referring to e)pi\ polu/, 23; and therefore the subj. of protre/yai is th\n pro/mantin, not *pleistoa/nakta.

e)s *lu/kaion : in the Arcadian mountains, with an ancient and celebrated sanctuary of Zeus.— 28. meta\ dw/rwn dokou=san a)naxw/rhsin: dokou=san, as in i. 32. 15, of the belief which was, though not proved, generally received. This corresponds to the report in ii. 21. 8, h( fugh\ au)tw=| e)ge/neto e)k *spa/rths do/canti xrh/masi peisqh=nai th\n a)naxw/rhsin. See App.

to/te: he occupied this dwelling at that time while in banishment.— h(/misu th=s oi)ki/as tou= i(erou=: i.e. a house, half of which belonged to the temple of Zeus, so that he could, fo/bw| tw=n (with Vat. for tw=|, cf. c. 11. 11) *lakedaimoni/wn, retreat at any moment to the shelter of the sanctuary. i(erou= is
pred. part. gen. H. 732 a.
e)/tei e(no\s de/onti ei)kostw=|: i.e. 427 B.C., since he had left the country in 446 B.C. (i. 114. 9 ff.; cf. ii. 21. 6).

tou\s basile/as: the pl. refers doubtless to the two kings at Sparta; prob. without reference to the controversy mentioned by Hdt.vi. 52. 1 ff., as to whether Aristodemus himself originally occupied the throne. See O. Müller, Dorier, p. 90.

On this account Pleistoanax was all the more active in furthering the reconciliation; and after long negotiations a peace was brought about toward the end of the winter between the Athenians on one side, and the Lacedaemonians, with most of their allies, on the other.

a)xqo/menos ou)=n th=| diabolh=| tau/th|: resumes diaballo/menos, in c. 16. 18, with its results, while nomi/zwn introduces the other considerations by which he was influenced, which led to the result prouqumh/qh (aor.), he conceived the ardent wish; with subst. obj. as in viii. 1. 5; 90. 9.
komizome/nwn: i.e. ei) komi/zointo.
a)po\ tw=n cumforw=n : “on occasion of,” etc., as in ii. 25. 13, a)po\ tou/tou tou= tolmh/matos e)ph|ne/qh.

e)s lo/gous, kai\ pro\s to\ e)/ar h)/dh : the punctuation is that adopted by St. and Cl., who put a comma after lo/gous, and, 10, a comma instead of a period after e)sakou/oien, and, 17, a third comma after *ni/saian. The te in to/n te xeimw=na tou=ton brings into close connexion with one another not the times to\n xeimw=na and pro\s to\ e)/ar h)/dh, but the events h)=|san e)s lo/gous and paraskeuh\ proepanesei/sqh, kte(., and the te of paraskeuh/ te corresponds further to kai/, 10. This kai/ introduces the third member of the period, i.e. as far as 17, to/te dh/. The temporal force of the long clause e)peidh\ . . . th\n *ni/saian is repeated by to/te dh/. See App.—h)=|san: see App.
kai\ pro\s to\ e)/ar h)/dh: in close connexion: “and when the spring was already near.” See on i. 30. 20.

paraskeuh/ te: corresponding to to/n te xeimw=na h)=|san e)s lo/gous: on the one hand, negotiations were conducted; on the other hand, warlike demonstrations were made. On the use of te . . . te to give equal importance to two ideas, see on i. 8. 14; also iii. 81. 5.—proepanesei/sqh: h( po-
lemikh\ paraskeuh\ prohpeilh/qh, Schol. The same figurative expression occurs in e)pana/seisis tw=n o(/plwn, iv. 126. 22. Cf. vi. 86. 2, prosei/ontes fo/bon.—a)po\ tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn: from the Lacedaemonian side, similarly i. 141. 6; iii. 36. 24, gnw=mai a)f) e(ka/stwn e)le/gonto.
periaggellome/nh : closely connected with paraskeuh/. The warlike demonstration of the Lacedaemonians consisted of proclamations calling for military service.—w(s e)s e)piteixismo/n: see App.
e)sakou/oien: give heed, obey. Cf. i. 82. 11; 126. 3; iii. 4. 3; iv. 110. 1; v. 45. 18; 50. 1; viii. 31. 10.

dikaiw/seis: “demands made with an assumption of right.” See on i. 141. 6.—proenegko/ntwn: gen. abs. with no subj. expressed. Cf. i. 2. 8 and note; ii. 52. 9; iii. 82. 6; iv. 94. 10. For the force of profe/rein, see on iii. 59. 11, profero/menoi o(/rkous; iii. 64. 7, mh\ profe/rete th\n to/te genome/nhn cunwmosi/an.—cunexwrei=to: only here in neut. pass. The impf. denotes the hardly attained result. The agreement reached is introduced by w(/ste. Cf. i. 28. 18, e(toi=moi de\ ei)=nai kai\ w(/ste a)mfote/rous me/nein kata\ xw/ran. GMT. 98, 2, N. 2. See App.
e)/sxon: had acquired. Inceptive aor. G. 200, N. 5 b; H. 841.
e)/xein: retain, keep.—a)ntapaitou/ntwn: sc. tw=n *)aqhnai/wn.
e)/fasan ou) bi/a| kte(.: cf. iii. 52. 10, where the still more positive expression au)tw=n e(ko/ntwn prosxwrhsa/ntwn is used.

kai\ ou) prodo/ntwn: does not continue the idea of prosxwrhsa/ntwn with entire accuracy, since the subj. of prodo/ntwn comprises only part of the subj. of prosxwrhsa/ntwn, but the sense is easily understood from the connexion, and the antithesis is a natural one.
kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi...*ni/saian : sc. e)/xein e)/fasan. A remark of the author, not of the Thebans. — 17. parakale/santes: a word used esp. of the cu/mmaxoi. Cf. i. 67. 3; 68. 10; v. 30. 12.

w(/ste: cf. 12.—tou/tois de/: refers back to the words before tw=n a)/llwn. — ou)k h)/reske ta\ prasso/mena:
the separate negotiations between the Lacedaemonians and Athenians, as in iv. 121. § 1.
poiou=ntai th\n cu/mbasin , kte(.: the conclusion of the peace took place in Sparta, as appears also from parakale/santes, 17. See Ullrich, Beitr., 1862, p. 4.
The terms of the treaty between the Athenians on the one hand and the Lacedaemonians, with such of their allies as joined them, on the other.
*sponda\s e)poih/santo kte(.: see App.

kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi: refers esp. to the allies of Sparta. The allies of the Athenians rarely (but see 10) appear in independent action. Cf. c. 47. 1 f. The same relation exists below § 9; and therefore kata\ po/leis here and in 48 refers only to the allies of the Lacedaemonians.

peri\ me
 tw=n i(erw=n tw=n koinw=n: standing at the beginning of the sent., is used almost abs. as regards the national sanctuaries. The sanctuaries referred to are esp. those at Delphi and Olympia. Cf. iii. 57. 7, and see on iv. 118. 1 f.—e)cei=nai: see App.— 5. to\ i(ero
 kai\ to
 new/n: new/s is the temple proper, i(ero/n the consecrated enclosure about the temple. Cf. iv. 90. 7.

au)tono/mous kte(.: i.e. free from external influence, esp. that of the Phocians, which had occasioned serious hostilities between Sparta and Athens. See i. 112. 13 ff. The unusual expression au)totelei=s kai\ au)todi/kous is used in order to exclude every kind of foreign interference. The temple and the inhabitants of Delphi are here joined in an indivisible community, and the following preds. apply to both in common.
a)do/lous kai\ a)blabei=s kai\ kata\ gh=n kai\ kata\ qa/lassan: this, like several other expressions in this chapter, is the regular formula. Cf. c. 47. § 1-4.
h)/n: see App.—dia/foron: adj. disputed, as in i. 56. 2.
dikai/w|: subst. legal means, settlement by law. Elsewhere with the art., as in iii. 39. 20.

a)podo/ntwn de/: this paragraph concerning the restoration of the places taken by the Lacedaemonians extends to 31. After the mention of the most important one among them, Amphipolis, the stipulations regarding their treatment are inserted (o(/sas de\ po/leis . . . e)ge/nonto, 25); and then the smaller towns which had revolted from Athens in the course of the war, and are to be restored, are mentioned by name: ei)si\ de\(ai(/de, which the inferior Mss. insert here, interferes with the connexion) *)/argilos . . . *spa/rtwlos. Then follows a number of special provisions. See App.

pare/dosan: we should expect a)\n paradw=si, but in the language of the treaty the provision requiring the restoration of the towns is regarded as already fulfilled. Cf. e)peidh\ e)ge/nonto in 24. But see App. on 18.

au)tou/s: the inhabitants (or, accepting Kirchhoff's reading, pare/labon for pare/dosan in 19, the Athenians who were in these cities) themselves. This emphasis upon the pronoun necessitates the use of the connective kai/ before e)/xontes.—ferou/sas to\n fo/ron: expresses the same condition as a)podo/ntwn to\n fo/ron, 24, if they or as long as they pay the tribute.

to\n e)p' *)aristei/dou: the first appointment of the tribute to be paid by members of the Delian confederacy was ascribed to Aristides (Plut. Arist. 24; Dem. XXIII. 209; Paus. viii. 52). See on i. 96. 5.

e)peidh\...e)ge/nonto : i.e. after the ratification of the treaty. See on 19, above. Until then the Athenians could try to subject the cities by violence, and the above provisions of the treaty were not in force.
*sta/geiros: see App. on c. 6. 2.

boulome/nas: “with their own
free will and consent.” See App.— 29. *)aqhnai/ois: const. with e)ce/stw. Because this provision applies only to the Athenians, they are mentioned a second time at the end of the sent.

*mhkubernai/ous kai\ *sanai/ous kai\ *siggai/ous: St. conjectures that these places were among those mentioned in i. 58. 11 ff., which had united in the foundation of Olynthus. Steup, Stud. Thuc. I. p. 40 ff., and Kirchhoff, Sitzungsber. d. Berl. Akad. 1882, p. 924, assume that the Olynthians claimed the rights of suzerainty over Mecyberna, the Acanthians over Sane and Singus. These claims are here denied, and the three towns are, at the instance of the Athenians, placed upon an equal footing with Olynthus and Acanthus.
*pa/nakton: this provision, made without the consent of the Boeotians (see c. 3. 24 and 17. 18), was only imperfectly executed. See c. 42. 2 ff.
*korufa/sion: the Lacedaemonian name for Pylos. It was taken by the Athenians in 425 B.C. See iv. 3 ff.

*ku/qhra: was taken by the Athenians in 424 B.C. See iv. 53 ff.—*meqw/nhn: was seized by the Athenians in 425 B.C. See iv. 45. 5 ff. See App.—*pteleo/n: has not been mentioned elsewhere by Thuc. Perhaps it is the place in Boeotia mentioned in Pliny, iv. 7. 26. —*)atala/nthn: an island near the Opuntian Locrians, was occupied by the Athenians in 431 B.C. See ii. 32.— 35. e)n tw=| dhmosi/w|: e)n tw=| desmwthri/w|, Schol. Cf. iv. 41. 1, oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)boi/leusan desmoi=s me\n au)tou\s fula/ssein me/xri ou(= ti cumbw=sin.
a)/lloqi pou o(/shs : like a)/lloqi pou h(=s, 41, with the rare ellipsis of gh=s. Part. gen. G. 168, N. 3; H. 757.
tou\s e)n *skiw/nh| poliorkoume/nous: see iv. 130. 34 and 131. 8.
a)fei=nai: here, as above, § 3 and 4, and below, § 9 and 10, the inf. and imv. interchange. GMT. 103; H. 957 a; Kühn. 474 b, and 595, 5.
o(/sous *brasi/das e)se/pemye: see iv. 123. 16,
*sermuliw=n: from inscriptions for Ms. *(ermuli/wn. The gens., at first loosely joined with ei)/ tina a)/llhn po/lin, are taken up again in the following peri\ au)tw=n. See App.

o)mnu/ntwn de/: this provision concerning the form of oath is, like the one above, 19 ff., concerning the treatment of the restored cities, inserted as a parenthesis between the corresponding members of the sent., o(/rkous de\ . . . po/leis and 52, e)/stw de\ . . . a)mfote/rous. The Athenians are to make oath to the Lacedaemonians as well as to those of their allies who unite in the peace; hence the pl. o(/rkous, 47. The Lacedaemonians and their allies take an oath to the Athenians only; hence, 53, o(/rkos pro\s *)aqhnai/ous.—e(ka/teroi: i.e. the Athenians on one side, the Lacedaemonians and their allies on the other. (Kirchhoff brackets e(ka/teroi.) —to\n e)pixw/rion o(/rkon to\n me/giston: Fränkel, Hermes, 13, p. 460, has shown that the oath by which the Athenians usually ratified treaties was sworn by Zeus, Demeter, and Apollo. Ullrich, Beitr. 1862, p. 7 ff., suggests for Sparta the Dioscuri, tw\ *siw/.
e(ptakai/deka e)c e(ka/sths po/lews : see App.

*)aqh/nhsi: see App.—e)n po/lei: i.e. e)n th=| *)akropo/lei. Cf. ii. 15. 33 f. —e)n *)amuklai/w|: i.e. in the temple of Apollo of Amyclae, which lay, acc. to Polyb. v. 19, twenty stadia from the city.

o(/tou: after o(poteroiou=n is easily understood in place of o(touou=n.— lo/gois dikai/ois: “negotiations about what is just,” “the just or legal method,” opp. to every sort of violence. So also in c. 98. 2.

eu)/or-
kon: consistent with their oath, i.e. with the sworn treaty.
The day of the ratification of the treaty and the names of those on both sides who took the oath.

This chapter is part of the official document recording the peace. It determines the day with which the peace shall begin for all parties, and gives the names of the men who are to take the oath. In c. 20 the narrative is resumed with the mention of the date of the ratification of the treaty. The indics. a)/rxei, w)/mnuon kai\ e)spe/ndonto, are not unusual in treaties. See Steup, Stud. I. p. 68.

a)/rxei: the manner of dating differs from that of iv. 118. 49, inasmuch as here, not the day, but the year appears as subj.; for e)/foros *pleisto/las and a)/rxwn *)alkai=os are the usual expressions for the year, Ol. 89, 3. The dats. (teta/rth| and e(/kth|) denoting the day immediately follow the nouns denoting the year. Lit., the year of the Ephor Pleistolas, etc., begins the peace on the fourth day from the end of Artemisios; i.e. the peace begins on the fourth, etc. The 27th of Artemisios in Sparta or the 25th of Elaphebolion in Athens for the year 421 B.C. fell about the middle of April. See Curtius, Hist. of Greece, III. p. 207.

*pleistoa/nac, *)=agis: see App.— 8. *)aqhnai/wn de/: of the seventeen Athenians, eleven (since for *)aristokri/ths of the Mss. we must certainly write *)aristokra/ths from c. 24; cf. viii. 89. 12) are known to us as generals in the course of the war. Among these Nicias, Laches, Hagnon, Lamachus, and Demosthenes are the most noted. Lampon was celebrated (Plut. Per. c. 6) and derided (Ar. Av. 521, 988) as an oraclemonger. Only Isthmionicus, Procles (for the general Procles of Ol. 88. 2 fell in the campaign against the Aetolians; see iii. 98. 23), Myrtilus, Iolcius, and Timocrates are not elsewhere mentioned. The reason for the number seventeen cannot be determined with any degree of certainty. Ullrich suggests on the Athenian side perhaps two priests, half of the generals of that year, and one citizen of each phyle. Perhaps the oath was taken on the Lacedaemonian side by a number of Lacedaemonians and one each from the allied cities which took part in the peace. Certainly the words kai\
w)/mosan kata\ po/leis in c. 18. 2 seem to imply that the allies took part in the oath as prescribed in c. 18. 47 ff., though Ullrich, p. 19, believes that they did not. Perhaps the number of Athenian envoys at Sparta had gradually risen to seventeen, all of whom were then commissioned to take the oath, or perhaps Kirchhoff is right in deducing the number from the peculiar Spartan constitution, in which case the seventeen Athenians would be appointed to correspond to the seventeen Spartans. See App. on c. 18. 50.
Previous duration of the war. Remarks on the best way of reckoning periods of time.
au(=tai ai( spondai\ e)ge/nonto: is a brief re-statement of the contents of the latter part of c. 17 (to/te dh/ parakale/santes, . . . ta/de).

e)k *dionusi/wn eu)qu\s tw=n a)stikw=n: the city or greater Dionysia began before the vernal equinox, and lasted several days, until about the end of March. e)k of immediate sequence, as in i. 120. 17, e)k me\n ei)rh/nhs polemei=n; ii. 49. 9, e)/peita e)c au)tw=n ptarmo\s kai\ bra/gxos e)pegi/gneto.—au)to/deka e)/th: exactly ten years, corresponding to Lat. decem ipsi dies. (Kr. compares au)totragiko\s pi/qhkos, Dem. XVIII. 242.)

parenegkousw=n: parafe/rein here and in c. 26. 8 intr. like diafe/rein, profe/rein (i. 93. 13), u(perfe/rein (i. 81. 2) be in excess, vary. With this h)\ w(s stands in close connexion: after exactly ten years had passed, and a few days were in excess since (i.e. had passed along further than when), etc. In accordance with the date of the beginning of the war as given in ii. 2, the words h( e)sbolh\ . . . tou= pole/mou tou=de must be closely connected, so that h( a)rxh\ tou= pole/mou tou=de refers to the attack upon Plataea, i.e. to the beginning of April, 431 B.C. h( e)sbolh\ h( e)s th\n *)attikh/n is mentioned first, as the more important event, but in the computation of the time it is made subordinate to the attack upon Plataca. The o)li/gai h(me/rai parenegkou=sai are, then, in the early part of April. The day upon which the peace began is mentioned in c. 19. 1, and falls about the middle of April. Here the same day is referred to as a few days after the first of April. But ten days, or even two weeks, may well be called a few days when a ten years' war is under consideration. See App.

kai\ mh\ th\n a)pari/qmhsin: this passage (to pisteu/sas ma=llon) is corrupt in all Mss. But the sense is evidently: one must (in order to understand
events properly) date them according to the (natural) divisions of time, and not acc. to (kata/ is understood with a)pari/qmhsin; see on i. 6. 21; ii. 63. 4; iii. 21. 10) the count of the names of the persons who serve in each place, either as highest magistrate or from any (other, e.g. priestly) office (as in Argos; cf. ii. 2. 4), to designate the year, because one considers that safer, for that is inexact (i.e. to embrace a whole year in this way), since something happened at the beginning as well as in the middle or at any other time of their tenure of office. oi(s is used in the sense of e)pei\ tou/tois to explain a)rxo/ntwn h)\ a)po\ timh=s tinos. See App.
kai\ o(/pws e)/tuxe/ tw|: sc. e)pigeno/menon. “In whatever other part of their time of office an event may have happened,” whether at the end, or in the first or in the second half, etc.
e)pege/neto: as in i. 16. 1 and vii. 87. 14.

w(/sper ge/graptai: “as has been done hitherto in my narrative.” Cf. ii. 1. 4.—e)c h(misei/as kte(.: acc. to the explanation given in the Introd. to Book I. p. 40, equiv. to e(kate/rou(tou= te qe/rous kai\ tou= xeimw=nos)th\n du/namin e)/xontos e)c h(misei/as tou= e)niautou=, “inasmuch as each of the two divisions of the year is to be reckoned (on an average) as half a year,” i.e. so that the two divisions, though not necessarily equal to one another, when taken together always make a year.

tw=| prw/tw| pole/mw|: also in c. 24. 12 and c. 26. 15. This and o( pro/teros po/lemos (vii. 18. 12) and o( dekaeth\s po/lemos (c. 25. 3 and 26. 15) are the words used by Thuc. to denote the first period of the Peloponnesian war, for which the designation *)arxida/meios po/lemos came into use among the orators. See Ullrich, Beitr., 1845, p. 13 ff.
The execution of the terms of the treaty meets with opposition at Amphipolis and other places in Thrace.
e)/laxon ga/r: i.e. in the drawing of lots, which evidently took place immediately after the conclusion of the treaty. Cf. c. 35. 7.

a)fi/esan: impf. after analogy of the use of pe/mpein. It expresses continuance of the action. Cf. iii. 111. 14, tou\s me\n *mantine/as kai\ tou\s *peloponnhsi/ous a)fi/esan, tou\s d' *)amprakiw/tas e)/kteinon, and viii. 41. 13.

*)isxago/ran: he took part (see iv. 132. 6 and 13) in the Thracian expedition. These three men all shared in the conclusion of the treaty. Cf. c.
19. 6 f.
to\n *kleari/dan: cf. c. 11. 19.
tou\s a)/llous: i.e. the inhabitants of the towns mentioned in c. 18. 19 ff.—w(s ei)/rhto e(ka/stois: i.e. acc. to the conditions mentioned in c. 18.
e)pithdei/as: this adj. is used with spondai/ also in c. 112. 12 (where it is declined as an adj. of two terminations), proper, acceptable.
toi=s *xalkideu=si: the inhabitants of Amphipolis of Chalcidic descent.—bi/a| e)kei/nwn: this use of bi/a| with gen. occurs also in i. 43. 8; 68. 19; iv. 99. 6.
e)lqw/n: sc. Clearidas. Const. e)s th\n *lakedai/mona with e)lqw/n.—meta\ pre/sbewn: not those mentioned in 4, but envoys of the Amphipolitans themselves, au)to/qen.
a)pologhso/menos : see App.
kateilhmme/nous: see App.—au)to/s: opp. to the pre/sbeis (10) with whom he had come. He was now sent back; the envoys probably stayed to see if they might not still accomplish something.
kai\ to\ xwri/on: kai/ is emphatic. He was to surrender the town itself if possible.
After vain attempts to induce the rest of their allies to join in the peace, the Lacedaemonians make a formal alliance with the Athenians.
oi( de\ cu/mmaxoi: the narrative recurs to the end of c. 17. See App.
profa/sei: the expressed reason, not a pretended one. Cf. i. 23. 23 and note.

to\ prw=ton: see c. 17. 18 ff., where a hint of their reasons is given in ou)k h)/reske ta\ prasso/mena.— de/casqai: on this rare use of the aor.
inf. where the fut. inf. seems to be required, see GMT. 23, 2, N. 3. See App.

e)kei/nous: i.e. all the allies, both those who had and those who had not accepted the peace; hence au)toi/, the Lacedaemonians alone.—au)toi\ de\ pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous...ei) e)ch=n, xwrei=n : this reading of the Mss. may be translated as follows: They themselves were about to make an alliance with the Athenians, thinking that (if they did this) the Argives would by no means (h(/kista, Lat. minime), since they had not been willing to renew their treaty when Ampelidas and Lichas came to them for that purpose,—thinking, I say, that they without the Athenians would not be dangerous to them, and that the rest of Peloponnesus would be least likely to stir. This is certainly very harsh, and is open to so many objections that an emendation seems necessary. For a full discussion of the passage, see App.
e)poiou=nto: impf. expressing intended action: “they decided to form an alliance with Athens.”
tou\s te *)argei/ous: stands first, being the most important consideration (as in c. 14. 20, pro\s tou\s *)argei/ous).

e)pispe/ndesqai: is equiv. to a)/llas spe/ndesqai of c. 14. 21. The names of the envoys are not given in c. 14.—nomi/santes: repeats the meaning of nomi/zontes (7). It is difficult to see why the tense is changed to the aor., and the repetition is certainly unnecessary, or rather, as Kr. says, is inexcusable.

pro\s ga\r a)\n kte(.: “for they thought that the Peloponnesians would join the Athenians if it were possible,” i.e. if the Spartans did not make an alliance with Athens, but in this case the Pelo, ponnesians could no longer join with Athens to the detriment of Sparta.
paro/ntwn ou)=n pre/sbewn: the same who had arranged the treaty of peace, and taken the oaths. See c. 24. § 1.
The terms of the treaty of alliance between the Lacedaemonians and the Athenians.
(kai/ *)aqhnai=oi): see App.
tro/pw|...dunato/n : the formal and somewhat verbose language is characteristic of the style of documents. Cf. 11, and c. 47. 14 and 23. Kühn. 582, 2, N. 4.
katalu/ein: abs. without po/lemon. So also in 14 and vii. 58. 8 f.
ei)=nai: used like gi/gnesqai with advs. is a somewhat antiquated usage. Cf. 15.

h( doulei/a: in collective sense occurs also in Plato, Legg. vi. 776 c. and Arist. Pol. ii. 5. The danger here referred to was also mentioned in c. 14. 17 ff. as one of the reasons for concluding the peace.
*)aqhnai/ous: see App.
o)mou=ntai: the same transition to a finite mood as in c. 18. 12.
ta\ *dionu/sia: the great or city Dionysia (cf. c. 20. 2) at which time many foreigners visited Athens.

ta\ *(uaki/nqia: the festival of Apollo of Amyclae in the month Hyacinthios,
corresponding to the Attie Hecatombaeon.
The names of the Lacedaemonians and Athenians who took the oath. Restoration of the prisoners taken at Sphacteria.

to\n de\ o(/rkon kte(.: as Steup, Stud. I. p. 84, observes, c. 24. § 1 belongs to the document recording the treaty. The narrative begins again in 9, au(/th h( cummaxi/a. The same relation exists between c. 19 and c. 20.
*pleistoa/nac kte(.: with the exception of some slight differences in the order (*te/llis, *)alkina/das, and *niki/as, *la/xhs above) this list is identical with that of c. 19.
kai\ tou\s a)/ndras: kai/ denotes immediate connexion: “and straightway.” — tou\s a)/ndras tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou: cf. c. 15. 2 f. and iv. 108. 38.

tau=ta ta\ de/ka e)/th: continues the idea of tou= e(ndeka/tou e)/tous (in which the de/ka e)/th are contained by implication), and therefore stands first, though these words belong grammatically, as acc. of duration of time, with cunexw=s geno/menos. This attrib. partic. is placed after its subst. in accordance with the usage discussed in the note on i. 11. 17. The more usual order would be: o( prw=tos tau=ta ta\ de/ka e)/th cunexw=s geno/menos po/lemos ge/graptai, i.e. “the history of the first (part of the) war which lasted without interruption for these ten years is finished” (pf.). With this cunexw=s geno/menos po/lemos the period of uncertain and unquiet peace until the renewal of the fanero\s po/lemos is contrasted in c. 25, and in c. 26 we have a general retrospect of the whole twenty-seven years' war with its three divisions. This furnishes Thuc. an occasion to speak of his own relation to the war.
