The division introduced by the peace occasions a break in the continuous narrative of the war, and the great importance of this division calls forth these remarks from the author.

div2.head: Character and duration of the time of peace between the first and second war.
div2.p: dekaeth=: see App.
*)aqh/nhsi: cf. c. 18. 55.
*kori/nqioi: see c. 17. 19 and 27. 5 ff.

dieki/noun: hardly occurs elsewhere in Attic prose. Cf. Ar. Nub. 477, diaki/nei to\n nou=n au)tou=. It seems here to denote the attempt to break up and unsettle by intrigues the agreements (ta\ pepragme/na) which had been made. —kai\ eu)qu\s a)/llh taraxh/: “and besides these intrigues of the Corinthians, other disturbances began immediately (after the end of the conflict between Athens and Sparta) between the Lacedaemonians and their (former) allies.” a)/llh refers to what precedes, not to the following kai\ a(/ma; hence St. is wrong in inserting te after a)/llh without Ms. authority. This is evident, for the Athenians, although they had just made an alliance with Sparta, are certainly not included among the cu/mmaxoi of 8. kai\ a(/ma introduces, as it freq. does (e.g. c. 14. 9), a new and important statement. For this was the most serious matter, that the friendly relations between Sparta and Athens were so soon disturbed.

a(\ ei)/rhto: are the separate articles of the cugkei/mena. Cf. c. 35. 5 ff. —kai\ e)pi\ e(\c e)/th kai\ de/ka mh=nas: neither beginning nor end of this period is accurately fixed. The beginning is not meta\ ta\s sponda/s, but meta/ th\n cummaxi/an, which was formed ou) pollw=| u(/steron (cf. c. 24. 9). (Grote, VI. p. 276 and note, thinks this interval between the two treaties was ‘not more than a month or two.’ Curtius, Hist. III. p. 285, thinks it was ‘a few weeks.’) The end is only loosely marked by the words a)pe/sxonto mh\ e)pi\ th\n e(kate/rwn gh=n strateu=sai. See App.

mh/: after the neg. a)pe/sxonto. See on iii. 32. 14; iv. 40. 5. G. 263; H. 1029.—e)/cwqen: i.e. without invading the territory of one another, but by taking part in hostile complications with others such as are mentioned in c. 26. § 2. Among these, the war in Sicily is most important.

met' a)nokwxh=s: see App.— meta/: “during the continuance,” “un
der the influence of.”

e)/peita me/ntoi: i.e. when they no longer avoided direct attacks.—a)nagkasqe/ntes...kate/sthsan : the subj. must be here as in 11, *lakedaimo/nioi kai\ *)aqhnai=oi. Therefore the sent. cannot refer to any single act. First the Athenians with thirty triremes ravaged the coast of Laconia in the latter part of the summer of 414 B.C. (vi. 105. 13 f.); the Lacedaemonians entered Attica to fortify Decelea early in the spring of 413 B.C. (vii. 19. § 1). This last act is probably considered as the beginning of the po/lemos fanero/s, and strictly speaking a)nagkasqe/ntes lu=sai applies only to the Lacedaemonians whose condition is described in vii. 18. § 3, 4. But the various stages in the renewal of the war overlap one another chronologically, as do the events which mark its beginning. Cf. c. 20. § 1.
e)s po/lemon fanero/n: the same words are used to designate the beginning of the first war in i. 23. 26.
Remarks concerning the duration and the division of the whole war, and the author's personal relations to it.

ge/grafe de\ kai\ tau=ta: with reference to the introductory words of the whole work, i. 1. 1. The pf. serves to establish the identity of the author, like the aor. in i. 1. 1 and i. 97. 7, and, like ge/graptai in ii. 1. 4, anticipates the completion of the work. “The same Thuc. has written (i.e. is the author of) this also” does not necessarily imply that the work was ever finished, but is the natural expression of one who expects his work to be finished before these words come before his readers. So when the actual narrative is to begin, we find the fut. e)chgh/somai in 30.
e)ch=s...xeimw=nas : identical with ii. 1. 4 f., and accordingly e)gi/gneto, which better expresses the successive development of events (e(ch=s), is preferred to Ms. e)ge/neto.
ta\ makra\ tei/xh kai\ to\n *peiraia= kate/labon : acc. to Plut. Lys. 15, e(/kth| kai\ deka/th| *mounuxiw=nos, i.e. the middle of April, 404 B.C.
e)ge/neto: used in comprehensive statements of numbers. See on ii. 20. 11.

th\n dia\ me/sou cu/mbasin: i.e. the time of truce between the earlier and the later war. See on iv. 20. 2.— a)ciw/sei: in characteristic opposition to dikaiw/sei. “If any one thinks the period of truce does not deserve (a)/cion) the name of war, he will ignore the relation which is founded upon the nature of the case (di/kaion).”

w(s dih/|rhtai: the only possible subj. appears to be h( dia\ me/sou cu/mbasis.
The best rendering seems, then, to be: how this (so-called) period of truce was really interrupted and torn asunder by the actual circumstances. The usual meaning of diairei=n, rend asunder, break through a fortification (cf. ii. 75. 24; 76. 2; iv. 48. 10; 110. 18; v. 2. 14; 3. 9), is transferred to the interruption of the state of peace; so that diairei=n appears as the opposite of cumbai/nein. See App.
ou)/t' a)pede/canto: see App.

e)/cw te tou/twn: after thenegative infringements of the treaty (10), the more positive breaches of its provisions are mentioned; esp. of that in c. 18. § 4, by supporting insurrections of allies. See App.—pro\s to
 *mantiniko
: see c. 33 ff.—pro\s to
 *)epidau/rion: see c. 53 ff.

e)s a)/lla: refers particularly to the Sicilian expedition.—a(marth/mata e)ge/nonto: the pl. of the verb on account of the previously expressed reference to a variety of cases. H. 604 b. a)mfote/rois e)ge/nonto is equiv. to a)mfo/teroi e)poih/santo.
pole/mioi h)=san : sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois.

e)kexeiri/an dexh/meron : “a truce which was (or must be) renewed every ten days.” *boiwtoi\ pro\s de/ka h(me/ras e)kexeiri/an e)spe/ndonto pro\s *)aqhnai/ous. Schol. Cf. c. 32. 17; vi. 7. 23; 10. 13. See App.
e)c au)th=s: see on c. 20. 2.

kata\ tou\s xro/nous: see on c. 20. 6 and 10.—h(me/ras ou) polla\s parenegkou/sas: see on c. 20. 2. The time is to be computed from the beginning of April, 431 B.C., to the middle of April, 404 B.C. See App. on ii. 2. 5.
a)po\ xrhsmw=n: relying upon prophecies. See on iv. 67. 1.

mo/non dh\ tou=to: refers perhaps to the various interpretations of the oracle in ii. 54. § 2 and 3.—a)ei/: const. with profero/menon (cf. vii. 68. 6). It is explained by kai\ a)rxome/nou tou= pole/mou kai\ me/xri ou(= e)teleu/thse. The whole is further explained by e)pebi/wn de/, which serves to establish the credibility of me/mnhmai e)/gwge, an essential element of the author's fitness for his task of writing the history of the Peloponnesian war.

tri\s e)nne/a: a reminiscence of
the original metrical form of the oracle. Also in Plut. Nic. 9.

ai)sqano/menos (cf. i. 71. 21) th=| h(liki/a|: “having the necessary degree of understanding in consequence of my age” (his age was probably from about forty years upwards). See Introd. to Book I. p. 4. Dat. of cause. G. 188, 1; H. 776.

meta\ th\n e)s *)amfi/polin strathgi/an: see iv. 104 15 ff.; 106. 16 ff.; and Introd. to Book I. p. 11. —genomenw|...pra/gmasi : since I became acquainted with the affairs of both sides. ou)x h(=sson, i.e. ma/lista. Cf. c. 15. 3. The results of this accurate acquaintance with the circumstances of the various states of Peloponnesus are very evident in the subsequent narrative.

ai)/sqesqai. see App. —diafora/n te kai\ cu/gxusin tw=n spondw=n: with these words Thuc. characterizes the period of uncertain peace, much as he calls the unstable condition before the breaking out of the war spondw=n cu/gxusis (i. 146. 4). The diafora/, which is closely connected with the cu/gxusis tw=n spondw=n by the common art. (cf. i. 120. 10; iii. 82. 8 f.), refers particularly, as in i. 81. 10; 102. 7; 146. 1; v. 43. 1; viii. 85. 2, to the disagreements which presently arose.
ta\ e)/peita w(s e)polemh/qh: i.e. the events of the second war.
Continuation of the narrative. The Corinthians are discontented, and make overtures to the Argives in order to bring about an alliance against Sparta.

ga/r: introduces the narrative announced in the previous chap.— 2. kai\ u(/steron h( cummaxi/a: is added to ai( . . . spondai/ almost parenthetically to remind us that the alliance followed the peace, as mentioned in c. 24. 9. It has the effect of a rel. clause (“which was presently followed by the alliance”), and must not be understood as determining the time of the following clause. “After the fifty years' peace had been concluded, and then the alliance also, the ambassadors, too, went home.” The treaty of alliance was concluded so soon after the peace, that it is referred to in the negotiations at Argos (8). See App.

au)ta/: is the
neut. pl. in a pregnant sense referring to the matter in hand. This Thuc. not infreq. uses. See on i. 1. 10. It refers very properly to the negotiations preceding the treaty as well as to the spondai/ (cf. parakale/santes, c. 17. 17, where the purpose of the summons is left unexpressed) and is therefore not to be changed (with St.) to au)ta/s.
prw=ton: refers to preliminary negotiations with prominent men at Argos. The further consequences appear in Argos (c. 28) and in Corinth (c. 30).
e)p' a)gaqw=|: cf. i. 131. 7; ii. 17. 15; iv. 87. 10; and see on e)pi\ kakw=|, iv. 86. 1, for further examples.—e)pi\ katadoulw/sei: cf. iii. 10. 10.

o(ra=n: with o(/pws and fut. ind., as in iii. 46. 16; vi. 41. 6. So with o(/tw| tro/pw| in vi. 33. 13; viii. 63. 20. GMT. 45 Rem.; H. 1054, 3.— 12. au)to/nomos: denotes political independence; di/kas i)/sas kai\ o(moi/as dido/nai denotes conduct which respects the independence of others. The first is intended to exclude the dependent allies of Athens and Sparta, the second more particularly Athens itself, which obliged the u(ph/kooi cu/mmaxoi to come to Athens for the conduct of certain cases (see on i. 77. 1), and therefore could not be said di/kas i)/sas kai\ o(moi/as dido/nai.

w(/ste : on condition that. See on i. 28. 18. GMT. 98, 2, and N. 2; H. 953 b.—th=| a)llh/lwn e)pimaxei=n: like e)pimaxi/an in c. 48. 8, a merely defensive alliance; in i. 44. 8 defined by th=| a)llh/lwn bohqei=n.

a)rxh/n : to be taken with au)tokra/toras, but not in the sense of “power” or “authority” (Kr. “in regard to their authority”), but like th\n a)rxh/n in ii. 74. 10; iv. 98. 4; 56. 5; here, however, as in Hdt.i. 193. 14; ii. 95. 13; iii. 16. 31, without the art. Originally from the beginning, and thence absolutely, entirely. See App.

tou= mh\ katafanei=s gi/gnesqai: sc. toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois. On the gen. of the inf., see on i. 4. 7; GMT. 92, 1, N. 5; H. 960. The envoys from
other states were to be relieved from the necessity of addressing the popular assembly concerning offers of alliance, in order that those who might wish to join the Argive alliance, but could not persuade the Argive popular assembly to accept them as allies (tou\s mh\ pei/santas to\ plh=qos), should not be exposed to danger from the Lacedaemonians. See App.— 17. prosxwrh/sesqai: sc. to the new alliance to be formed under the leadership of Argos.

dida/cantes: like didaska/lous genome/nous in c. 30. 2, of plans and deliberations set forth with arguments, esp. of such as are undertaken with hostile intent. Cf. ii. 93. 4; iii. 71. 7; vii. 18. 6; viii. 45. 9.
The Argives accept the proposals of the Corinthians, and declare themselves ready for the formation of the new alliance.
oi( de\ tw=n *)argei/wn a)/ndres kte(.: on the order of words in the dependent clause, see on iii. 4. 1.

a)nafe/rein: like referre ad senatum, also in Hdt.iii. 71. 20, and 80. 30.— tou\s lo/gous: i.e. the proposals of the Corinthians.—ta\s a)rxa/s: magistratus, also in c. 47. 52 and 55; 84. 20; i. 90. 27.

poiei=sqai: depends grammatically upon e)yhfi/santo, though we should expect poih/setai or poiei=sqai e)cei/h. This use of the inf. in rel. clauses occurs most freq. in quotations from laws and decrees. GMT. 92, 2, N. 3 b.
mhdete/rois: depends upon spei/sasqai.
a)/neu tou= dh/mou : “without express consent of the assembly.” See on i. 91. 23.

e)de/canto/ te: by the particle te Thuc. here introduces a sent. explanatory of what precedes. Cf. ii. 8. 16; 13. 22. Cl.'s change to de/ is unnecessary.—to/n te: the const. is planned with reference to a second obj.; but the general o(rw=ntes is subsequently replaced by the more specific e)lpi/santes (“because they had come to hope”), in consequence of which the order of words seems perverted, since we should expect o(rw=nte/s te to/n kte(.

e)p) e)co/dw|...h)=san : this fact is mentioned in c. 14. 20 and 22. 9 as influencing the Lacedaemonians to
make peace. Here reference is made to it to explain the motives of the Argives (Steup, Rhein. Mus. 25, p. 285 note, suggests that it be omitted as a superfluous gloss).
h(/ te *lakedai/mwn, oi(/ te *)argei=oi: the two equally prominent reasons are symmetrically opposed. See on i. 8. 14.

ma/lista dh/: cf. i. 1. 8; 50. 10; 138. 10. —h)/kouse: like u(perw/fqh and, 12, a)/rista e)/sxon, aor. with the signification: Lacedaemon had fallen into ill repute and had become an object of contempt, whereas the Argives had attained a desirable position.

toi=s pa=sin: in every respect. Cf. ii. 11. 25; 36. 10; 64. 20; vii. 50. 20.— 13. tou= *)attikou= pole/mou: so the Peloponnesian war is called here and in c. 31. 11 from the point of view of Peloponnesus, as in viii. 18. 10 and 37. 15, o( pro\s *)aqhnai/ous po/lemos. See Ullrich, Hellen. Kriege, p. 3, note 6.—cunara/menoi: const. with gen. as a verb of sharing, also in iv. 10. 1. G. 170, 2; H. 737.

ma=llon: rather. “Far from taking part in the war they stood rather (i.e. on the contrary) on terms of peace with both parties.”—e)kkarpwsa/menoi: like karpou=sqai in ii. 38. 7; vii. 68. 16, (e)k- referring to the source): “they derived profit from it (the e)/nspondoi o)/ntes).” tou\s karpou\s kai\ ta\s proso/dous labo/ntes a)po\ th=s gh=s a)kerai/ous dia\ to\ mh\ polemei=n. Schol.
prosede/xonto: impf. they were ready to receive.
The Mantineans are the first to join the league, and a sentiment favourable to it spreads throughout Peloponnesus.

toi=s *mantineu=si: with kate/strapto, equiv. to u(po\ tw=n *mantine/wn, a freq. use of the dat. with the plpf. pass. Cf. i. 46. 1; 48. 1; 118. 18.—me/ros ti th=s *)arkadi/as: among others the Parrhasians. Cf. c. 33. 3.—kate/strapto u(ph/koon: like i. 8. 16, prosepoiou=nto u(phko/ous, the pred. adj. expressing result.

sfa=s...a)/rxein : depends upon ou) perio/yesqai. Cf. i. 35. 14, du/namin proslabei=n perio/yesqe. GMT. 112, 2, N. 6; H. 986; Kühn. 484, 24. —e)peidh\ kai\ sxolh\n h)=gon: “since, inasmuch as the war with Athens
was over, they now had leisure also (as well as inclination) to turn their attention to Mantinea.”

dhmokratoume/nhn te: the third member of a series of words or clauses is freq. connected by te with the preceding. See on i. 2. 6; 76. 12. This is the first positive mention of a democracy at Argos. It may possibly have been introduced when Argos made an alliance with Athens in 460 B.C. See i. 102; Paus. i. 29. 9; Grote V. p. 175 ff.—w(/sper kai\ au)toi/: sc. e)dhmokratou=nto as in c. 44. 9. Cf. i. 32. 3. Kühn. 58, 3.

e)s qrou=n kaqi/stato: in act. signification: “they began to talk”; not “they began to be talked about.”— 12. nomi/santes: aor., their opinion concerning a particular case; nomi/zontes (8), concerning permanent conditions.—ple/on ti ei)do/tas: rebus melius compertis (St.), and therefore their example would have more weight. Cf. vii. 49. 22.—au)tou/s: sc. tou\s *mantine/as.
di) o(rgh=s e)/xontes . Cf. ii. 37. 12; 64. 2; v. 46. 32. See on ii. 8. 19.—e)p' a)/llois: on other grounds. Cobet, Mnem. 14, p. 9 for e)n a)/llois.
e)ge/grapto : cf. c. 18, § 11, and c. 23, § 6. This refers to both documents.
to\ gra/mma: the single article of the treaty. A rare use of the word.—dieqoru/bei: set in commotion far and wide.

di/kaion ga ei)=nai: would in dir. disc. have been di/kaion ga h)=n without a)/n, like kalo
 h)=n, i. 38. 10; ei)ko\s h)=n, iii. 40. 26.— 20. pa=si toi=s cumma/xois: for all the allies.—th
 meta/qesin: the power to prosqei=nai kai\ a)felei=n or to metaqei=nai o(/ph| a)
 dokh=| a)mfote/rois, c. 18. 58.
pro\s tou\s *)argei/ous: as in c. 27. 12; 28. 3.—kai\ au)toi\ e(/kastoi: pred. to oi( polloi/: “for their part also.”
The Lacedaemonians protest in Corinth against the intended alliance with Argos, but meet with a rebuff, for the Corinthians declare that they cannot betray the Chalcidian cities.
kaqestw=ta, genome/nous, me/llontas: are all pred. (supplementary) partics. dependent upon ai)sqo/menoi. Cf. c. 10. 38. GMT. 113; H. 982.
didaska/lous genome/nous: see on iii. 2. 11; v. 27. 18.
prokatalabei=n to\ me/llon: fqa/sai pri\n me/llein tou\s *korinqi/ous prosxwrei=n toi=s *)argei/ois, Schol. With obj. of the thing affected, as in i. 57. 15; with pers. obj. in i. 33. 20; 36. 18.

th/n te e)sh/ghsin tou= panto/s: the instigation of the whole movement, corresponding to e)shgei=sqai in iii. 20. 7; iv. 76. 8; vi. 99. 7, and e)shghth/s in viii. 48. 40. te is the correlative of the following kai/, which belongs with e)/fasan. te belongs with h)|tiw=nto, but stands after th/n. te is occasionally carelessly put between the art. and its noun even when it belongs with the word preceding the art.—kai\ ei)...e)/sontai : Cl. takes this with h)|tiw=nto, or rather with an h)gana/ktoun, deino\n e)poiou=nto, or deino\n au)toi=s e)fai/neto supplied from h)|tiw=nto, and cites iv. 85. § 6; vii. 73. § 1; viii. 53. § 2. These passages do not offer any very close analogy. It is better, with Jowett, to take kai\ ei) . . . e)/sontai as prot. with parabh/sesqai, and to put the comma before kai\ ei), instead of after e)/sontai.— 9. ei)rhme/non: acc. abs. See on i. 140. 13, and cf. c. 39. 12; vii. 18. 14. The provision to which the Lacedaemonians here refer must have been contained in the original treaty of alliance between the Peloponnesian states and Sparta, which is called by the Corinthians (20) oi( tw=n cumma/xwn o(/rkoi, and by Thuc. (24) oi( palaioi\ o(/rkoi. —to\ plh=qos: the majority, as in i. 125. 4.
sfi/si: i.e. in Corinth.

o(/soi...ta\s sponda/s : those mentioned in c. 17. § 2. ou)d' au)toi/ corresponds to kai\ au)to/s (cf. i. 50. 18; 62. 21), “also not.”—pareka/lesan de/: epexegetical de/. See on c. 10. 21. Aor. in the sense of plpf.

au)toi/:
on their own responsibility, paying no attention to the Lacedaemonians, whose opposition they naturally expected.

a(\ me\n h)dikou=nto: in what respects (acc. to their opinion) they had been wronged.—a)/ntikrus: straightforwardly, openly, also in viii. 92. 65.—*so/llion: *korinqi/wn po/lisma in Acarnania, was taken by the Athenians in the first year of the war (cf. ii. 30. 2), Anactorium in the seventh (cf. iv. 49).

ou)/te...sfi/sin a)pe/labon par) *)aqhnai/wn : that they (the Lacedaemonians) had not recovered these places from the Athenians for them (the Corinthians), i.e. that in making the peace they had not forced the Athenians to restore them.

ei)/ te/ ti a)/llo: parallel to o(/ti . . . *)anakto/rion, is in appos. to the obj. of dhlou=ntes. te is not a correlative of ou)/te in 15.—e)lassou=sqai: “they were getting less than their rights”; also in i. 77. 1.

tou\s e)pi\ *qra/|khs mh\ prodw/sein: collectively the obj. of pro/sxhma (see on i. 96. 4). That they (the Corinthians) would not give up the Greeks on the Thracian coast (to the rule of Athens) was the chief reason they gave for their opposition to Sparta.
i)di/a|: the Corinthians alone, so that with a)/llous u(/steron (sc. o(/rkous) some word like koinh=| (Kr.) is to be understood, although not expressed.—o(/te...a)fi/stanto : cf. i. 58. § 1.
ou)k ou)=n: written (with Cl.) as two words.

ou)k e)sio/ntes: by not joining, as the Lacedaemonians had asserted in 8, a)dikei=n o(/ti ou) de/xontai ta\s *)aqhnai/wn sponda/s (here tw=n *)aqhnai/wn; the usual variation in the use of the art. with names of peoples).
qew=n...o)mo/santes : qew=n o(/rkous e)pi\ pi/stei, Schol. “Since they had bound themselves by oaths sworn by the gods.”

ou)k a)\n eu)orkei=n: in dir. disc. ou)k a)\n eu)orkoi=men (“preserve the eu)/orkon”; cf. c. 18. 58), ei) prodidoi=men.—ei)rh=sqai: “that the words of the agreement were”; after which o(/ti has no effect upon the const., but serves as a mark of punctuation. GMT. 79; H. 928 b.
fai/nesqai ou)=n sfi/si kte(.: “so it seemed to them that this, the solemn oath, was a hindrance interposed by the gods themselves.”

peri\ de\ th=s *)argei/as cummaxi/as: (so with the best Mss. for *)argei/wn; the less usual expression like ai( *)attikai\ spondai/ in c. 29. 14 and 36. 13) const. with ei)=pon. “In regard to the Argive alliance, they declared that they would,” etc.
e)/tuxon paro/ntes: they were already present in Corinth during these negotiations with the Lacedaemonian envoys.
i)e/nai e)s: equiv. to e)sie/nai, 20.
au)toi=s proei=pon : equiv. to e)ke/leuon au)tou/s. Cf. i. 26. 20.

The Eleans make an alliance with Corinth and Argos, because they have a quarrel with the Lacedaemonians about Lepreum. Thereupon the Corinthians join the Argive alliance, as do also the Thracian Chalcidians. The Boeotians and Megarians keep quiet.
e)poih/santo: see App.
kaqa/per proei/rhto: in the proclamation which the Argives made (c. 28. § 1), acting on the advice of the Corinthians (c. 27. § 2).
*lepre/ou: Lepreum in Triphylia, not far from the boundaries of Elis and Laconia (c. 34. 7). Remains of its fortifications still exist. Curtius, Pelop. II. p. 84.
e)pi\ th=| h(misei/a| th=s gh=s: “on the condition that they should cede half of their land” to the Eleans. Kühn. 405, 5 c.

kai\ lusa/ntwn: see App. The same subj. in the main clause and in the gen. abs. occurs freq. in Thuc. See on ii. 83. 15 and iii. 13. 30.—th\n gh=n nemome/nois au)toi=s: the Eleans allowed the Lepreans to remain in possession of the half of their land which they had relinquished, but obliged them to pay a rent of a talent to Olympian Zeus, whose temple was under the control of the Eleans.— 10. e)/tacan: ta/cai is used of the im
position of tribute in i. 19. 6; iii. 50. 6.
tou= *)attikou= pole/mou: see on c. 28. 13.
pausame/nwn: sc. tou= fo/rou.

e)phna/gkazon : “they prepared to force them,” impf. e)panagka/zein also in Plat. Prot. p. 345 e.— 14. e)pitrapei/shs: “having been referred to the Lacedaemonians for arbitration.” Cf. i. 28. 9; iv. 83. 10; vii. 18. 24.

mh\ i)/son e(/cein: that they would not receive fair treatment at the hands of the Lacedaemonians.—a)ne/ntes: shows that they had originally agreed to accept the arbitration: pausa/menoi tou= e)pitre/yai th\n di/khn toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois, Schol. Equiv. to ou)k e)mmeina/ntwn th=| e)pitroph=|, 18.
ou)de\n h)=sson e)di/kasan: they gave their decision notwithstanding the refusal of the Eleans to acknowledge their jurisdiction.
a)dikei=n: were in the wrong.—w(s ou)k e)mmeina/ntwn: “because they had, as they said, refused to submit to the judgment of those whom they had previously accepted as arbitrators.”
de/casqai: had taken under protection. Cf. i. 34. 2; 40. 17, 22.

th\n cunqh/khn: this agreement between the states hostile to Athens must have been made shortly before the outbreak of the Peloponnesian war. See Grote VI. p. 290. It is not mentioned elsewhere. See App.—profe/rontes: cf. c. 17. 11.

a(\ e)/xontes, tau=ta e)/xontas: a quotation from the treaty, the formality of the expression being part of the official style “what any (tines) had when they entered upon the war, that shall they have when they leave it.”
w(s ou)k i)/son e)/xontes: “on the ground that they had not received what was their due.”
w(/sper proei/rhto; cf. kaqa/per proei/rhto, 3.
oi( e)pi\ *qra/|khs *xalkidh=s: their independence was most endangered by the peace (see c. 18. § 5 and § 8).

*boiwtoi\ de\ kai\ *megarh=s: their envoys were present in Corinth at the discussions, acc. to c. 30. 11 f. and 17. 18 f.—to\ au)to\ le/gontes: th\n au)th\n gnw/mhn e)/xontes, Schol., and so also in iv. 20. 17, i.e. “though they were of the same mind” as the Corinthians and Chalcidians. Böhme and Jowett explain “saying the same thing,” i.e. “agreeing”: “the Boeotians and Megarians agreed to refuse” (Jowett).

h(su/xazon: equiv. to ou)k e)newte/rizon, as in ii. 3. 5; v. 22. 12, they remained quiet.—periorw/menoi: mid. as in vi. 93. 3, me/llontes d' e)/ti kai\ periorw/menoi. See on iv. 71. 7, a)mfote/rois e)do/kei h(suxa/sasi to\ me/llon periidei=n (the aor. mid. is not in use), where the two expressions are joined as here. The sense of the passage is: “they were of the same mind as the Corinthians, but remained quiet awaiting the event and thinking,” etc. See App.
au)toi=s: them themselves. Boeotians as well as Megarians, who in the summer of 424 B.C., e)s o)ligarxi/an ta\ ma/lista kate/sthsan th\n politei/an. Cf. iv. 74. 16.
politei/as: political constitution, as in i. 18. 9; ii. 37. 1.

The Athenians take Scione and treat the inhabitants with great severity. They restore the Delians to their island. The Corinthians and Argives try without success to induce the Tegeans to leave the alliance with Sparta. The Boeotians and Corinthians enter into ineffectual negotiations with Athens.

*skiwnai/ous: their fate had been decided at Athens two years before at the instigation of Cleon (see iv. 122. § 6), and they had been left at the mercy of the Athenians by the Lacedaemonians in making the peace. See c. 18. § 8.

a)pe/kteinan: tw=| fo/bw| boulo/menoi kataplh/casqai tou\s e)n u(poyi/a| a)posta/sews o)/ntas para/deigma pa=sin a)ne/deican th\n e)k tw=n *skiwnai/wn timwri/an, acc. to Diod. xii. 76. But this severe measure did not have the desired effect.
pai=das...h)ndrapo/disan : see App.

*plataieu=sin: those who had been received in Athens before the siege of Plataea (cf. ii. 78. 10), and those who had made their escape thither by a successful sally (cf. iii. 24. § 3).—kath/gagon pa/lin: cf. c. 1.

e)nqumou/menoi: here equiv. to e)nqu/mion poiou/menoi. Cf.
vii. 50. 29; c. 16. 18. “Since they took their mishaps (at Delium and Amphipolis) to heart,” seeing in them a proof of the divine wrath.—ta/s te: much as in c. 28. 7 after o(rw=ntes, we should here after ta/s te . . . cumfora/s expect a second obj. of e)nqumou/menoi, instead of which we find the gen. abs. kai\ tou= . . . xrh/santos. Kühn. 417, 5, N. 9. Still a change of the reading in either passage is unadvisable (Cobet, Mnem. 14, p. 9, proposes te ta/s).
xrh/santos: the restoration of the Delians was, then, commanded by the god.
kai\ *fwkh=s kte(.: this isolated statement is all the notice that is taken of this war. See Introd. p. 2.

*tege/an: Bekker and others accent *te/gean wrongly, as the Ion. form is *tege/h. Göttling, Doctr. Accent., p. 128. This town and its territory on the border of Laconia always maintained an independent position in Arcadia as well against Spartan plans of conquest as in this instance against the anti-Spartan alliance of the Corinthians and Argives. Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 152.
me/ga me/ros: (as in ii. 20. 10 of Acharnae) “a place of importance”; perhaps implying that its adherence would throw the balance of power upon one side or the other.
a(/pasan a)\n e)/xein *pelopo/nnhson: equiv. to c. 28. 9 f., th=s *peloponnh/sou h(gh/sesqai.
proqu/mws pra/ssontes: “who had hitherto been zealous” in carrying out the plan of c. 27. § 2.

a)nei=san: with gen. as in vii. 43. 45, a)ne/ntwn th=s e)fo/dou. G. 174; II. 748.— 14. mh\ ou)dei/s...prosxwrh=| : they relinquished their hopes as quickly as they had (c. 27. § 2) accepted and expressed them.

e)pisponda/s: this word, which does not occur elsewhere, is formed like e)pispe/ndesqai (renew a treaty, c. 22. 9), and is adapted to express the nature of these constantly renewed truces. See on c. 26. 14.
[tou/twn | tw=n penthkontouti/dwn: see App.
kai\ sfi/si poih=sai: procure for them also from the Athenians.
w(/sper *boiwtoi\ ei)=xon: see App.— 22. mh\ spe/ndesqai: sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois.
e)pisxei=n: wait a while, have patience. Cf. viii. 5. 11.
ou)x hu(/ronto: did not succeed in obtaining. Cf. i. 31. 10, w)feli/an tina\ peira=sqai a)p' au)tw=n eu(ri/skesqai, and i. 58. 6. Lat. non impetraverunt.

a)ciou/ntwn: sc. a)peipei=n. cunqe/sqai sfi/si depends upon ai)tiwme/nwn (not, as Kr. thinks, upon a)ciou/ntwn): “although the Corinthians demanded that they give up their agreement with Athens, and accused them (the Boeotians) of having agreed with them (the Corinthians) to do so if the Athenians did not accede to their request.” The Corinthians had asked the Boeotians to do this (22), and believed, apparently, that they had agreed.
a)nokwxh\ a)/spondos: opp. to the dexh/meroi spondai/; an actual cessation of hostilities, but without any guarantee.
The first hostile acts of the Lacedaemonians against the Mantineans in consequence of their alliance with the Argives.

th=s *)arkadi/as: stands first as in iii. 19. 6, th=s *kari/as, and freq.—*parrasi/ous: an old Pelasgic tribe the capital of which, Parrhasia, is mentioned in Il. B 608. They dwelt at the base of Mt. Lycaeum toward the southeast. See Curtius, Pelop. I. p. 279; Bursian, II. p. 225 and 235.
e)pikalesame/nwn: tw=n *parrasi/wn, Schol. On the gen., see GMT. 110, 1, N. 5; H. 972 d.

sfa=s: tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous, Schol.—to\ e)n *kuye/lois
tei=xos: its exact position is now unknown. Curtius, Pelop. I. p. 340; Bursian, II. p. 243.—a)nairh/sontes: cf. c. 77. 5, kai\ to\ tei=xos a)nairou=ntas; viii. 24. 7. Therefore not to be changed (with Meineke) to kaqairh/sontes.

th=| *skiri/tidi : the mountainous region between the upper Eurotas and the valley of the Oenus, one of the most important districts inhabited by Laconian perioeci. See Curtius, Pelop. II. p. 263. e)pi\ th=| *skiri/tidi, i.e. threatening the border. Cf. c. 51. 4; iii. 16. 4, to\ e)pi\ *le/sbw| nautiko/n; iv. 14. 29, e)/menon e)pi\ th=| *pu/lw|.
th\n po/lin: i.e. their own city, Mantinea.
th\n cummaxi/an: the region under their supremacy and protection. Cf. iv. 118. 17 and 27; viii. 44. 5; h(\n u(ph/koon katestre/yanto, c. 29. 4.
ta\s e)n *parrasi/ois po/leis: the names of none of these can be given with certainty. Curtius, Pelop. I. p. 340; Bursian, II. p. 241.

Measures adopted by the Lacedaemonians to confer honours upon the troops which had taken part in Brasidas's expedition to Thrace, and to render those citizens who had returned from captivity incapable of causing trouble to the state.

tw=n a)po\ *qra/|khs: the use of a)po/ is occasioned by h(ko/ntwn. It is here ambiguous on account of e)celqo/ntwn. tw=n a)po\ *qra/|khs meta\ *brasi/dou e)celqo/ntwn seems to imply that Brasidas returned from Thrace, so that Kr.'s suggestion to read tw=n meta\ *brasi/dou is not without reason.— 2. e)celqo/ntwn: cf. iv. 78. § 1, and 80. § 5.

e)ko/misen: brought home, in accordance with the command received in c. 21. 15 ff. komi/zein is used in the same sense in iv. 16. 19, a)postei=lai de\ au)tou\s trih/rei *)aqhnai/ous kai\ pa/lin komi/sai, but with pa/lin.
maxesame/nous : placed after its subst. acc. to the usage discussed on i. 11. 18.

oi)kei=n o(/pou a)\n bou/lwntai: i.e. no longer as serfs glebae ad
scripti. This is one of the first requisites of e)leuqeri/a.

tw=n neodamw/dwn : a class of new citizens composed of liberated Helots, though they seem to be distinct from the Helots who have just received their freedom. They are mentioned here for the first time, then freq. in Thuc. (vii. 19. 16; 58. 12; viii. 5. 7) and Xen., but not afterwards. See Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, I. p. 198 ff.; Gilbert, Griech. Staatsalt. I. p. 35 f. The accent acc. to Hdn. i. p. 428, 13. See v. Bamberg, Ztschr. f. d. Gymn.Wesen, 28, p. 7.
e)s *le/preon: see c. 31. § 1 and § 2.
o)/ntes h)/dh dia/foroi: with reference to c. 31. 5, diafero/menoi ga\r e)tu/gxanon.
lhfqe/ntas, kai\ ta\ o(/pla parado/ntas : the ultimate result stands first. Cf. iv. 38. § 3 f.

dia\ th\n cunfora\n nomi/santes: the Spartans were afraid that these men who had returned from captivity would fear lest their misfortune might be regarded as their fault and cause them to be less respected (e)lasswqh/sesqai here in the form of the fut. pass. as in Dem. XXIV. 66, while in c. 104. 4 and 105. 12, the mid. form e)lassw/sesqai is used), and that they would therefore endeavour to change the constitution of the state (newteri/swsi) if they remained in the exercise of all their rights as citizens (kai\ o)/ntes e)pi/timoi). To prevent this, a)ti/mous e)poi/hsan, they took from them for a time the most important rights of citizenship, making them incapable of holding office and of conducting business transactions.

h)/dh kai\ a)rxa/s tinas e)/xontas: this adds to the whole obj. tou\s . . . parado/ntas a special part as appos. in the same case. See on c. 3. 23; ii. 95. 4; iii. 13. 17. It is not remarkable that they already held offices, h)=san ga\r oi( *spartia=tai au)tw=n prw=toi kte(. Cf. c. 15. 4. On a)timi/a and its degrees, esp. in Athens, but also in other Greek states, see Hermann, Griech. Staatsalt. § 124, 6; Schömann Antiq. of Greece, I. p. 360 f.
The summer passed while the Athenians and the Lacedaemonians were vainly endeavouring to obtain from one another the fulfilment of the conditions of the treaty.
*qusso/n: for the accent, see on iv. 109. 9.—e)n th=| *)/aqw *)akth=| *dih=s: see App.

*)aqhnaiw/n ou)=san cu/mma-
xon: since the Dians also, acc. to c. 82. 1, belonged to the Athenian alliance, their attack upon an allied town is incomprehensible. Steup. Stud. I. p. 34, therefore regards these words as an interpolation. But in several places in this book where events are briefly mentioned, the connexion is not made clear. See Introd. p. 2.
e)pimici/ai: used of friendly intercourse, like the related verbal forms e)pimignu/nai and e)pimi/gnusqai. See on i. 2. 5.
th\n ou)k a)po/dosin: see on i. 137. 29. a)llh/lois depends upon the verbal force of a)po/dosin. See on i. 63. 9; 73. 1; iii. 66. 17. G. 185; II. 765 a.
pro/teroi laxo/ntes: cf. c. 21. 1.

a)podedw/kesan: so the Mss. St. writes the plpf. everywhere with syllabic aug. See Stahl, Quaest. Graec. p. 17.— ou)de\ parei=xon dexome/nous: the partic. const. with pare/xein after the analogy of adjs. Cf. ii. 84. 20, a)peiqeste/ras(ta\s nau=s); iii. 12. 6, e)xuro/n; iv. 67. 31, bebai/ous(ta\s pu/las).
le/gontes a)ei/: although they constantly assured them.
prou/qento: the composition is the same as that of proqesmi/a, fore-appointed time.

cuggrafh=s: written agreement; sumfwni/a gegramme/nh, Schol.—tou\s mh\ e)sio/ntas: with this e)s ta\s sponda/s (cf. c. 30. 20) is to be supplied from the preceding ta\s sponda\s dexome/nous (but not, with Meineke, to be received into the text).
ou)de\n e)/rgw| gigno/menon: in spite of the a)ei\ le/gein.
u(pw/pteuon : here and in viii. 76. 6 for Mss. u(peto/p|euon. See on i. 20. 9.
a)paitou/ntwn: this (pres.) and a)pedi/dosan (impf.) imply repeated negotiations.

meteme/lonto a)podedwko/tes: see
on c. 14. 10.
poih/seian: for the form, see on iii. 49. 10. Stahl, Quaest. Graec. p. 18. On the mood, see GMT. 77, 1 d; H. 937 a.

tou\s e)pi\ *qra/|khs stratiw/tas: as in c. 67. 4.—kai\ ei)/ tou a)/llou (neut. not masc.) e)rkratei=s h)=san: in a perfectly general sense: and whatever else they had been able; and accordingly a general expression like poih=sai, not a)podou=nai or a)pagagei=n is to be supplied. Cf. 19, ta\ me\n dunata\ e)/fasan pepoihke/nai.
w(/ste : see on c. 14. 1.
a)polabei=n: cf. c. 30. 15.
komiei=n: depends upon e)/fasan, not upon peira/sesqai: they said they would attend to the restoration of the captives.

*messhni/ous te kai\ tou\s *ei(/lwtas: several editt. following Reiske have adopted ge for te. But since, acc. to iv. 41. § 2, the Messenians had been expressly transferred to Pylos from Naupactus, whereas the Helots had simply run away thither, the separation by means of te, kai/ seems very appropriate.
e)/peisan e(/ste: cf. c. 16. 23.— 31. kai\ tou\s a)/llous [*ei(/lwta/s te kai\] o(/soi : see App.

katw/|kisan: elsewhere const. with e)s. See on i. 103. 9.—e)n *krani/ois: from nom. *kra/nioi acc. to Steph. Byz. s.v. *kra/nioi po/lis e)n *kefallhni/a|, to\ e)qniko\n *kraniei=s. (Bursian, Geogr. v. Griech. II. p. 373, calls the town Krane; Jowett, Cranii.) The Athenians had been in possession of Cephallenia since the first year of the war. See ii. 30. § 2 (where *kra/nioi seems to be used as e)qniko/n).
e)/fodoi: equiv. to e)pimici/ai, 3. Cf. i. 6. 2, dia\ ta\s ou)k a)sfalei=s par' a)llh/lous e)fo/dous.
Endeavours of the Lacedaemonian war party to induce the Boeotians to join the Argive alliance, in order that through their instrumentality an alliance between Argos and Sparta may be brought about.
e)/foroi e(/teroi: the annual change of the five ephors took place at the autumnal equinox, the beginning of the Lacedaemonian year. See Hermann, Griech. Staatsalt. § 45, 3.
a)/rxontes h)/dh: const. with e)/tuxon.
spondai=s : see App.

th=s cummaxi/dos: i.e. the allied states, as in i. 110. 10, e)k de\ tw=n *)aqhnw=n kai\ th=s a)/llhs cummaxi/dos. Of the whole body of allies the three most important are esp. mentioned; the Athenians as new allies, the Boeotians and Corinthians as members of the old alliance, though not participators in the peace with Athens.— 6. w(s a)ph=|san: as they were on the point of departing.
*cena/rhs: see App.
i)di/ous: is not as common as i)di/a|, but is not (with v. Herwerden) to be emended. Cf. c. 39. 10; viii. 9. 5.

tau)ta/: adopted by Poppo and subsequent editt. for tau=ta of the Mss.—tau)ta\ gignw/skein: agree, adopt the same policy.—These negotiations with the Boeotians and Corinthians, have for their first object to induce the Boeotians to accept the proposal made them in c. 32. § 5, 6 (i.e. to join the Argive alliance as the Corinthians had done), in regard to which they had asked for time to consider (e)pisxei=n). Taking it for granted that the Boeotians will now agree to the proposal of the Corinthians, the two ephors address the second part of their proposition (te kai/ shows this division into two heads) to the Boeotians alone, peira=sqai *boiwtou/s kte(. The great importance of the part the Boeotians have to play occasions the unusual repetition of the subst. meta\ *boiwtw=n, instead of the pron. meq' e(autw=n. We must connect *boiwtw=n closely in thought with cumma/xous. If the Boeotians were once allies of the Argives, then it would be possible to bring about an alliance between Sparta and Argos. The repetition of cumma/xous increases the emphasis laid upon this
idea. See App.
au)=qis: after prw=ton as in c. 76. 9.

ou(/tw ga\r h(/kist) a)\n a)nagkasqh=nai kte(.: the argument likely to persuade the Boeotians is stated first, viz. that the possibility (referred to in c. 35. 11) that the Lacedaemonians and Athenians together would force the Boeotians to accept the peace, would disappear. Then in 14, in the words e(le/sqai ga\r(a)\n)*lakedaimoni/ous kte(. the interest which the Lacedaemonians would have in an alliance with Argos is set forth. See App.

e(le/sqai: choose, be glad. Here pro/ is not equiv. to a)nti/ (cf. iv. 20. 6) but temporal (as may be the case in iii. 59. 21, e(loi/meqa a)\n pro/ ge tou/tou limw=| teleuth=sai, “before we do that we would starve to death”): “the Lacedaemonians would prefer that the Argives (*)argei/ous first for emphasis) should join them in friendship and alliance before they declared their hostility to the Athenians and put an end to the peace,” which they would probably do before long, since their friendly relations had been disturbed eu)qu\s meta\ ta\s sponda/s, c. 35. 2. This is then further explained in 16, to\ ga\r *)/argos . . . r(a/w| a)\n ei)=nai, “the Boeotians knew that the Lacedaemonians wished all along to be on good terms with Argos, because then their rear would not be exposed in case of a war outside of Peloponnesus,” i.e. with Athens. See App.

kalw=s: rightly explained by St.: opportune; “under favourable circumstances,” “if they had a good opportunity.” Cf. i. 124. 1; v. 65. 24.—h(goume/nous: the statement is evidently to be made of the Lacedaemonians. See App.
e)de/onto kte(.: see App.
r(a=|on: in the same sense as in 19, with greater safety.
Similar proposals are made by influential Argives. Negotiations are begun between the Boeotians and the Argives.

tau=ta e)pestalme/noi: e)piste/llein in pass., const. like e)pitre/pein in i. 126. 33. G. 197, N. 2; H. 819 b. With this, a)po/, not u(po/, acc. to the usage established by Herbst, gegen Cobet, p. 50 f. Cf. i. 141. 6; iii. 36. 24; 82. 41.

w(/ste: with e)piste/llein, as in c. 16. 23 with pei/qein.—e)pi\ ta\ koina/: pl. of koino/n. Cf. i. 89. 14; 90. 29; ii. 12. 6. The most important legislative body is meant. Here pl. because both Thebes and Corinth are referred to.
th=s a)rxh=s th=s megi/sths: prob. the a)rtu=nai mentioned in c. 47. 53, though it may be that the strategi are intended. See Gilbert, Griech. Staatsalt. II. p. 79, note 2.
a)pio/ntas: sc. e)p' oi)/kou. Cf. c. 36. 6.—kaq' o(do/n: i.e. on the way home through Argive territory.

ge/nointo: the opt. depends upon the notion of indir. disc. implied in e)s lo/gous h)=lqon. GMT. 77, 1 c; 53, N. 2; II. 937.—w(/sper *kori/nqioi: cf. c. 31. 26.—*)hlei=oi: cf. c. 31. 20.—*mantinh=s: cf. c. 29. 1.

kai\ polemei=n kai\ spe/ndesqai, kai\ pro\s *lakedaimoni/ous kai\ ei)/ tina pro\s a)/llon de/oi: two pairs of alternatives. The first concerns the fact (peace or war), the second the persons (Lacedaemonians or anybody else). ei)/ tis is equiv. to o(stisou=n (cf. i. 14. 11; iv. 26. 16), and cannot be separated, which accounts for the peculiar position of the prep. pro/s.

koinw=| lo/gw| xrwme/nous : is the consequence arising from tou/tou proxwrh/santos: “if the Argives, Boeotians, Corinthians, Eleans, and Mantineans pursued a joint policy.” The subj. of nomi/zein is still the two Argives, but when we come to the dependent infs. polemei=n kai\ spe/ndesqai (with a)/n) introduced by tou/tou proxwrh/santos the subj. embraces the whole body of allies.—ei) de/oi: if circumstances demanded it.

e)de/onto: sc. the two Argives.— w(=nper: const. with e)pesta/lkesan. Gen. by assimilation for a(/per. See on i. 1. 12; iv. 20. 4. G. 153; II. 994. For tou/twn, Schütz and Naber, Mnem. 14, p. 319, prefer tw=n au)tw=n.—oi(...fi/loi: oi( peri\ to\n *kleo/boulon dhlono/ti, Schol.
dexome/nous to\n lo/gon: almost like an adj., inclined to accept the proposal. Cf. c. 35. 9.

a)fiko/menoi: sc. at Thebes.— toi=s *boiwta/rxais: see on iv. 91. 4.
The Boeotarchs were the chief magistrates of the Boeotian confederacy. At this time they seem to have been eleven in number. Later they were only seven. See Boeckh, Corp. Insc. Gr. I. 729. Hermann, Griech. Staatsalt. § 179, 10. Gilbert, Griech. Staatsalt. II. p. 54 f.
h)re/skonto: see on c. 4. 11.
cunebebh/kei: see on c. 10. 33.
tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn: part. gen. as in 3.—tw=n au)tw=n: depends upon dei=sqai, wanted the same things, i.e. had the same needs and desires as themselves. G. 172, 1; H. 743.

e)s ta\ o(moi=a: Thuc. elsewhere uses speu/dein without a prep. (cf. c. 16. 7; vi. 10. 15), but Xen. Cyr. i. 4. 4 has e)s to\ au)to\ h(mi=n speu/dete. Cf. Aesch. Prom. 192; Eur. Ion. 599 (Kr. proposes to omit e)s).

parh=san: sc. e)n *qh/bais.—ta\ ei)rhme/na: here refers only to the proposals of 6 ff., not “that which had been agreed upon,” as in c. 35. 18.— 24. prokalou/menoi: with acc. as in ii. 74. 15, prokalesa/menoi ga\r polla\ kai\ ei)ko/ta ou) tugxa/nomen. Cf. c. 111. 19.
But owing to the resistance of an opposing party in Boeotia, nothing is accomplished.
e)do/kei: not e)/doce. As presently appears, it was only a proposition, not a decision.
*korinqi/ois kte(.: that the envoys of these states had come to Thebes has not been stated, but is evident from the context. See 20 f.— toi=s a)po\ *qra/|khs: cf. c. 31. 26.
e)n tw=| paratuxo/nti: “under the circumstances that might at any time arise.” para- has the force of a)ei/, and hence the sing. See on i. 122. 6; iii. 82. 47.
tw=| deome/nw|: general, like to\n boulo/menon, i. 26. 3, and freq.
ou(/tws h)/dh: thereupon, “then and not till then.” ou(/tws denotes the fulfilment of certain conditions. Cf. i. 37. 4; iii. 96. 8; iv. 88. 8; v. 55. 8.

to\ ga\r au)to\ e)poi/oun: like c. 31. 27, to\ au)to\
le/gontes, and c. 36. 10, tau)ta\ gignw/skein, denotes, esp. in the impf., general agreement in act and word.

tai=s te/ssarsi boulai=s: they are not mentioned elsewhere, and the organization of the Boeotian confederacy is altogether but imperfectly known. See Hermann, Griech. Staatsalt. § 179, 11. Gilbert, Griech. Staatsalt. II. p. 57.
e)p' w)feli/a|: cf. i. 3. 9, e)pagome/nwn au)tou\s e)p' w)feli/a| e)s ta\s a)/llas po/leis.
toi=s e)kei/nwn a)festw=si: cf. c. 27. § 2; 30. § 2 ff.
ou) ga\r ei)=pon: they had not informed them.
tw=n te e)fo/rwn: part. gen. opp. to kai\ oi( fi/loi. Cf. c. 37. 2.
parainou=sin: sc. toi=s *boiwtoi=s, as in c. 36. 9 f.

met' au)tw=n: rightly restored by St. for meta\ tw=n (on this error of the Mss. see App. on c. 16. 6); for upon this the whole plan of the ephors and their party depended. They wished first to induce the Boeotians to form an alliance with Argos (and Corinth, which was already in the Argive confederacy), and then to bring about an alliance between these and Sparta, so that Athens should be entirely isolated. Where the reconciliation of Argos and Sparta is the main point, we read in c. 36. 11 f., meta\ *boiwtw=n *)argei/ous *lakedaimoni/ois poih=sai cumma/xous; here where the restoration of the somewhat loosened alliance between Thebes and Sparta is most prominent, the same idea is expressed somewhat differently: (tou\s/ *boiwtou/s, for this is the obj. of parainou=sin and subj. of gi/gnesqai)met' au)tw=n (sc. tw=n *)argei/wn kai\ *korinqi/wn)*lakedaimoni/wn (sc. cumma/xous)gi/gnesqai. The way to the goal is in both cases the same: *)argei/wn prw=ton(kai\ *korinqi/wn, which is omitted as superfluous in c. 36) genome/nous cumma/xous. Only the difference between poih=sai and gi/gnesqai occasions that between meta\ *boiwtw=n and met' au)tw=n, i.e. meta\ tw=n *)argei/wn kai\ *korinqi/wn.

sfi/si : refers to the subj. of yhfiei=sqai: “they would adopt no other measures than those which they (the Boeotarchs) recommend to them after previous deliberation.” The indir. refl. pron. often refers in Thuc. to the subj. of a de
pendent verb. Cf. i. 20. 10; 30. 14; 58. 7; iii. 3. 19; iv. 113. 11. Kühn. 555, N. 9. The change to sfei=s or e)n sfi/si, which has been proposed, is therefore unnecessary.
a)nte/sth: see on c. 4. 22.

ei) tau=ta e)/peisan: the aor. indic. is chosen under the influence of the failure of their attempt (“if they had succeeded, which they did not”); me/llontes peira/sesqai would otherwise lead us to expect here a fut. prot., e)a\n pei/swsi or ei) pei/seian. GMT. 49, 2, N. 3. e.
kai\ th\n cummaxi/an: the alliance with the Argives, which has been previously mentioned, is the important one; hence the art.
e)sh/negkan: e)sfe/rein, propose for deliberation, occurs also in viii. 67. 5 and 9.
ou(\s u(pe/sxonto: cf. c. 37. 25.
The Lacedaemonians make a separate alliance with the Boeotians.
*mhku/bernan: mentioned by Strabo, vii. frg. 29, as e)pi/neion of Olynthus on the Toronaic Gulf. It now loses its independence, which Athens had tried to secure (c. 18. 29) in the treaty of peace.
e)gi/gnonto lo/goi toi=s te *)aqhnai/ois kte(.: i.e. oi( *)aqhnai=oi kte(. lo/gous e)poiou=nto. te intimates that sometimes one party and sometimes the other took the initiative.
peri\ w(=n a)llh/lwn ei)=xon: i.e. by conquest during the war. These places were to be restored acc. to the treaty. Cf. c. 35. 5, kata\ th\n tw=n xwri/wn a)llh/lois ou)k a)po/dosin.
a)pola/boien : a)polabei=n, get back, either directly or by the mediation of others. Cf. c. 30. 15; 35. 24; 36. 21; iv. 99. 9.—komi/sasqai: cf. c. 15. 4; 17. 3; iv. 41. 15.
presbeuo/menoi: cf. i. 31. 13, where the fut. partic. presbeuso/menoi is used in the same way.
ei)rhme/non kte(.: either this provision is regarded as contained in c. 23. § 1, or it was subsequently added to the treaty. See App. Cf. c. 46. 15.

paralabei=n: denotes the acquisition of Panactum preparatory to exchanging it with the Athenians.— 15. tw=n cugxe/ai speudo/ntwn ta\s sponda/s: i.e. the party of the two ephors. See c. 36. 7. The verb cugxei=n occurs only here in Thuc.; but spondw=n cu/gxusis in i. 146. 5 and c. 26. 29. Cf. confundere foedus, Verg. Aen. v. 496.
proqumoume/nwn: with acc. See on c. 17. 6.—ta\ e)s *boiwtou/s: a general expression: the connexion with the Boeotians. Cf. c. 46. 5, e)pisxo/ntas ta\ pro\s *)argei/ous.

h)/dh : const. with tou= xeimw=nos teleutw=ntos (not as in iv. 135. 2 with e)/ar), intimates that the winter had been frittered away in the repeated negotiations.—kai/: connects the following words closely with e)poih/santo th\n cummaxi/an, and makes the destruction of Panactum appear as a consequence of the alliance.

kaqh|rei=to: u(po\ tw=n *boiwtw=n, Schol. The impf. denotes the beginning of the work which is still uncompleted in c. 40. 3 (kaqairou/menon), and is not finished (kaqh|rhme/non) until c. 42. 6. The reasons for it are given in c. 42. 7 f. The words of Plut. Alc. 14, *lakedaimo/nioi . . . *pa/nakton ou)x e(stw=san, w(/sper e)/dei, toi=s *)aqhnai/ois pare/dwkan, a)lla\ katalu/santes show that the Lacedaemonians were regarded as morally responsible for this breach of the spirit of the provision (see c. 18. 31 f.) of the treaty.
Thereupon the Argives, fearful of being isolated, begin to negotiate with Sparta.
h(=kon: see App.

xwrh/sh|:
xwrei=n e)/s tina seems to differ from the more usual xwrei=n pro/s tina (cf. i. 18. 28; v. 22. 10; 43. 6) as accedere ad aliquem differs from se convertere ad aliquem, and thus lays more stress upon the central position of Sparta.

tou/s te *)aqhnai/ous ei)de/nai tau=ta: the Argives were in error, believing that the Athenians had agreed to the destruction of Panactum preparatory to admitting the Boeotians into the alliance headed by Sparta and Athens.—w(/ste ou)de\...poih/sasqai : a consequence of this erroneous opinion. The inf. ei)=nai still depends upon w)/|onto. The neg. ou)de/ (not mhde/) is retained. Their thought was w(/ste ou)de\ . . . e)/sti.
ei)=nai : equiv. to parei=nai, as in ii. 97. 4, ou) ga\r h)=n pra=cai ou)de\n mh\ dido/nta dw=ra.

e)k tw=n diaforw=n : in view of the differences existing between the Lacedaemonians and Athenians, which the Argives falsely believed were now removed.—ai( pro\s *lakedaimoni/ous spondai/: the expiration of this truce was at hand (see c. 14. 21; 22. 8 f.; 28. 8). Cleobulus and Xenares had tried to renew it (see c. 36. § 1). ei) mh\ mei/neian then means: “if the thirty years' truce should not be renewed.” See App.

a)porou=ntes ou)=n tau=ta: the adv. acc. of the neut. pron. (as with other similar verbs) occurs also in vii. 48. 36, ta\ me\n a)porei=n, and 55. 11, ta/ te pro\ au)tw=n h)po/roun. Cf. Xen. Hell. vi. 1. 4.
pro/teron ou) dexo/menoi: cf. c. 22. 8 f.
e)n fronh/mati o)/ntes: “proudly hoping”; a stronger expression for e)lpi/santes of c. 28. 9.
au)toi=s: i.e. toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois.

kra/tista : const. with h(gou/menoi as pred. adj. modifying h(suxi/an e)/xein. Cf. i. 85. 11, tai=ta ga\r kra/tista bou-
leu/sesqe.

cugxwrh=| : impers. liceat, it should be feasible; a usage found only in Xen. Eq. 9. 11, but assured by the analogy of e)gxwrei= in Plat. Phaedo, 116 e; Sophist. 246 c; Gorg. 520 d: “they thought it was, under the circumstances, best to make peace with the Lacedaemonians in whatever way (i.e. on whatever terms) was possible, and to keep quiet,” i.e. give up their pretensions to the hegemony.—h(suxi/an e)/xein: like h(suxa/zein in c. 22. 12; 31. 28.
The Argive envoys arrive at Sparta, and after making a foolish stipulation about Cynuria, prepare to conclude a treaty of peace with the Lacedaemonians for fifty years.
au)tw=n: sc. tw=n *)argei/wn.
ai( spondai/ : the treaty of peace which was now ardently desired. sfi/sin also here and in 4 (where Kr. and v. Herwerden would omit it) points to the lively interest of the Argives in the matter.
e)s po/lin: with the subst. e)pitroph/, whereas with the verb e)pitre/pein the dat. is used. Cf. i. 28. 9; iv. 83. 10; v. 31. 14.
h(=s a)ei\ pe/ri: a)ei/ is freq. inserted between closely connected words. See on i. 18. 29.

ne/montai d' au)th\n *lakedaimo/nioi: the Lacedaemonians had established there the Aeginetans who had been expelled from their home. See iv. 56. 13 f. On the situation of the towns, see Curtius, Pelopon. II. p. 376; Bursian, Geogr. v. Griech. II. p. 71.

memnh=sqai: mentionem facere: elsewhere used by Thuc. only in the aor. mnhsqh=nai (i. 10. 26; 37. 4; ii. 45. 7; iii. 90. 6; vi. 15. 6; viii. 47. 10); nor is the pf. found in other Att. writers, nor in Hdt. (hence v. Herwerden writes mnhsqh=nai).

w(/sper pro/teron: i.e. on the same conditions as in the thirty years' peace concluded in 451 B.C. See on c. 14. 21.—e(toi=moi ei)=nai: anacoluthon after e)w/ntwn, but no change in the text should be made, for ou)k e)w/ntwn suggests the idea of indir. disc., as if we had lego/ntwn after a)lla/, 9. Cf. viii. 48. § 6; 104. 13 ff., e)peigome/nwn de\ tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn pro/tero/n te cummi=cai, kai\ . . . u(persxo/ntes au)toi/. Kühn. 593, N. 1.
ta/de: const. with cugxwrh=sai.

diama/xesqai :
decertare, “fight it out.” Cf. i. 143. 25.

w(/sper kai\ pro/teron: this battle is described in detail in Hdt. i. 82. The conditions of the struggle were to be agreed upon now as in the old days (about 550 B.C.). Fair warning was to be given (prokalesame/nois), the enemy was not to be taken at a disadvantage (mh/te no/sou mh/te pole/mou kte(.), nor was the defeated party to be pursued beyond the boundary of Cynuria (16, diw/kein de\ mh\ e)cei=nai kte(.).
au)toi\ e(ka/teroi h)ci/wsan (claimed) nika=n: so in Hdt.i. 82. 27, au)toi\ e(ka/teroi e)/fasan nika=n. Cf. i. 105. 23, kai\ e)no/misan au)toi\ e(ka/teroi ou)k e)/lasson e)/xein.
e)pequ/moun ga/r: cf. c. 36. 17, where kalw=s is quite as justifiable as here pa/ntws, under all circumstances, in any case.—fi/lion: for Mss. fi/lon. Cf. c. 36. 18.

cunegra/yonto: sunqh/khn e)/ggrafon dedw/kasi, Schol. They drew up the treaty in writing, but withheld the ratification for the present, and e)ke/leuon dei=cai (to present il, cf. i. 133. 1) tw=| plh/qei.
te/los e)/xein : go into effect. The subj. is ti au)tw=n.
a)re/skonta : adj.; cf. i. 38. 8, ei) toi=s ple/osin a)re/skonte/s e)smen. —ta\ *(uaki/nqia: about midsummer. See on c. 23. 21.
Meanwhile the Athenians are greatly incensed against the Lacedaemonians on account of the destruction of Panactum and the conclusion of the alliance between Sparta and the Boeotians.
e)n de\ tw=|...e)/prasson : the events recorded in c. 42 and 43 are contemporaneous with those of c. 40 and 41.

w(=|: the dat. is to be explained rather by the continuation of the force of e)n than by assimilation. Cf. i. 41. 10, kai\ e)n kairoi=s toiou/tois e)ge/neto, oi(=s ma/lista a)/nqrwpoi a)peri/optoi/ ei)si.
*)androme/nhs : see App.

pa-
ralabo/ntas: see on c. 39. 14.

tw=n *boiwtw=n: the genuineness of these words is wrongly doubted by v. Herwerden, Stud. Thuc. p. 74. But the suspicion expressed in c. 40. 7, pepei=sqai u(po\ *lakedaimoni/wn, is meant to be met by saying that “the Boeotians themselves,” etc.—kaqh|rhme/non: see on c. 39. 18. e)pi\ profa/sei is to be const. with kaqh|rhme/non. “They had destroyed the fort, giving as their reason that,” etc.
koinh=| ne/mein: koinh\n nomh\n e)/xein e)n au)tw=|, Schol. Only the use of the land, not its permanent occupation, was to be permitted.— 11. e)ko/misan: cf. c. 35. 26.

nomi/zontes kai\ tou=to a)podido/nai: sc. ei)=nai. “They thought that this, too, was restoring it,” i.e. that in this way also they were fulfilling the conditions of the treaty. Cf. c. 18. 31 f., a)podo/ntwn . . . *pa/nakton. (Cobet, Mnem. 14, p. 10, proposes to insert ei)=nai after a)podido/nai; Naber, ibid. p. 319, would read ou(/tws for tou=to.)
legome/nwn tou/twn: (pres. partic.) “the moment this was said,” “as soon as they heard this.”

deina\ e)poi/oun: only here in Thuc., who uses the mid. deino\n poiei=sqai ti in i. 102. 17 and vi. 60. 21. The two expressions arise from different points of view. The latter means, strictly speaking, “to regard something as terrible or intolerable”; the former, “to do terrible things,” “to act so as to inspire terror.”
o)rqo\n paradou=nai: though this was not expressly stipulated, it was naturally their duty, e)/dei.—kai\ punqano/menoi: continues tou= te *pana/ktou th=| kaqaire/sei with a different const.
i)di/a|: a)/neu tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, Schol.—fa/skontes pro/teron: cf. c. 35. 10 f.

ta/ te a)/lla:
te connects with what precedes, and is not the correlative of the following kai/. The reference is to the complaints of c. 35. § 2 and 3.—e)sko/poun: they took into consideration. A clearer expression would be a)nesko/poun, as in i. 132. 8; vii. 42. 24.—th=s cunqh/khs: part. gen. with o(/sa, which belongs not only with e)celeloi/pesan, but also with e)chpath=sqai: and the things in which they thought they had been deceived.
pro\s tou\s pre/sbeis: unusual for toi=s pre/sbesin. Cf. i. 144. 6, tou/tois a)pokrina/menoi.
This increases the influence of the war party at Athens, and Alcibiades in particular exerts himself to attract Argos and her allies to the Athenian alliance.
au)=: with reference to the party in Sparta which was working for the same end (cf. c. 36. § 1): likewise. au)= belongs with e)ne/keinto. Cf. c. 14. 12; ii. 45. 1.
e)ne/keinto: abs. exerted themselves eagerly. See on iv. 22. 5, where (as also in viii. 85. 18) it is used in much the same sense. Elsewhere it refers to hostile attacks.

*)alkibia/dhs: this is the first mention of him by Thuc. He was born about 450 B.C., since he is said to have been in his fifth year when his father was killed in the battle of Coronea in 446 B.C. He must therefore have been at this time about thirty years of age. See Grote, VI. c. 55, p. 301.

w(s e)n a)/llh| po/lei: ut in alia civitate; according to the view held in other cities, implying that at Athens younger men were influential in polities than elsewhere. w(s as in iii. 113. 25, w(s pro\s to\ me/geqos th=s po/lews; iv. 84. 9; vi. 20. 8, and like ut in Lat., as in magno ut populo, Hor. Sat. i. 6. 79.

progo/nwn: the founder of his family was said to be Eurysaces, the son of Ajax. His father Clinias fought in his own trireme in the battle of Artemisium in 480 B.C. His mother Deinomache was the daughter of the Alcmaeonid Megacles.
e)do/kei me/n: “it was to be sure his sincere opinion, but his chief motive (ou) me/ntoi a)lla/ with increasing emphasis, see App.; also note on i. 3. 17) was ambition.”
fronh/mati: pride, as in ii. 43. 28, a)lgeinote/ra ga\r a)ndri/ ge fro/nhma e)/xonti h( . . . ka/kwsis h)\ o( . . . qa/natos.

filonikw=n : (not filoneikw=n, see Stahl, Qu. Gr. p.
13) is used of jealous striving for advancement, as in iv. 64. 5.
*la/xhtos: Laches appears also in c. 19 and c. 24, with Nicias, among the seventeen who took the oaths at the conclusion of the two treaties.—e(auto/n: see App.

th
 palaia
 proceni/an pote\ ou)=san: cf. vi. 89. § 2, tw=n d' e)mw=n progo/nwn th
 proceni/an u(mw=n kata/ ti e)/gklhma a)peipo/ntwn au)to\s e)gw\ pa/lin a)nalamba/nwn e)qera/peuon u(ma=s a)/lla te kai\ peri\ th
 e)k *pu/lou cumfora/n, and Plut. Alc. 14.
ou) timh/santes: they did not treat him with the respect he had anticipated.—tou= pa/ppou: i.e. his paternal grandfather, Alcibiades the elder.
qerapeu/wn: also in vi. 89. 5. See on 10.
pantaxo/qen: in general. Const. with a)ntei=pen. Cf. i. 17. 7, ou(/tw pantaxo/qen h( *(ella\s katei/xeto mh/te . . . katerga/zesqai.
to/ te prw=ton : opp. to kai\ to/te, 17.—ou) bebai/ous: untrustworthy. Cf. ii. 102. 8, a)/ndras ou) dokou=ntas bebai/ous ei)=nai e)ch/lasan, and note.
sfi/si: toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, Schol.
e)ce/lwsi: overthrow, conquer utterly. See on iii. 113. 27. In this sense used only in aor.—au)=qis: as in c. 36. 11: 76. 9. thereupon, afterwards.
h(/kein: he told them to “come (in the persons of ambassadors) to Athens as quickly as possible in order to invite (prokaloume/nous, fut.) the Athenians to form an alliance.”
w(s: with the gen. abs. and also with the nom. partic. cumpra/cwn, so that the two are very closely connected. Cf. iv. 5. 2 f.
The Argives, Eleans, and Mantineans immediately send envoys to Athens. Envoys from Sparta also arrive.

th=s te a)ggeli/as: the connective particle belongs in strictness with a)kou/santes, but is joined instead with the obj., because a)ggeli/as really contains the idea opp. to e)/gnwsan: “on
the one hand the message of Alcibiades reached them; on the other hand they had obtained information from other sources” that their suspicion in regard to Athens (c. 40. § 2) had been unfounded, ou) met' *)aqhnai/wn (i.e. a)/neu *)aqhnai/wn, Atheniensibus invitis) praxqei=san th\n tw=n *boiwtw=n cummaxi/an.

oi(\ sfi/si peri\ tw=n spondw=n e)/tuxon a)po/ntes: i.e. those who were carrying on the negotiations of c. 41. But the Argives had as yet received no news of the result of these negotiations or of the departure of their envoys (c. 42. 1), nor did they wait for such news (h)me/loun) before acting upon the suggestion of Alcibiades. Consequently the recommendations of the Lacedaemonians (see c. 41. 21 ff.) were never carried out.—sfi/si: a free use of the dat. (ethical dat.), as in c. 3. 21, au)toi=s. G. 184, 3, N. 6; H. 770.
pro\s de\ tou\s...th\n gnw/mhn ei)=xon : see on iii. 25. 10. Used with a common noun in c. 13. 8; 14. 4.

nomi/zontes kte(.: reflecting that it was a city which had been friendly to them of old, and that since it was, like themselves, governed by a democracy, it would aid them with its great naval power if they were involved in war.—a)po\ palaiou=: an alliance had been formed between Athens and Argos in 460 B.C. Cf. i. 102. 19 f.— 9. dhmokratoume/nhn kte(.: the same words are used in c. 29. 9, in explaining the feelings of the Mantineans toward the Argives.
th\n kata\ qa/lassan: see App.
*)hlei=oi kai\ *mantinh=s: the Mantineans (see c. 29. 1) and Eleans (see c. 31. 1 ff.) were the first to join the Argive league.

dokou=ntes kte(.: attrib. with pre/sbeis: “such as were thought to be acceptable to the Athenians.” Philocharidas is one of those who took the oaths in concluding the treaties (c. 19 and 24); Endius appears in viii. 6. 17 as a friend of the family of Alcibiades.— 16. dei/santes: refers not merely to the envoys, but to the Lacedaemonians
in general, as freq. in such cases.— 17. kai\ a(/ma *pu/lon kte(.: this second reason for their haste in reaching Athens is no longer dependent upon dei/santes, as we should expect after th/n te cummaxi/an. The inexact use of the particles does not, however, justify a change in the text.
e)pi\ kakw=|: as in iv. 86. 1, and like e)p' a)gaqw=| in c. 27. 7.—a)pologhso/menoi: although we read in c. 39. 11, *lakedaimo/nioi ei)do/tes o(/ti a)dikh/sousin *)aqhnai/ous.

Alcibiades by a trick frustrates the endeavours of the Lacedaemonian envoys, and inclines the Athenians to accept the advances of the Argives and their allies. Further proceedings are, however, interrupted by an earthquake.
cumbh=nai: aor. “come to a final agreement.”—tw=n diafo/rwn: points of difference, as in i. 56. 2; 78. 13.— 3. e)s to\n dh=mon: cf. i. 72. 14; iv. 58. 9; vi. 41. 13; 89. 1.—h)\n kai/: see App.
tau)ta/: see App.—a)pwsqh=|: used of rejecting the cummaxi/a, as in c. 22. 4, the spondai/.
mhxana=tai de/: see App.
pi/stin...dou/s : assuring them with an oath. Cf. i. 133. 14; viii. 73. 13.
mh\ o(mologh/swsin: mh\ fanerw=s ei)/pwsi, Schol.

kai/: after w(/sper is proleptie in the rel. clause, for kai/ really belongs with pei/sein. See on i. 74. 25. For the inf. (a)ntile/gein) in a rel. clause in indir. disc., see on i. 91. 23. GMT. 92, 2, N. 3; H. 947; Kr. Spr. 55, 4, 9; 53, 2, 9; Kühn. 594, 5.

kai\ o(/pws...poih/sh| : parallel to boulo/menos au)tou\s *niki/ou te a)posth=sai. But te, which would naturally stand after boulo/menos, is forced out of its place by the connective de/ and so comes to stand after *niki/ou.

w(s ou)de\n a)lhqe\s e)n nw=| e)/xousin : corresponds to ou) bebai/ous fa/skwn ei)=nai in 43. 14 (Plut. says u(gie/s, which Kr.
prefers with no sufficient reason): “that they were not to be trusted.”— 14. poih/sh|: act., used of the statesman who influences the people; in 20 poiei=sqai is mid. of the sovereign people. —e)s to\n dh=mon: i.e. after the preliminary discussion had been held e)n th=| boulh=| (1).
parelqo/ntes: parie/nai and parelqei=n are the regular expressions for coming before a deliberative assembly. See on i. 67. 16. To this corresponds paraga/gontes in 19, and c. 46. 34.

katabow=ntos: inveighing against, as in i. 67. 4 and 115. 3.— 20. seismou= de\ genome/nou: earthquakes were regarded as divine signs, and sufficed to put an end to all public business. Cf. c. 50. 26; viii. 6. 29; Plut. Nic. 10, seismo/s tis dia\ me/sou geno/menos kai\ dialu/sas th\n e)kklhsi/an. On gi/gnesqai used of natural phenomena, see on i. 54. 6.

Next day Nicias persuades the Athenians to send ambassadors, of which he himself is one, to Sparta. The Spartans refuse to give up their alliance with the Boeotians; consequently the Athenians conclude the alliance with Argos.

u(sterai/a|: Thuc. uses this word most freq. to denote the following day (though h(me/ra| is never expressed), but sometimes, as here, with other substs. to denote what happened on the following day. See on i. 44. 4.— tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn au)tw=n h)pathme/nwn: see App.
peri\ tou= mh\...o)mologh=sai h(/kein : in regard to the announcement that they had not come with full powers. Const. with both h)pathme/nwn and e)chpathme/nos.

e)pisxo/ntas : in meaning as in c. 32. 24 (delay, wait); but here, as in c. 63. 13 and ii. 76. 4, const. with the acc.—ta\ pro\s *)argei/ous: as in c. 39. 16, ta\ e)s *boiwtou/s. th\n cummaxi/an tw=n *)argei/wn,
Schol.

e)n...kalw=| : e)n (as in the conj. e)n w(=|, see on ii. 1. 2) denotes the circumstances, the state of things. “He urged them to put off the war, under circumstances (i.e. since the circumstances were) favourable for them, but humiliating for the Lacedaemonians.” The words kalo/n and a)prepe/s are justified by the fact that Athens could very well remain in her present condition, whereas Sparta must try to improve hers by means of war. e)n kalw=| as in c. 59. 17; 60. 11. Cf. i. 33. 1.

w(s e)pi\ plei=ston: as long as possible. See on i. 82. 20.—diasw/sasqai th
 eu)pragi/an: as in iii. 39. 26, th
 eu)daimoni/an, and c. 16. 11, th
 eu)tuxi/an; mid., preserve their own good fortune.
o(/ti ta/xista: const. with diakinduneu=sai.—eu(/rhma: a piece of good luck. So in Hdt.vii. 155. 8; Xen. Anab. ii. 3. 18; vii. 3. 13; and e(/rmaion, Plat. Phaedo, 107 c; Sympos. 217 a.
e)/peise/ te: expresses the result: “and he succeeded in persuading them.”
o)rqo/n: as in c. 42. 17. Const. with *pa/nakton only.

a)nei=nai: give up, as in c. 31. 15, th
 e)pitroph/n; i. 75. 13, th
 a)rxh/n.—h)
 mh\...e)si/wsi: cf. c. 42. § 2.
kaqa/per ei)/rhto: on the lack of agreement between this passage and c. 23. § 1, see App. on c. 39. 12.

o(/ti kai\ sfei=s...a)/n...pepoih=sqai : instead of e)pepoi/hnto, as we should expect. Kr. Spr. 55, 4, N. 10, gives examples of a similar confusion of two consts. in Xen. All these cases seem to be the result of carelessness in the author.

w(s parei=nai au)tou/s: sc. tou\s *)argei/ous. Here the inf. of the indir. disc. is retained in the dependent clause. Cf. c. 45. 9. GMT. 92, 2, N. 3 a; H. 947. w(s corresponds to the causal cum: “for this was just the purpose for which they had come.”

pa/nta: repeats ei)/ ti a)/llo.— tou\s peri\ to\n *niki/an pre/sbeis: i.e. *niki/an kai\ tou\s a)/llous pre/sbeis. So
also in 25 and vi. 96. 14. G. 141, N. 3; H. 666 c.

*boiwtoi=s mh\ e)siou=sin: ‘dat. of interest,’ loosely connected with the verb (a)nh/sousi); not unlike the gen. abs. in meaning. See on iv. 56. 1, and App. on iv. 10. 11. H. 771 a. e)siou=sin is the cond. partic., and so mh/, not ou). Cf. 14.
e)pikratou/ntwn: with inf. of result, as in vi. 74. 8, e)pekra/toun mh\ de/xesqai.

to
 e)/foron : cf. c. 36. 7. The art. is repeated with the explanatory designation, as in ii. 67. 14, to
 *sa/dokon to
 gegenhme/non *)aqhnai=on.— th=s au)th=s gnw/mhs h)=san: “were of the same political party.” Cf. i. 113. 10.

a)nenew/santo: this was to be done annually, acc. to the provision of the treaty. Cf. c. 18. 54. Since the conclusion of the treaty in the spring of 421 B.C. a year had passed. See on c. 40. 1.—e)fobei=to ga/r: gives a reason for deome/nou *niki/ou. By the renewal of the oaths Nicias hoped at least to prove that the peace which he had been so prominent in arranging was still effective.—mh/...a)pe/lqh| kai\ diablhqh=| : “that his mission would be absolutely unsuccessful (which would be painful enough for him), and he would be exposed to the attacks of his enemies in addition.” The sense would be more exactly expressed by mh/, h)\n pa/nta a)telh= e)/xwn a)pe/lqh|, kai\ diablhqh=|, taking kai/ in a pregnant sense.
di) o)rgh=s ei)=xon: abs. Cf. dia\ fulakh=s (ii. 81. 16), e)n fulakh=| (iv. 14. 26), and e)n o)rrwdi/a| (ii. 89. 3) with e)/xein: “were in a state of angry excitement.”

paro/ntes: refers to the presence of the envoys in Athens (see c. 44. 11 ff.), paragago/ntos, 34, to their introduction into the assembly (see on c. 45. 15) where the treaty was concluded. The parenthe
sis includes therefore only e)/tuxon . . . cu/mmaxoi, not paragago/ntos *)alkibia/dou, as Bekker and others have thought.
Terms of the alliance between the Athenians on one side, and the Argives, Mantineans, and Eleans on the other.
sponda\s e)poih/santo kte(.: see App.
a)do/lous kai\ a)blabei=s: the same formula as in c. 18. 11. Several other expressions of c. 18 and 23 are repeated here.
o(/pla de/: also occurs in c. 18. 12 preceded by the same words as here. It stands very properly opp. to the declaration of peace, so that de/ should not (with Kr.) be omitted.
te/xnh| mhde\ mhxanh=|: a slight variation from c. 18. 15, but there is no change in meaning.
h)\n pole/mioi i)/wsin kte(.: cf. c. 23. 2-15 and below 21 and 36.
e)pagge/llwsin: demand, call for; also in vi. 56. 5.

mhde\ kata\ qa/lassan: Kr. considered these words an interpolation, as they disagree with c. 56. 6; it appears, however, from the count of the letters and spaces in the inscription discussed in the App., that they were contained in the original document (see App.). This provision evidently affects the Athenians only, as the other members of the alliance were powerless at sea, and seems to prove that the sea was regarded as part of the domain of Athens, through which she binds herself to allow no one diie/nai e)pi\ pole/mw|. (Pericles, in ii. 62. 10 ff., says: du/o merw=n e)s xrh=sin fanerw=n, gh=s kai\ qala/sshs, tou= e(te/rou u(ma=s panto\s kuriwta/tous o)/ntas.) The expression dia\ th=s gh=s is, therefore, not to be taken too literally; and indeed gh=s is omitted in c. 56. 5.—h)
 mh/: elliptical, as elsewhere ei) mh/. Cf. Dem. XXIV. 46, ou)k e)w=n le/gein ou)de\ xrhmati/zein a)
 mh\ th=s a)dei/as doqei/shs. In Thuc. supply dii/wsi with h)
 mh/, in Dem. le/gwsi kai\ xrhmati/zwsi. GMT. 42, 3, N. 2; H. 905 a.

e)ph\n e)/lqh|: the sing, may be explained by supposing that the city herself is supposed to go in the persons of her soldiers or by supplying a sing. from bohqou=sin, such as boh/qeia or o( bohqw=n. St. and v. Herwerden (following Kirchhoff) read e)/lqwsin, which is obtained by calculating the space on this line of the inscription, and is certainly easier and simpler. These words are closely connected with me/xri tria/konta h(merw=n, “from the day on which,” etc. Cf. viii. 58. 19 and 24, e)ph\n ai( basile/ws nh=es a)fi/kwntai, and Ar. Av. 1355.

bou/lwntai: this, which is the reading of the Mss., is a rather awkward con
structio ad sensum with po/lis. Kirchhoff, St., and v. Herwerden read bou/lhtai.

*ai)ginai/ous : the Aeginetan system of coinage was the one most in vogue throughout Greece, and therefore best adapted for use in international transactions. The Aeginetan drachma, also called paxei=a, was heavier than the Attic, containing, as Hultsch, Metrol. p. 192 ff., shows from the weight of coins which have been preserved, 8.3 Attic obols, while the Attic drachma contained six. Poll. ix. 76 and 86 says wrongly that the Aeginetan drachma contained ten Attic obols.
th=| au)th=s: Duker for Mss. th=| au)th=|.
kata\ po/leis: cf. c. 18. 48.
o(mnu/ntwn...kata\ i(erw=n : cf. Ar. Ran. 101, o)mo/sai kaq' i(erw=n. The i(era\ te/leia are probably the hostiae maiores, full-grown victims, which Hdt.i. 183. 8 opposes to ta\ galhqina/.

ai( e)/ndhmoi a)rxai/ : magistrates whose official functions were confined to the city, and did not, like those of the generals, extend beyond its limits; opp. to u(pero/rioi a)rxai/.—e)corkou/ntwn: used of the magistrates who preside over the ceremony and administer the oath; also in Hdt.iii. 133. 7; iv. 154. 13.

ai( a)rti=nai: probably as in ai( a)rxai/ above the office stands for the officials; therefore the reading of the Mss. is not to be changed to oi( a)rtu=nai. But little is known of these and the following magistrates. See on c. 37. 5.

tria/konta h(me/rais: the difference between the thirty days here and the ten days in 61 arises from the fact that the Athenian envoys were to take the oaths in three cities, the others only in Athens. h(me/rais is ‘dat. of degree of difference’ before pro\ *)olumpi/wn.—*panaqhnai/wn: in the third year of each olympiad. The two festivals were therefore two years apart.
e)n po/lei: see on c. 18. 55.
kataqe/ntwn de\ kai\ *)olumpi/asi: to be executed by the Eleans as sovereigns and directors of the temple of Zeus and the Olympic festival, but in the name of all the members of the league, koinh=|.
*)olumpi/ois toi=s nuni/ : “at the Olympic games of this year.” Cf. c. 49. 1.
e)a/n...ei)=nai : see App.
The treaty between Athens and Sparta (c. 18) is, however, not renounced. The Corinthians refuse to join the Argives in the Athenian alliance, but turn their thoughts again toward the Lacedaemonians.

h( cummaxi/a: to correspond to c. 46. 35 (see on c. 27. 2), for ai( cummaxi/ai of the Mss. e)ge/nonto (not e)ge/neto, as in c. 80. 1 and i. 102. 22, kate/sth) has for its subj. ai( spondai\ kai\ h( cummaxi/a regarded as a compound subst. of which the pl. ai( spondai/ is the most important part; accordingly the following ai( tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn kai\ *)aqhnai/wn refers grammatically only to spondai/. Indeed the cummaxi/a (c. 23) of the Lacedaemonians and Athenians was practically if not formally at an end, since both parties had entered into obligations which conflicted with
it.
ou)k a)pei/rhnto: the treaty was not renounced, i.e. was not regarded as void.
ou)d' u(f) e(te/rwn: not by either party. Equiv. to u(p' ou)dete/rwn. Cf. ii. 67. 34, tou\s mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn.

*kori/nqioi de\ *)argei/wn o)/ntes cu/mmaxoi kte(.: the conduct of the Corinthians is represented as equivocal from the beginning: “although they were allies of the Argives (see c. 31. 25 ff.), they did not join the alliance with the Athenians.” To this is added the parenthetical sent., a)lla\ kai\ . . . ou) cunw/mosan (see a similar parenthesis in c. 72. 3 f.). This refers, as explanation and confirmation, to the events recorded in c. 29-31: “for that matter, when the Eleans, Mantineans, and Argives had (at their instigation) made an alliance (see c. 29. 1 f. and 31. 24) the year before (pro\ tou/tou), they had not joined it.” (cunw/mosan, aor. in parenthetical clause with the force of plpf.; see on ii. 2. 12. GMT. 19, N. 4; H. 837.) We now learn for the first time that the Eleans and Mantineans had bound themselves to the Argives toi=s au)toi=s polemei=n kai\ ei)rh/nhn a)/gein (either when they first became allies of Argos, or by some subsequent agreement of which no mention is made), whereas the Corinthians, who in c. 31. 25 eu)qu\s met' e)kei/nous *)argei/wn cu/mmaxoi e)ge/nonto, had confined themselves, in accordance with their invitation to the Argives (c. 27. 13), to an e)pimaxi/a, a)llh/lois bohqei=n, cunepistrateu/ein de\ mhdeni/, i.e. to a defensive alliance. Now they declare themselves contented with this treaty (a)rkei=n sfi/si th\n prw/thn genome/nhn e)pimaxi/an, which is no other than that mentioned in c. 31. 25 f.), and refuse to join in the new alliance with Athens. This Thuc. regards as a departure from their previous connexions (ou(/tws a)pe/sthsan tw=n cumma/xwn) and a return to their old relations with the Lacedaemonians, pa/lin pointing to a renewal of earlier relations (cf. c. 32. 5).

a)lla\ kai\...ou) cunw/mosan : is properly a parenthesis, for a)rkei=n d' e)/fasan kte(. must explain ou)k e)sh=lqon e)s au)ta/s, and the fact that they had not joined the Eleans, Argives, and Mantineans in their offensive and defensive alliance is merely introduced as an illustration of the half-heartedness of the Corinthians, but is not of sufficient importance to warrant the further explanation a)rkei=n d' e)/fasan kte(. (St. and Schütz think a)rkei=n d' e)/fasan kte(. explains cunw/mosan, and that there is therefore no parenthesis).
pro\s tou/s...gnw/mhn ei)=xon : see on c. 44. 7 and iii. 25. 10.
The Eleans exclude the Lacedaemonians from the Olympic games, on the ground that they had broken the Olympic truce and refused to pay the fine imposed upon them.

pagkra/tion: in later times the name of the victor in the stadium is usually the one given. In iii. 8. 5 the kind of contest is not specified.—to\ prw=ton: points to subsequent victories of the same man.
di/khn: fine or punishment imposed by judicial sentence. Cf. vi. 29. 5.
e)n tw=| no/mw|: see App.—katedika/santo: mid. because they gave sentence in their own case.
sfa=s: see App.—*fu/rkon: Phyrcus was a fort near Lepreum not far from the southern border of Triphylia. Paus., iii. 8. 3, gives some details of this attack under King Agis.
au(tw=n o(pli/tas: see App.—e)n tai=s spondai=s: temporal, as in 16 below; i. 55. 14; ii. 2. 19; iii. 52. 20.— 9. h)=san: agrees with the pred. Cf. i. 10. 30, o(/ti me\n *mukh=nai mikro\n h)=n.
katadedika/sqai: mid. with subj. au)tou/s understood, not pass.
mh\ e)phgge/lqai tw: “that the sacred truce had not yet been proclaimed.”

th/n...e)kexeiri/an : the truce occasioned by the festival. See App. on c. 1. 1.—par' au)toi=s: const. with ei)=nai (“it had been already in force in their country”; ei)=nai as preterite), stands proleptically with the subst.— 14. prw/tois ga\r sfi/sin au)toi=s: refers to the Eleans, not (as E. Curtius, Hermes 14, p. 131, thinks) to the
Lacedaemonians.
laqei=n: i.e. before they (the Eleans) knew anything about it.

u(pela/mbanon: replied (took speech against them) as in u(polabw\n ei)=pe, ii. 72. 1; iii. 113. 11.—ou) xrew\n ei)=nai kte(.: they need not have announced (GMT. 49, 2, N. 3 a) the truce in Sparta if they had been of the opinion that the Lacedaemonians had already transgressed it (by beginning hostilities); but they had not done it (i.e. proclaimed the truce) in this belief at all. For tou=to dra=sai, see on i. 5. 11; ii. 49. 22; iii. 40. 21; iv. 59. 6).
ou)x w(s nomi/zontes: not as if they thought so, but as if they didn't think so. (Naber, Mnem. 14, p. 320, suggests ou)x ou(/tw nomi/zontes.)
kai\ o(/pla ou)damo/se e)/ti au)toi=s e)penegkei=n: they (the Lacedaemonians) had not continued hostilities against them after the truce had been announced at Sparta.
mh\ a)\n peisqh=nai: ‘the Eleans were still positive that the Lacedaemonians were in the wrong, and said that they would never be persuaded of the contrary’ (Jowett).
