to/ te au(tw=n me/ros: the fine of 2000 minae would, if paid, have been divided between the state of Elis and the temple.—gi/gnetai: o)fei/letai, Schol.
Still the fear of a disturbance at the games turns out to be unfounded. Fruitless negotiations at Corinth.
a)naba/ntas: a necessary correction for a)naba/ntes of most Mss.— 4. e)peidh\ proqumou=ntai: since they eagerly desired.
e)pomo/sai: see App.

qusi/as kai\ a)gw/nwn: in appos. with tou= i(erou=, answering the same purpose as w(/ste with the corresponding infs. in c. 49. 3. These words are not necessary, but are not out of place here (Kr. and St. bracket them
as an interpolation derived from c. 49. 3).

oi)/koi e)/quon: for ‘participation in the sacrifice at the festival of the Olympian Zeus belonged to the state religion of the Spartans’ (Curtius, Hermes 14, p. 131).—e)qew/roun: “were on the spot and took part in the festival.” Cf. c. 18. 4; viii. 10. 2.

mh\ bi/a| qu/swsi: “that they would force their way to the sacrifice by arms,” aor.—cu
 o(/plois tw=n newte/rwn: an unusual expression: cum iuuentute armata, with the young men under arms. The simple cu
 o(/plois or cu
 toi=s o(/plois (cf. 13; ii. 2. 11; 90. 28; iv. 14. 13; vi. 105. 10) freq. denotes arms in actual use, and is practically equiv. to cu
 o(pli/tais. Cf. Scott, Marmion, i. 20.
The sight of plundering Border spears Might justify suspicious fears.

Here the o(/pla are limited to the new/teroi because the rest of the population was just then busy with the festival.— 12. *(arpi/nh|: for *)/argei of the Mss. is an emendation of Michaelis (Philol. 24, p. 166) adopted by Cl. and St. Harpina, one of the eight towns of the Pisatid (Strab. viii. 32), was situated in the valley of the Alpheus, twenty stadia above Olympia (Curtius, Pelopon. II. p. 50; Bursian, II. p. 287 f.), near enough for protection, and far enough away to avoid disturbing the festival by the sight of arms.
*li/xas: the same who appears freq. in the course of the war as a man of some influence. Cf. c. 76. 11; viii. 39. 8, etc.
r(abdou/xwn: prob. the subordinates of the agonothetae or hellanodicae, whose duty was to keep order and correct offenders. Hermann, Griech. Alt. II. § 50, note 20.

*boiwtw=n dhmosi/ou: tou= dhmosi/ou tw=n *boiwtw=n, Schol. Apparently Lichas had the community or state of the Boeotians proclaimed victor. Others take dhmosi/ou with zeu/gous.— kata\ th\n ou)k e)cousi/an: dia\ to\ mh\ e)cei=nai *lakedaimoni/ois a)gwni/zesqai, Schol. Cf. i. 137. 28, th\n tw=n gefurw=n ou) dia/lusin, and c. 35. 6. Lichas had the Boeotians proclaimed victor because he, as a Lacedaemonian, could not take part in the games. He was struck by the beadles because he went upon the course and crowned his charioteer.

a)gwni/sews: this word occurs only here in Thuc. and prob. nowhere else in Att. Greek.—e)s to\n a)gw=na:
upon the course.—a)ne/dhse: e)stefa/nwse, Schol.

ti ne/on: in the sense of the more usual comp. new/te ro/n ti, as in i. 132. 25; vii. 86. 22.— 22. ou(/tw dih=lqen: i.e. without any further disturbance. au)toi=s refers not to the Lacedaemonians but the Greeks (pa/ntes, 20) present at Olympia.
te/los: adv. finally.—seismou= genome/nou: cf. c. 45. 20.
The Heracleans of Trachis are defeated by the neighbouring tribes.
*(hraklew/tais: Heraclea in Trachis was founded in 426 B.C. See iii. 92.
*mhlia=s: see App.

prosoikou=nta: in pred. position, gives the reason for pole/mia h)=n. Being neighbours of the Heracleans they felt that the town was dangerous to them. The same idea is expressed by w(=n e)pi\ th=| gh=| e)kti/zeto, iii. 93. 7, where the foundation of Heraclea is described.
e)teixi/sqh: teixi/zein of the fortified settlement, as in iii. 92. 24.
kaqistame/nh|: pass. like kaqi/stasqai, iii. 92. 14.
fqei/rontes: denotes continued destructive action. Cf. e)/fqeiron, iii. 93. 8.—e)ni/khsan: aor., expressing the momentary result without regard to further consequences. See on i. 29. 19.
*kni/dios: gen. of *kni=dis. Cf. iv. 107. 11, *goa/cios. Meineke (Hermes 3, p. 363) suggests *knidi/ou. The name is uncertain. Xenares is doubtless the ephor of c. 36. 7.

The Boeotians take possession of Heraclea to protect it against the Athenians. Alcibiades, acting in concert with the Argives and their allies, tries to increase the power of the confederacy in Peloponnesus.
e)fqei/reto: i.e. by its hostile neighbours. Cf. c. 51. 7.
pare/labon: i.e. in a friendly way, for protection (not kate/labon); but the Lacedaemonians regarded it differently.

w(s ou) kalw=s a)/rxonta: about the misconduct of the Lacedaemonian governors in Heraclea complaints were made as early as iii. 93. 15, xalepw=s te kai\ e)/stin a(\ ou) kalw=s e)chgou/menoi (sc. tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn oi( a)fiknou/menoi).
*lakedaimoni/wn ta\ kata\ *pelopo/nnhson qoruboume/nwn: “since the Lacedaemonians had their hands full with Peloponnesian affairs just then” (pres.).
*)alkibia/dhs: on his position and conduct at this time, see Müller-Strübing, Aristoph. und die hist. Krit. p. 398 f.
tw=n au)to/qen (a)po\ *peloponnh/sou, Schol.) cumma/xwn: part. gen. with paralabw/n, as in iv. 80. 7 with e)kpe/myai.
peri\ th\n cummaxi/an : he made the arrangements required by the treaty of c. 47.

*patre/as: Patrae, now Patras. On the importance of its position at the entrance of the Gulf of Corinth, see Curtius, Peloponnes. I. p. 434 ff. Hertzberg, Alkibiades, p. 101, shows the importance of this expedition.

tei/xh kaqei=nai...e)s qa/lassan : i.e. makra\ tei/xh e)s qa/lassan oi)kodomei=n acc. to a regular principle of Athenian policy, to make the town accessible from the sea. See on i. 103. 14.— e(/teron (sc. tei=xos) teixi/sai: cf. i. 90. 7; 91. 3.

tw=| *(ri/w| tw=| *)axai+kw=|:
a low point of land on the coast of Achaea. On the opposite side of the gulf is a similar cape called to\ *(ri/on to\ *molukrino/n. Cf. ii. 84. 29; 86. 6 and 11.

oi(=s h)=n e)n bla/bh| teixisqe/n: (sc. to\ *(ri/on) “those to whom the fortification of Rhium by the Athenians was injurious” (because they would then have entire control of the entrance to the Gulf of Corinth). The const. is like i. 100. 16 f., oi(=s pole/mion h)=n to\ xwri/on ktizo/menon. e)n bla/bh| is a periphrasis for the adj. Cf. e)n h(donh=|, Hdt.iv. 139. 8; vii. 15. 11.
The Argives acting under the advice of Alcibiades make war against the Epidaurians.

profa/sei: the dat. (here and in vi. 76. 5) and the acc. (in c. 80. 17; iii. 111. 2; vi. 33. 9) are used by Thuc. with the same signification.—qu/matos: a rare word, corresponding to the Dor. su/matos in c. 77. 11.

tou= *puqae/ws: from nom. *puqaeu/s, used by Paus. ii. 24. 1, who says of the inhabitants of Hermione, ii. 35. 2, to\ tou= *puqae/ws o)/noma memaqh/kasi para\ *)argei/wn (the uncontracted form is retained after the analogy of *mhlie/ws, iv. 100. 2). Prob. the temple of Apollo Pythaeus is meant, which was the only building left standing by the Argives when they destroyed Asine, acc. to Paus. ii. 36. 5. Perhaps the Epidaurians, even though the Argives were kuriw/tatoi tou= i(erou=, claimed a share in the use of the lands of the temple for pasturage or similar purposes, and the expression u(pe\r botami/wn, which does not occur elsewhere, may refer to this. (St. writes u(pe\r botanw=n and cites Plat. Rep. 401 b, pro pascuis. parapotami/wn, which Poppo took from inferior Mss., is still more difficult to explain.)—de/on: acc. abs., equiv. to e)/dei. When they ought to have (but did not).—a)pagagei=n: pay. Cf. Ar. Vesp. 707, to\n fo/ron a)pa/gousin; Xen. Cyr. ii. 4. 12.
e)do/kei: “it was their opinion,” “they favoured the plan.” Cf. iii. 30. 2; iv. 71. 6.—kai\ a)/neu th=s ai)ti/as: “even apart from the abovementioned ground of complaint.”
proslabei=n: i.e. to force them to join the Argive alliance. Cf. i. 35. 14; iii. 13. 31.

th=s te *kori/nqou e(/neka h(suxi/as kai\...braxute/ran e)/sesqai th\n boh/qeian : the first reason is expressed by e(/neka h(suxi/as: “in order to keep Corinth quiet” (which was now in a position of doubtful
friendship toward Argos; cf. c. 48. § 2); the second by the acc. and fut. inf. which is still under the influence of e)do/kei: “and the Athenians (they thought) would be able to bring aid to Argos more quickly by way of Aegina (if they could march through the Epidaurian territory) than if they were obliged to sail around Scyllaeum.”

h)\ periplei=n: a loose const. caused by attraction of the preceding inf. periplei=n stands as the subj. of e)/sesqai which is to be supplied from the preceding line: “than (it would be) to sail round,” etc. We should naturally expect a cond. clause after h)/. Cf. iv. 66. 15, kai\ nomi/zontes e)la/ssw sfi/si to\n ki/ndunon h)\ tou\s e)kpeso/ntas u(po\ sfw=n katelqei=n.

*sku/llaion : Scyllaeum, a promontory between Hermione and Troezene.— 10. au)toi/: sponte. They did not wish the influence of Alcibiades to be observed; and therefore they mentioned only one reason for hostilities, that they must collect the arrears of sacrifice.—dia\ tou= qu/matos th\n e)/spracin: on the position of the words, see on i. 32. 8; iii. 46. 19.
Ademonstration of the Lacedaemonians against Argos and for the assistance of Epidaurus is without result.

*leu=ktra: can be only the Areadian Leuctra, since it is described as pro\s to\ *lu/kaion (another Leuctra was in Laconia, near the mouth of the Pamisus). At this time the Lacedaemonians counted it among their possessions, although it was situated in the meqori/a, and they wished to cross the border from this point. It afterwards belonged to the territory of Megalopolis. See Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 293 and p. 336, note 9.
ai( po/leis: ai( *lakwnikai/, Schol., doubtless correctly. At first only the perioeci were called out (pandhmei/, 2). kai\ toi=s cumma/xois perih/ggeilan, 7, applies only to the later campaign.

ta\ diabath/ria: sc. i(era/. Cf. c. 116. 3. The sacrifice offered to Zeus by the Spartan kings before crossing the border; freq. in Xen. Hell. (iii. 4. 3; iv. 7. 2; v. 3. 14; 4. 37 and 47), who describes it, de Rep. Lac. 13. 2 ff.
prouxw/rei: cf. Xen. Hell. iii. 4. 3, e)ch=lqe. Elsewhere in Thuc., c. 55. 15 and c. 116. 3, and Xen. ll.cc., e)ge/neto.

meta\ to\n me/llonta : sc. mh=na. The Laconian month *karnei=os corre
sponds to the Att. *metageitniw/n as the second month of summer, nearly our August.
i(eromhni/a: see App.
tetra/di fqi/nontos: i.e. on the 27th of the month.

a)/gontes th
 h(me/ran tau/thn pa/nta to
 xro/non: with this punctuation (comma after pa/nta to
 xro/non, not before), which is that adopted by Bekker, Grote, VI. p. 336, explains: ‘keeping that day during the whole time’; i.e. they called every day the 27th as long as they were in Epidaurian territory, and in that way postponed the following month as long as they pleased. Madvig (Advv. Critt. I. p. 324) gives the same explanation: Argivi fraude minime sane subtili utentes, ne mense Carneo, ut adversarii, quiescere cogerentur, per totum tempus unum diem se agere finexerunt eodemque omnes numero nomineque signarunt, triaka/da [rather tetra/da] fqi/nontos mensis qui Carneum praecedebat appellantes. He compares with this a similar trick told of Alexander by Plut. Alex. 16. Grote reminds us that the Argives once tried a similar trick against the Lacedaemonians. Cf. Xen. Hell. iv. 7. 1 f. (Schütz, Ztschr. für d. Gymn. Wesen 1, 31, p. 258, thinks it means “marching this day all the time,” i.e. ‘they employed the whole day in marching.’)

tines oi( me/n: Kr. explains this by saying that tines shows that oi( me/n . . . oi( de/ do not include all the allies, some of whom may actually have come. This seems prob. from c. 55. 6, tou\s d' *)epidauri/ous kai\ tou\s cumma/xous. (Cl. explains tines oi( me/n as equiv to oi( me/n tines, but suggests that oi( me/n may be a copyist's addition.)
A conference held at Mantinea. The war between Argos and Epidaurus is intermitted at the suggestion of the Corinthians, but is presently renewed.
a)po\ tw=n po/lewn: primarily from the allied cities (c. 47); but the narrative shows that envoys from other places, or at any rate from Corinth, were present.
parakalesa/ntwn: used esp. of invitations to allies. Cf. i. 67. 3; v. 17. 17; 27. 3.

o(molo-
gei=n: only here in figurative sense, agree, correspond; elsewhere used of persons, come to an agreement.

e)f' e(kate/rwn e)lqo/ntas: St. (followed by Cl. and v. Herwerden) for a)f' e)kate/rwn of Mss. Euphamidas calls upon the envoys present to go to the camps of the two hostile parties and bring about a cessation of hostilities (dialu=sai). —kai\ ou(/tw: “and when that had been accomplished.” See on c. 38. 5.
pa/lin le/gein: “they might renew their conference.”

peisqe/ntes: sc. the envoys. (Cl. says: ‘the envoys of both parties, who had agreed to this.’ Perhaps rather the envoys present at Mantinea, whose influence would certainly suffice to effect a truce.)
a)ph/gagon: they induced them to depart. Cf. iii. 36. 3; v. 35. 21.
ou)d' w(\s e)dunh/qhsan cumbh=nai: refers esp. to those engaged in the war, i.e. the Argives and Epidaurians.
*karu/as: Caryae, on the road from Sparta to Tegea. In early times it was a canton of the Tegeans, later a town of the Perioeci. It lay near the present Arachova. Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 261.
e)ge/neto: see on c. 54. 7.
w(s to\ tri/ton me/ros: w(s with numerals denotes that they are only to be taken approximately, as in iv. 31. 8, w(s tria/konta.

e)boh/qhsan : aor., corresponds to our plpf., as in c. 48. 7, cunw/mosan. Opp. to this and completing the account, stand the words kai\ w(s . . . a)ph=lqon: “as soon as they heard that the Lacedaemonians had marched out, they hastened to take the field, and now that they were no longer needed, they went home.”
puqo/menoi [de\] tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous : see App.

w(s ou)de\n e)/ti au)tw=n e)/dei: intimates briefly that they had also heard of the departure of the Lacedaemonians.—
20. ou(/tw dih=lqen: Müller-Strübing, Aristoph. und die hist. Krit. p. 400, note, thinks this expression intimates that the summer had been uneventful. But dielqei=n is so freq. used by Thuc. to denote the passage of time (cf. i. 82. 12; iv. 115. 1; v. 20. 3; 50. 22), that no special signification should be attached to it here.
The Lacedaemonians send a garrison to Epidaurus. The Athenians bring Helots to Pylos to plunder Laconia. The Argives make an unsuccessful attack upon Epidaurus.
laqo/ntes *)aqhnai/ous: their ships were doubtless on guard in the Gulf of Argos. These words express the opinion referred to in c. 47. 31, that the sea was under the rule of Athens,
*)aghsippi/dan: prob. the same whose name is given in Att. form, *(hghsippi/dan, in c. 52. 3.

gegramme/non: acc. abs. of the impers. verb like ei)rhme/non in c. 30. 9; 39. 12. G. 278, 2; H. 973.—dia\ th=s e(autw=n: with intentional omission of gh=s of c. 47. 30. See on c. 47. 31 and Grote VI. c. 56, p. 340.—e)n tai=s spondai=s: const. with gegramme/non. spondai/, treaty, is here used to mean the written document.—e(ka/stous: corresponding to w(=n a)\n a)/rxwsin e(/kastoi, c. 47. 31.
komiou=sin: transfer, see to the transportation of. Cf. c. 35. 26.
tou\s *messhni/ous kai\ *ei(/lwtas: cf. c. 35. 27.—a)dikh/sesqai: in pass. signification occurs also in vi. 87. 17.

th=|...*lakwnikh=| sth/lh| : h)\n e)/sthsan oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)/xousan ta\s *lakwnika\s sponda/s, Schol. On the Acropolis. See c. 23. 23.—u(pe/grayan: this did not officially put an end to the peace with Sparta, but prepared the way for war by showing that the Athenians no longer considered themselves bound by the treaty.

e)k *krani/wn: on the island of Cephallenia, where they had given them a home. See c. 35. § 7.—lh/|zesqai: for the simple inf. expressing purpose, cf. c. 2. 11, periplei=n; ii. 84. 25, kate/sthsan tre/pesqai; vi. 16. 33. GMT. 97; H. 951.
e)k paraskeuh=s: e)k fanera=s parata/cews, Schol. Cf. iv. 94. 4.
w(s tu/xoien, diefqei/ronto: impf. after the opt. of the cond. rel. sent. in general supposition. So ii. 4. 3, ta\s prosbola\s h(=| prospi/ptoien a)pewqou=nto. GMT. 62; H. 914, B, (2).
pro\s e)/ar h)/dh: see on c. 17. 7; i. 30. 20.

w(s e)rh/mou ou)/shs kte(.: in the belief that since the place was stripped of its defenders by the war they would take it by storm. On the use of the gen. abs., see GMT. 110, 1, N. 5; H. 972d. w(s belongs with ai(rh/sontes, but also affects e)rh/mou ou)/shs.
The next summer (418 B.C.) the Lacedaemonians and their allies take the field with a great armament against Argos.
au)toi=s: dat. as in c. 3. 21.

ta)=lla: the other states. ta\ me/n and ta\ de/ distribute the preceding ta)=lla (part. appos. G. 137, N. 2; H. 624 d), so that ou) kalw=s ei)=xe must be taken as referring to their disaffection. On the other hand, au)ta/, 5, refers, not to the separate states, but to the general condition of things, acc. to the usage of i. 1. 10. See on c. 27. 3.

prokatalh/yontai: abs. here, as in iii. 2. 15; 3. 9. and 46. 25: “take measures of precaution” (Jowett). On the various uses of prokatalamba/nein, see on i. 57. 15. (Herbst, Philol. 24, p. 626, defends the reading of inferior Mss. katalh/yontai.)

e)pi\ ple/on xwrh/sesqai: would go further, as in vii. 50. 19, e)pi\ to\ be/ltion.—e)stra/teuon e)p) *)/argos: in a general way, they took the field against Argos. Since the Boeotians and Corinthians chose Phlius as the place in which their contingents were to unite (10, e)s *fliou=nta cunele/gonto), Agis also marched in that direction.

o(/soi a)/lloi: i.e. the Heraeans
and Maenalians. Cf. c. 67. 7.
*fliou=nta: see Bursian, II. p. 35, note 5. See App.

a(/mippoi: (cf. Xen. Hell. vii. 5. 24, a(mi/ppous pezou/s) ‘footsoldiers, who being attached each to a horseman (which is to be inferred from i)/soi), accompanied him on foot or, as occasion demanded, sprang upon his horse’ (Kr.); ‘foot-soldiers who ran alongside with the horsemen’ (Grote). In Thuc. and Xen. a Boeotian custom. Caes., Bell. Gall. i. 48. 5, ascribes the same custom to the Germans of Ariovistus; there we find totidem, as here i)/soi.
The Argives march out to meet them. The Lacedaemonians effect a union with their allies at Phlius, after which they advance in three divisions by three roads into the plain of Argos.

*)argei=oi de\ proaisqo/menoi...e)xw/roun, to/te dh/ kte(.: *)argei=oi proaisqo/menoi th/n te prw/thn tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn paraskeuh\n kai\ au)=qis prosxwrou=ntas tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous e)pi\ *fliou=ntos u(pe\r tou= toi=s i)di/ois summi=cai summa/xois, Schol. Two members of a period are connected, of which one is expressed by a partic., while the other begins with e)peidh/ and ends with a finite verb. Cf. c. 44. § 1. See App.
prosmi=cai: see App.

e)boh/qhsan d) au)toi=s...trisxi/lioi o(pli=tai : inserted parenthetically, so that the story begins again with kai\ proi+o/ntes. e)boh/qhsan has therefore the force of the plpf., had joined them. See on c. 48. 3 and ii. 2. 12.

*mequdri/w|: Methydrium in the highlands of Arcadia, at the junction of the brooks which form the Ladon. Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 306 ff. Hence the name. The Lacedaemonians had turned considerably toward the west in order to avoid Mantinea. e)n *mequdri/w| as in c. 55. 1, e)n th=| *)epidau/rw|.
e)poreu/eto: impf. he set out in a northerly direction through Orchomenus and Alea.
e)xw/roun: also impf.; therefore e)s *)/argos: “on the road to Argos.” From this road they then turned more to the north toward Nemea, which lies between Argos and Phlius, but near Phlius.
e)/peita: without de/. Cf. c. 7. 1.

tau/thn ou)k e)tra/peto: the acc. as in iii. 24. 1, e)xw/roun th\n e)s *qh/bas fe/rousan o(do/n, nomi/zontes h(/kista sfa=s tau/thn au)tou\s u(potoph=sai trape/sqai. This is continued by the same case in the rel. clause (Cobet, Mnem. 14, p. 11, rejects h(\n prosede/xonto).

toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois kai\ *)arka/si kai\ *)epidauri/ois: i.e. those troops with which he had set out (see c. 57. 8), with the addition of the Epidaurians. paraggei/las intimates that Agis commanded this division of the army in person. The allies, who had met in the territory of Phlius (see c. 57. 10) and had been joined by the Pellenaeans of Achaea (see ii. 9. 6), the Megarians and the Sicyonians, pressed forward by two different roads into the plain of Argos.

o)/rqion (less usual ending of the fem.) e(te/ran: a road, which, like the one called xaleph/ just before, was also (that is the meaning of e(te/ran, like e(te/ran tosau/thn, vi. 37. 13) steep. To the Boeotians, etc., on the other hand, since they had cavalry with them (see c. 57. 12), the more level road by Nemea had been allotted (ei)/rhto, cf. iv. 77. 8; v. 10. 4; vi. 30. 4; viii. 11. 15). On the various roads from Phlius into the plain of Argos, see Curtius, Pelopon. II. p. 582, note 56. His explanation of o)/rqion e(te/ran as the straight road is, however, very doubtful.
e)ka/qhnto: see App.
e)pi\ sfa=s: i.e. against the main force under Agis.—e)fepo/menoi toi=s i(/ppois xrw=|nto: that they might following them use their horses, i.e. attack the Argives in the rear with their cavalry.
diata/cas: cf. iv. 31. 7.
*sa/minqon: its position is very uncertain; ‘it seems to be the name of a mountain,’ Curtius, Pelopon. <*>. p. 582. See Bursian, <*>. p. 49.
When the Argives are already surrounded by the three divisions of the enemy, two prominent citizens enter into negotiations with Agis.

h(me/ras h)/dh: equiv. to e)pei\(h)/dh)h(me/ra e)ge/neto (cf. iii. 24. 18), not long after the a(/ma e(/w| of c. 58. 12. The gen. followed by h)/dh, as in i. 30. 20, xeimw=nos h)/dh. Cf. c. 17. 7, pro\s to\ e)/ar h)/dh.
au)toi/ : on their side.
w(/sper ei)/rhto au)toi=s: cf. c. 58. 20.

ou)ke/ti kate/labon: sc. kata\ xw/ran o)/ntas. Cf. ii. 56. 20, ou)ke/ti kate/labon e)n th=| *)attikh=| o)/ntas, a)ll' a)nakexwrhko/tas. Everywhere else katalamba/nein in the sense of find, come upon is used with a partic. or an expression denoting place. Cf. i. 59. 2; 61. 6; ii. 18. 17; 56. 20; 94. 19; iii. 69. 5; 115. 6; iv. 70. 7 (a)na/lwton as pf. partic.); 92. 3; 129. 2; vi. 53. 1; 94. 17; vii. 2. 5; 33. 24; viii. 55. 3.— 8. kataba/ntes: sc. oi( *)argei=oi. Change of subj. after a)lla/, as in i. 26. 17.— ta\ e(autw=n dh|ou/mena: cf. c. 58. 24.

e)k tou= pedi/ou: into this plain Agis himself with his Lacedaemonians e)se/bale, c. 58. 23. They were drawn up between the Argive army and Argos, which is about fifteen miles south of Nemea. This position the Argives thought would be for their own advantage (18, a)peilhfe/nai e)n th=| au(tw=n te kai\ pro\s th=| po/lei), for the Lacedaemonians would be harassed from the city, to which special reference is made in c. 60. 26. The expression a)peilhfe/nai (18) is intentionally repeated from 10, not without irony. Each party thought it had caught the other in a trap.
kaqu/perqen: for they had followed the o)/rqios o(do/s of c. 58. 19.

to\ pro\s *neme/as: from the direction of Ne
mea, after they had marched e)pi\ *neme/as.
oi( *)aqhnai=oi : upon their cavalry the Argives had relied; but they did not come until c. 61. 2.
ou)x ou(/tw deino/n: not so very dangerous. See on ii. 11. 24 and c. 104. 8.—e)n kalw=|: under favourable circumstances here and in c. 60. 11. Similarly kalw=s, c. 36. 18.
tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous a)peilhfe/nai: acc. and inf. with e)do/kei in spite of the nom. h( ma/xh, e)do/kei being equiv. to e)no/mizon.
tw=n de\ *)argei/wn du/o a)/ndres: opp. to to\ me\n plh=qos, 16.

tw=n pe/nte strathgw=n : there were in Argos five generals, as in Athens ten; possibly the number at Argos has some such connexion with the pe/nte lo/xoi of c. 72. 21, as that at Athens has with the ten tribes.
pro/cenos: diplomatic representative. This title was an honour bestowed upon foreigners, who then represented the state in their own cities. See on ii. 29. 4, and Schömann, Griech. Alt. <*>. p. 25.
o(/son ou): cf. i. 36. 8, and o(/son ou)/pw, iv. 125. 9.—cunio/ntwn: confligere, also iv. 94. 11; v. 69. 2.—proselqo/nte: see App.
poiei=n ma/xhn: bring on a battle, or “allow it to take place.” See on ii. 86. 22.
*)argei/ous: the two men evidently claim to be representatives of the state.—i)/sas kai\ o(moi/as: as in c. 27. 12.
Agis and the two Argives, without consulting the proper authorities of either state, make a truce for four months, which causes great displeasure in both armies.
ei)po/ntes [tw=n *)argei/wn ]: see App.

au)to/s: for himself alone. See on iv. 49. 5.—ou)de\ au)to\s bouleusa/menos kte(.: and without any deliberation on his own part, further than to communicate the matter to one man. a)ll' h)/, nisi. Cf. c. 80. 6. See on iii. 71. 4.

tw=n e)n te/lei: probably one
of the two ephors who accompanied the king upon military expeditions, as did also, acc. to Arnold, the polemarchs, o(/moioi, and two Pythii. See Gilbert, Griech. Staatsalt, I. p. 60, 64, 80.—custrateuome/nwn: Cl. suggests custrateuome/nw|.
ta\ r(hqe/nta : i.e. what they had offered to do in c. 59. 23 ff.

tw=n a)/llwn cumma/xwn: as in i. 128. 21, in contradistinction to the Lacedaemonians. That he said nothing to his own countrymen has already been stated; but he was silent toward the allies as well. a)/llwn does not imply that the Lacedaemonians are put upon an equal footing with the allies, and should therefore be omitted in English. See on i. 128. 21. (St. and v. Herwerden follow Kr. in rejecting cumma/xwn.)

ei(/ponto me
 w(s h(gei=to dia\ to
 no/mon: “they followed his guidance (i.e. obeyed the order to march away, a)ph/gage to
 strato/n) because of their discipline, because the rules of military subordination compelled them; but,” etc.
e)n ai)ti/a| ei)=xon pollh=|: cf. i. 35. 10, e)n plei/oni ai)ti/a| h(mei=s . . . u(ma=s e(/comen, and 21 below.—kat' a)llh/lous: as in iv. 84. 4.
paratuxo/n: cf. i. 76. 14.
au)tw=n: i.e. tw=n *)argei/wn. See c. 59. § 3.
strato/pedon kte(.: on the mode of expression and the order of words, see on i. 1. 8.—ka/lliston: is esp. explained by the following loga/des a)f) e(ka/stwn.
w)/fqh ma/lista : this (the excellence of the army) was especially noticeable.

e)n *neme/a|: Cl., St., and others take this as referring to c. 59. § 3. But the Argives had at that time descended into the plain of Argos (a)lla\ kataba/ntes, c. 59. 8), and there they were surrounded by the Lacedaemonians and their allies (c. 59. 11 ff.). The valley of Nemea is completely separated from the plain of Argos, the only connexions being by passes neither broad nor low. It is therefore impossible to believe that e)n *neme/a| refers to any part of the plain of Argos. zhtei=tai pw=s, trixh=| diaireqe/ntos tou= tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn strateu/matos ei)s *fliou=nta, kai\ e(no\s mo/nou me/rous th\n e)pi\ *neme/an i)o/ntos, tw=n de\ a)/llwn a)/llais xrhsame/nwn
o(doi=s kai\ ou)damou= summica/ntwn, e)/fh a)qro/ous au)tou\s w)=fqai peri\ *neme/an, Schol., who is evidently puzzled. Philippi, Rhein. Mus. 36, p. 256, says e)n *neme/a| is a gloss. If it really belongs in the text, it must refer to something not made plain in the preceding narrative, prob. something connected with the movements of c. 58.—panstratia=| h)=san: Jowett takes this with *lakedaimo/nioi only, but the Phliasians were certainly present panstratia=| (cf. c. 57. 13). The Epidaurians are mentioned in c. 58. 16, but are omitted here, perhaps, as St. suggests, because only part of their force was present. We must take panstratia=| with all the subjs. This St. reconciles with loga/des a)f' e(ka/stwn by the assumption that panstratia=| means cum universis quas tum instructas habebant copiis, not pandhmei/. There seem to be considerable corruptions in the passage.
kai\ a)/llh| kte(.: for another force, too, if it were added. GMT. 52, 1 and Rem.; 74. 1; 77; H. 932, 2; 934; 937. See App.
a)nexw/roun: they set out upon their way home, impf. Pl. after to\ stra/teuma, as in i. 89. 14 with to\ koino/n, and iii. 80. 1 with dh=mos.

ka)kei=noi: is a repetition of kai\ au)toi/ with marked emphasis.—mh\ a)\n sfi/si pote\ ka/llion parasxo/n: these words are in close connexion, so that the force of the neg. mh/ does not pass beyond parasxo/n. Cf. c. 63. 3. They thought it was the Lacedaemonians who had escaped, since circumstances could never be more favourable for them (the Argives). mh/ is used because it is in the inf. clause, although ou) would be more regular after nomi/zontes. Kr. Spr. 67, 8. a)\n parasxo/n is here equiv. to para/sxoi a)/n. On the acc. abs., cf. paratuxo/n, 11. G. 278, 2; H. 973.
pro\s th=| sfete/ra| po/lei: near Argos. Cf. c. 59. 11 and 19.

meta\...cumma/xwn : the Mantineans and Eleans. See c. 58. 4 f.— a)
 gi/gnesqai: the pres. inf., corresponding to the impf. ind. of dir. disc. (o( a)gw
 a)
 e)gi/gneto), represents the Argives as thinking, “we should have fought under these favourable circumstances.”

e)n tw=| *xara/drw|: ‘about the
northeast part of the city wall extended, like a natural moat, the gorge of the Charadrus, in the wide bed of which generals returning from the field were tried before they entered the city.’ Curtius, Pelopon. H. p. 363.— 29. stratei/as: a necessary correction of the reading of most Mss. stratia=s.
After the arrival of troops from Athens, the Argives are persuaded by their allies to break the truce. Accordingly their united forces besiege Orchomenus, in Arcadia, which surrenders to them.
triakosi/wn: Diod., xii. 79. 1, says two hundred.—*la/xhs kai\ *niko/stratos: are both freq. mentioned in the earlier course of the war (iii. 75. 15; 86. 2; 115. 7; iv. 53. 5; 119. 10).
o(/mws: is to be explained by assuming that a concessive sent., “although they were dissatisfied with the truce,” is understood. Cf. iii. 28. 13; 80. 4.

xrhmati/sai: cf. c. 5. 2; i. 87. 17.—pri
 h)/: as elsewhere in Thuc. pri
 dh/ (iii. 29. 5; vii. 71. 26; Haase, followed by St., writes pri
 dh/ here) or the simple pri/n (see on i. 51. 5) with the aor. indic. (Perhaps Thuc. wrote pri
 oi( *mantinh=s.)
paro/ntos: see App.
tau=ta: see App.

kai\ ge/nointo, kai\ nu=n a(/ptesqai xrh=nai: kai/ is used before ge/nointo, as if some similar const. (as kai\ nu=n e)/ti me/noien) were to follow (see on iii. 67. 24), instead of the inf. The present duty of the Argives is emphasized by nu=n as opp. to the past time expressed by ge/nointo.
sfei=s : is nom. referring to the subj. of the main verb. G. 138, N. 8; H. 940 b.

pei/santes...e)xw/roun pa/ntes : the subj. is at first only the Athenians (pei/santes can refer only to them), but is enlarged until it includes pa/ntes plh\n *)argei/wn. On similar changes of subj. (though usually contracting rather than expanding its content),
see on i. 18. 21; 49. 14, and c. 64. 12. —e)k tw=n lo/gwn: cf. vii. 48. 23, e)k tou/twn au)tou\s pei/sesqai, and viii. 47. 5, pei=sai d) a)\n e)no/mize ma/lista e)k tou= toiou/tou.
to\n *)arkadiko/n : to distinguish it from the *boiw/tios of iii. 87. 11.
o(/mws: const. with u(pelei/ponto.—kai\ peisqe/ntes: “although the speech of the Athenians (i.e. of Alcibiades) had not failed to convince them.”
proskaqezo/menoi: const. with acc. also in i. 26. 19; 61. 8.
pa/ntes: here the Argives also are included.
prosgene/sqai sfi/si: cf. c. 32. 10.
kai\ o(/mhroi au)to/qi: the inorganic connexion of these words with the preceding boulo/menoi a)/llws te prosgene/sqai sfi/si makes them only more prominent: “and besides, there were,” etc.
kei/menoi: i.e. katakei/menoi, as pf, pass. partic. of kate/qento, 23. Cf. vi. 61. 16, o(mh/rous tou\s e)n tai=s nh/sois keime/nous.

kai\...mh\ proapo/lwntai : is, like th/n te tou= tei/xous a)sqe/neian kai\ tou= stratou= to\ plh=qos, obj. of dei/santes. kai/ introduces mh\ a)po/lwntai; the explanatory w(s ou)dei\s au)toi=s e)boh/qei is, then, a parenthesis.—cune/bhsan w(/ste: cf. iv. 46. 8.
*mantineu=si: the Mantineans, as the most powerful of the Arcadian allies, are given the charge of these Arcadian hostages.
The allies decide to attack Tegea, whereupon the Eleans return home in anger because their proposal to attack Lepreum had been rejected.
e)f' o(/ ti xrh\ i)e/nai: is the regular periphrasis for the deliberative subj. in dependent clauses. Cf. i. 40. 20; 91. 4; ii. 4. 10; iii. 11. 18; 53. 9; iv. 34. 25; 125. 5.
e)ke/leuon: sc. i)e/nai. So also in 6, with e)yhfi/santo.
[*tegea] tw=n : see App.
e)nedi/dosan: impf. expressing attempted action. So also in iv. 76. 13.—ta\ pra/gmata: cf. ii. 65. 43, ta\ pra/gmata e)ndido/nai.
The Lacedaemonians are very angry with Agis, and appoint ten Spartans to be his advisers.
*lakedaimo/nioi de/ kte(.: the narrative of c. 60. § 4 is resumed. The indignation which had already been expressed on the march (c. 60. 21) broke out with more violence e)peidh\ a)nexw/rhsan.

e)n mega/lh| ai)ti/a| ei)=xon : is repeated from c. 60. 10 and 21.— 4. w(s ou)/pw pro/teron au)toi\ e)no/mizon: sc. parasxei=n. “When such an opportunity was offered as they, for their part, thought had never been offered before.” Cf. c. 60. 25. ou)/pw pro/teron occurs again in 13 and c. 64. 6. This repetition may be due to a lack of careful revision by the author. See App.— 5. labei=n: a)nti\ tou= sullabei=n, a)qroi/zein, Schol. Cf. c. 102. 2, koinote/ras ta\s tu/xas lamba/nonta; vi. 86. 13, o(/tan kairo\n la/bwsin.
peri\ *)orxomenou= h)gge/lleto e(alwke/nai: a loose const. for *)orxo/menos h)gge/lleto e(alwkw/s. See Kühn. 600, 3 b.
para\ to\n tro/pon to\n e(autw=n : their usual mode of conduct is described in i. 132. 27, mh\ taxei=s ei)=nai peri\ a)ndro\s *spartia/tou kte(.
de/ka muria/si draxmw=n : if these are Aeginetan drachmae, as is likely (see c. 47. 39), the sum amounts to about $24,840.
parh|tei=to: deprecabatur. Cf. Plat. Rep. iii. 387 b; Dem. XXI. 58, paraith/somai u(ma=s mhde\n a)xqesqh=nai/ moi.

r(u/sesqai : a)polu/sein, Schol. The word is seldom found elsewhere in this sense (but cf. Soph. O. T. 313), at least in Attic prose; but St.'s remark that this is prob. an expression of Agis, not of Thuc., makes any emendation unnecessary. In c. 75. 11 Thuc. uses a)polu/esqai in the same
sense.—strateusa/menos: see App.— h)/: i.e. ei) de\ mh/. Cf. i. 78. 13; 140. 8, bohqei=n, h)\ mhde\ katorqou=ntas th=s cune/sews metapoiei=sqai. See Kr. Spr. § 69, 29, 1.—to/te: then, after he had tried to make good his fault. Cf. Dem. IV. I, ei) de\ mh/, to/t' a)\n au)to\s e)peirw/mhn.

e)pe/sxon: see on c. 46. 5; ii. 76. 4.—no/mon de\ e)/qento kte(.: the wording of the new law is not given, but merely the application of it to King Agis. e)n tw=| paro/nti, for the present, may imply that the law was passed for this special case, and was intended to apply only to Agis. But if Arist., Pol. ii. 9. 30, e)ce/pempon sumpresbeuta/s, refers to this law, it must have been a general one.

de/ka ga\r cumbou/lous: a council of ten men was assigned to him, without whose consent or company he could not lead an army from the city. In this way his actions as general were under constant supervision. Advisers had accompanied Spartan admirals before (see ii. 85. 1; iii. 69. 7; 76. 6), but had never been forced upon an adult king in command of the army. Pleistoanax was accompanied by one or more on account of his youth. See Plut. Per. 22. See on ii. 85, 1, and Herbst, Jahrbb. 1858, p. 682 ff.

ei)=nai: the inf. in rel. clauses occurs occasionally, as here, without a preceding inf. when provisions of a law are quoted. GMT. 92, 2, N. 3 (b); H. 957 a.— a)pa/gein: is ordinarily used of the withdrawal of troops from foreign territory. Here it seems to show the strict nature of the new law. He was not allowed to lead troops away from the city. In other words, his power as general was entirely under the control of his advisers, whose authority did not cease with the e)ca/gein but extended to the a)pa/gein (and all subsequent action) after the army had left the city. It is then not necessary to follow Haase, Lucubr. Thuc. p. 88 ff., and read e)k th=s polemi/as for e)k th=s po/lews. Besides, as St. observes, if Thuc. had written e)k th=s polemi/as, we should expect th\n stratia/n with the art.
The Lacedaemonians lead out their whole force to the support of Tegea. They invade the territory of Mantinea after having summoned their allies to meet them there.
para\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn: opp. to the hostile faction mentioned in c. 62. 8.

o(/son ou)k: with pf. or plpf. already almost; so in iv. 69. 15; vii. 6. 4.
The pf. ind. (like the preceding fut. inds.) is of course retained in the indir. disc. after the pres. a)fiknei=tai a)ggeli/a. GMT. 70, 1; H. 932, 1.— boh/qeia tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn gi/gnetai: equiv. to oi( *lakedaimo/nioi poiou=ntai boh/qeian.
oi(/a ou)/pw pro/teron : sc. e)ge/neto. They exerted themselves to the utmost, for the question whether Sparta or Argos should be leader in Peloponnesus was to be decided.

*)ore/sqeion: also called *)oresqa/sion by Paus. viii. 27. 3. Thuc. calls the territory belonging to it *)oresqi/s in iv. 134. 4.—*mainali/as: the whole mountainous district around the Maenalus range. See Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 311 f.
proei=pon: cf. c. 30. 31.—kata\ po/das au(tw=n: close upon their heels. See on iii. 98. 11; iv. 126. 38; viii. 17. 15.
au)toi\ pa/ntes, tw=| loipw=| strateu/mati a)fiknou=ntai: a change in the content of the subj. the reverse of that in c. 61. § 3.

a)p' *)arka/dwn: shows that the summons of 8 had been obeyed. The Areadian allies came at the proper time; on the other hand pe/mpousi kai\ . . . *lokrou/s, with whom the old alliance of ii. 9. 8 still existed.

toi=s me/n: the more distant allies just mentioned.—e)c o)li/gou e)gi/gneto: it (with an indefinite subj. supplied from what precedes) came upon them suddenly. e)c o)li/gou is similarly used in ii. 11. 17; 61. 11; iv. 108. 32.—mh\ a)qro/ois kte(.: unless in a body, and after having waited for one another (Arnold). mh/ shows that the expression is hypothetical. G. 283, 4; H. 1025.

th\n polemi/an: as in i. 142. 7; ii. 11. 20; iii. 58. 24. This refers not only to Argolis, but also to the territory of Orchomenus, which was in the possession of the Argive alliance since the events of c. 61. § 5. This whole region cune/klh|e dia\ me/sou, i.e. it closed up the communication (for those wishing to reach Mantinea from the north) by lying just in the
way of it. cugklh/|ein is similarly used in c. 72. 14, kata\ to\ dia/kenon kai\ ou) cugklhsqe/n.
h)pei/gonto : sc. dielqei=n.

e)se/balon: from the south, the side toward Tegea, where the site of the temple of Hercules must be sought (acc. to Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 243, ‘not far from the plain of Alcimedon by the heights of Capsa’).
The hostile armies approach one another, but the Lacedaemonians suddenly retreat. After some delay the Argives follow them.

xwri/on e)rumno\n kai\ duspro/sodon: apparently the southern part of the hill called Alesium, which was a point of considerable strategic importance for Mantinea. See Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 241. It is therefore called (6) xwri/on kartero/n.
tw=n presbute/rwn tis: perhaps one of the ten cu/mbouloi of c. 63. 15.

kako\n kakw=| i)a=sqai: proverbial. So Hdt.iii. 53. 15, mh\ tw=| kakw=| to\ kako\n i)w=. Cf. Soph. Aj. 362; Plat. Prot. 340 d. It refers to Agis's words in c. 63. 10 f.—e)paiti/ou: which had caused him to be blamed. Cf. c. 60. 10; 63. 2. But in vi. 61. 4 we find the pers. use of e)pai/tios.
boulome/nhn : the partic. with dhlou=n is used also in i. 21. 12; ii. 50. 4; with dhlou=sqai in i. 11. 17. The man called to Agis, pointing out (dhlw=n) that his eagerness wished, etc. See App.

ei)/te kai/, ei)/te kai/: the adv. kai/ adds liveliness and force to the expression, as in vi. 60. 11 f. Kühn. 541, 2, N. 2. —to\ e)pibo/hma: (cf. e)pebo/hsen, 5) occurs nowhere else in Thuc. Poll., vi. 208, objects to it as sklhro/n, but Dio C. uses it freq.

h)\ kata\ to\ au)to/: Kr. explains: “than in accordance with the line of action he had begun.” See App.—do/can: acc. abs. (aor. partic.), as in viii. 79. 2; 93. 7. The partic. is used in a causal sense, and the whole expression au)tw=| . . . do/can is parallel to dia\ to\ e)pibo/hma, giving a second reason for his sudden
retreat.—e)cai/fnhs: to be const. with what follows, and therefore separated by a comma (with Cl.) from what precedes. Not that his decision was sudden, but that he executed it suddenly is important. Hence below, 20, the astonishment of the enemy at the ai)fni/dios a)naxw/rhsis. Moreover kata\ ta/xos indicates the rapidity of the march.

pro\s th\n *tegea=tin: to the border of the territory of Tegea.—to\ u(/dwr: not the brook Ophis, but a stream which flows northward from the Tegean territory. See Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 235; Baedeker, Griechenland, p. 274.—e)ce/trepen: impf., he set about turning, etc. This task naturally required some time. See 18 f.
o(pote/rwse a)\n e)spi/pth|: since it had no sufficient outlet, and tended to flood the neighbouring land.

tou\s a)po\ tou= lo/fou: acc. to the wellknown proleptie use for tou\s e)pi\ tou= lo/fou (i.e. the xwri/on e)rumno\n kai\ duspro/sodon of 2). G. 191, N. 6; H. 788. Const. as obj. with the inf. katabiba/sai, with which bohqou=ntas kte(. is to be connected as a pred. adj.: “he wished to make the troops on the hill come down and try to stop the turning aside of the water (bohqou=ntas e)pi\ th\n tou= u(/datos e)ktroph/n), as soon as they heard of it, and fight on the plain.” tou\s *)argei/ous kai\ tou\s cumma/xous is rightly struck out by St., v. Herwerden, and Cl. as a useless gloss.

e)c o)li/gou: this refers apparently to the near approach me/xri li/qou kai\ a)konti/ou bolh=s (4), i.e. it is to be taken in a local sense. ai)fnidi/w| refers to the unexpectedness of the withdrawal. Cf. e)cai/fnhs, 10. See App.
ou)k ei)=xon kte(.: on the use of ou)k e)/xein with deliberative subjv., see on ii. 52. 11.

a)pe/kruyan: e(autou\s dhlono/ti. a)fanei=s e)ge/nonto. i)di/ws de\ e)pi\ tw=n ploi+zome/nwn kai\ ou)ke/ti o(rwme/nwn le/getai o(/ti a)pe/kruyan, Schol. Of this rare use only two examples are cited; one from Plat. Prot. p. 338 a, feu/gein ei)s to\ pe/lagos tw=n lo/gwn a)pokru/yanta gh=n, and one from Luc. Ver. Hist. ii. 38, e)feu/gomen . . . e)pei\ d' a)pe/kruyan (got out of sight of) au)tou/s. Acc. to these examples, we should supply au)tou/s
rather than with the Schol. e(autou/s.— sfei=s: is here opp. to e)kei=noi and oi( me/n, and is equiv. to an emphatic au)toi/. This is rare in dir. disc.

au)=qis e)n ai)ti/a| ei)=xon: cf. c. 60. 23.— kalw=s lhfqe/ntas: “when they had caught them so finely.” Used of the favourable opportunity, as in c. 36. 18, kalw=s sfi/si fi/lion gene/sqai.—to/ te pro/teron a)feqh=nai: see c. 59. § 4; 60. § 5. The inf. depends upon the idea of speaking implied in e)n ai)ti/a| ei)=xon (i.e. it is the inf. of indir. disc.), and refers to past time. They preferred the charge that the Lacedaemonians had been let off. Cf. vii. 81. 3, e)n ai)ti/a| to\n *gu/lippon ei)=xon e(ko/nta a)fei=nai tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.

kai\ nu=n o(/ti : here introduces the continuation of the indir. disc., but the change from the inf. to o(/ti (which is far less usual than the change from o(/ti to the inf.) gives the following words somewhat the effect of dir. disc. Kr. says ‘o(/ti here means because.’ If Kr. were right, we should have here an example of a causal sent. after a secondary tense and implying that the cause is assigned by other persons than the writer in which the pres. ind. is retained. It would be difficult to find other examples of this const. See GMT. 81, 2, Rem.
kaq' h(suxi/an: at their leisure; very ironical, esp. with prodi/dontai.
e)qorubh/qhsan me\n to\ parauti/ka: a higher degree of a)porei=n. For a moment they lost their self-control (or, as we say, lost their heads) on account of the violence of the reproaches.
Next day the two armies are drawn up opposite one another in the plain. The organization of the Lacedaemonian army appears in all its excellence.

oi(/ te *)argei=oi kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi: the copula te does not connect the two substs., but stands opp. to te in oi(/ te *lakedaimo/nioi. Thus a paratactical opposition of the two members of the sent. is brought about; on the one hand . . . on the other hand (cf. i. 8. 14 f.; 26. 8 f.; 57. 3 f.; ii. 22. 3 ff.; 64. 28 f., etc.). If w(s were inserted before o(rw=si (Kr. and Meineke), it would interfere with the peculiarly Thucydidean structure of the sent.: “on the one hand, the Argives drew themselves up for battle; on the other, the Lacedaemonians, as they are returning to their former position,
see the enemy already drawn up in battle array and brought down from the hill.” The order of these last words is the reverse of the order of the events. See on i. 90. 4. Cl. suggests that o)/ntas may have been lost before pa/ntas. Since the Lacedaemonians had now attained their object of drawing the enemy down into the plain as expressed in c. 65. 14 ff., it seems strange that they should be surprised at finding them there, except in so far as they may have expected them to wait a little longer. What follows is evidently told by Thuc. as a peculiarly good example of their excellent military organization, and this idea must be contained in the next sent., ma/lista dh\ kte(., since the continuation with the words dia\ braxei/as ga/r evidently gives a reason for what immediately precedes. Yet this necessary connexion is certainly not clearly expressed in the text. For the various emendations proposed, see App.
h)\n peritu/xwsin: toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois, Schol.
pro\s to\ *(hra/kleion: cf. c. 64. 22.

di) o)li/gou: at a short distance. dia/, which is here used in a local sense, is used in a temporal sense in 7, dia\ braxei/as mellh/sews, after a short hesitation, i.e. after the interval of a short delay.
e)s o(\ e)me/mnhnto: as far back as they remembered; meta\ th\n tw=n a)nqrw/pwn mnh/nhn, Schol.
h( paraskeuh\ au)toi=s e)gi/gneto: i.e. th\n paraskeuh\n e)poiou=nto.
u(po\ spoudh=s : used also in iii. 33. 12; viii. 107. 1. Elsewhere kata\ spoudh/n and dia\ spoudh=s.
a)/rxetai: pass. as in ii. 41. 11; iii. 46. 21.
polema/rxois kte(.: on the Spartan military organization, see Hermann, Griech. Staatsalt. § 29; Schoemann, Antiq. of Greece, I. p. 279 ff.; Gilbert, Griech. Staatsalt. I. p. 75 f.; 49 f.

paragge/lseis: the special orders for the execution of de/on of 12. para/ggelsis is an order not given by the trumpet but passed along the
ranks in such a way as not to attract the attention of the enemy. See Kr. on Xen. Anab. iv. 1. 5.
taxei=ai e)pe/rxontai: they reach their destination quickly. Cf. iii. 29. 4, sxolai=oi komisqe/ntes. Cobet's proposal, perie/rxontai, is less appropriate with taxei=ai used adv.

pa=n...to\ strato/pedon...a)/rxontes a)rxo/ntwn ei)si/ : “nearly the whole army consists of officers who in turn have officers under them.” (ei)si/ is pl. agreeing with the pred. subst.) Further details are given in c. 68. § 3, from which it appears that plh\n o)li/gou, referring to those who have no one under them, is not to be taken too literally.
to\ e)pimele\s tou= drwme/nou: the use of the neut. adj. or partie. for the corresponding abstract subst. is very common in Thuc. See on i. 36. 4.
The disposition of the troops on both sides.

to/te de/: the narrative is resumed after the digression of c. 66. § 3 f.— 2. ke/ras eu)w/numon: stands as pred. with kaqi/stanto: as the left wing. The dat. au)toi=s is acc. to the usage of c. 44. 6; 57. 2.—*skiri=tai: lo/xos *lakwniko\s ou(/tw lego/menos, Schol. The Sciritae inhabited the rough hilly country toward the borders of the Tegean territory (Curtius, Pelopon. H. p. 217). On their precedence in the Lacedaemonian army, cf. Xen. Cyr. iv. 2. 1; Rep. Lac. 12. 3; 13. 6. This is the only passage which records that the position on the left wing was their special privilege (e)pi\ sfw=n au)tw=n for themselves alone; see on ii. 63. 10).— 4. oi( e)pi\ *qra/|khs *brasi/deioi: cf. c. 35. 21. This had apparently become the usual designation for the soldiers who had served in Thrace with Brasidas, though the expression in c. 34. 1, tw=n a)po\ *qra/|khs meta\ *brasi/dou e)celqo/ntwn stratiwtw=n was at this time more accurate, for e)pi/ cannot properly be used of them after their return to Greece. Still, it seems that this prep. had become part of their designation, so that a change to a)po/ (Haase followed by v. Herwerden and St.) or e)k (Cobet, Mnem. 14, p. 11) is not advisable.
neodamw/deis: see on c. 34. 6.

par' au)tou/s: no less admissible than par' au)toi=s, as in 4. Cf. ii. 2. 28; ti/qesqai par' au(tou\s ta\ o(/pla; vi. 67. 17. But it is not necessary to change au)toi=s above to au)tou/s (St. and Badham).

*)arka/dwn *(hraih=s:
part. gen. as in i. 27. 11, *palh=s *kefallh/nwn. The men of Heraea, which was situated in the valley of the Alpheus between the confined mountain territory of Arcadia and the open country of the Elean coast. Curtius, Pelopon. I. p. 363 f. It had attained importance through the union of nine communities at the instance of King Cleombrotus (Strab. viii. 3. 2); hence, probably, the honourable position of the Heraeans beside the Lacedaemonians.—*maina/lioi: from the Areadian district Maenalia. Cf. c. 64. 7.
oi( d' e)nanti/oi: the nom. of the whole with the parts in the same case. Cf. i. 89. 18; ii. 65. 3; iii. 32. 2. G. 137. N. 2; H. 624 d.

to\ e)/rgon: the action. Cf. i. 105. 24; ii. 89. 42; iv. 25. 9.— 13. *)arka/dwn: from Arcadia, as in c. 64. 7.—*)argei/wn oi( xi/lioi loga/des kte(.: this institution is further described by Diod. Sic. xii. 75. 77: a)polu/santes au)tou\s kai\ th=s a)/llhs leitourgi/as kai\ trofa\s dhmosi/as xorhgou=ntes prose/tacan gumna/zesqai sunexei=s mele/tas. Arist. Pol. v. 4. p. 1304 tells of its political results.
e)k pollou=: to be explained with the help of Diod.'s sunexei=s mele/tai: for a long time, i.e. from their youth up. Cf. c. 69. 19.
*klewnai=oi kai\ *)ornea=tai: Cleonae and Orneae were on the northern border of Argolis, toward Phlius and Corinth. As allies of Argos they were among the cu/mmaxoi w(=n a)/rxousi. Cf. c. 47. 3.
The difficulty of ascertaining with accuracy the numbers of either army.
ta/cis: this refers to the arrangement, paraskeuh/ to the armament (cf. c. 67. 13 and 18) of the troops.— h(/de: the more usual word to refer to what precedes is au(/th, as in ii. 9. 22.
mei=zon e)fa/nh: was evidently larger.

ou)k a)\n e)duna/mhn: I could not (even if I were trying to do so)
write the number accurately. Kr. supplies ei) e)pexei/roun, Poppo and Böhme ei) e)boulo/mhn. Either answers the purpose of introducing a prot. for a)\n e)duna/mhn. See App.
dia\ th=s politei/as to\ krupto/n: dia\ to\ e)/qos ei)=nai *lakedaimoni/ois pa/nta kru/fa pra/ttein, Schol. The order of words as in i. 32. 8, meta\ th=s cummaxi/as th=s ai)th/sews.
[plh/qh ]: see App.

lo/xoi me
 ga kte(.: the computation of Thuc., which is undoubtedly correct as applied to the army engaged in the battle of Mantinea, though Xen. Rep. Lac. 11. 4 makes a different statement, is correctly summed up by the Schol.: e)/xei e(/kastos lo/xos penthkostu/as te/ssaras, kai\ gi/nontai tw=n e(pta\ lo/xwn ei)/kosi o)ktw/, e)/xei e(ka/sth penthkostu\s e)nwmoti/as te/ssaras, kai\ gi/nontai tw=n ei)/kosi o)ktw\ penthkostu/wn e)nwmoti/ai e(kato
 dw/deka. e)/xei e(ka/sth e)nwmoti/a a)/ndras tria/konta du/o (i.e. 4 x 8, because four men stood in the first rank of each enomoty, and they were drawn up as a rule, e)pi\ pa=n, eight deep), w(/ste gi/nesqai to
 pa/nta strato
 trisxili/ous pentakosi/ous o)gdoh/konta te/ssaras (7 x 4 x 4 x 4 x 8 = 3584). Thuc. himself gives only the sum of the front rank of the army when drawn up: 7 (lo/xoi) x 4 (penthkostu/es) x 4 (e)nwmoti/ai) x 4 (a)/ndres e)n tw=| prw/tw| zugw=|) = 448. This multiplied by 8 for the depth of the array gives likewise 3584, and with the 600 Sciritae, makes the whole army of the Lacedaemonians 4184. See Rüstow and Koechly, Gesch. d. gr. Kriegswesens, p. 90 ff.; Gilbert, Griechische Staatsalt. I. p. 73 ff.

e)pi\ de\ ba/qos...kate/sthsan e)pi\ o)ktw/ : because it seemed strange that the depth of the lochi should be left to the discretion of the lochagi, Dobree struck out the words a)ll' w(s loxago\s e(/kastos e)bou/leto, and went so far as to propose the omission of the whole passage, th=s te e)nwmoti/as . . . e)bou/leto. Others also, and esp. Grote, find the passage troublesome. If we take the enomoty at 32 men (with the Schol.) and assume (with Thuc.) that four men stood in the front rank, then the arrangement of the remaining 28 men may have varied somewhat, so as to cause a variation in the depth of the column. Still complete certainty is hardly to be obtained in this matter.

h( prw/th ta/cis: the
front rank, the meaning being here further determined by para\ a(/pan, all along the line.
The leaders encourage their troops by suitable addresses.
cunie/nai e)/mellon: cf. c. 59. 22; iv. 94. 10.
kai\ a(/ma: and besides, stands opp. to and in close connexion with the preceding te, adding emphasis to the second clause. a(/ma is not to be const. with a)rxh=s kai\ doulei/as.

th\n me/n : toute/sti th\n a)rxh/n, Schol.—mh/: const. with a)faireqh=nai: not to lose. peirasame/nois is affirmative: after they had made a trial of it. (This relation is reversed in ii. 44. 9, w(=n a)/ntis mh\ peirasa/menos a)gaqw=n steri/skhtai.) For the truth of the statement, see c. 29. 3 ff.

a)faireqh=nai, peira=sqai: the infs. denote the end or purpose of h( ma/xh e)/stai, as in ii. 89. 45, o( de\ a)gw
 me/gas u(mi=n, h)\ katalu=sai th
 e)lpi/da h)\ katasth=sai to
 fo/bon, the infs. express the purpose of o( a)gw/n. GMT. 97; H. 951.—th=s de/: sc. th=s doulei/as, their former subjection to the supremacy of Sparta, for this is the meaning of doulei/a.—*)argei/ois de/: sc. paraine/seis e)gi/gnonto. The object of the struggle is introduced as above by the prep. u(pe/r, and the end to be attained is expressed by the infs. mh\ a)ne/xesqai and kai\ a(/ma a)mu/nasqai.

th=s te palaia=s h(gemoni/as : this refers to the earliest times and the rule of Atridae, while th=s e)n *peloponnh/sw| i)somoiri/as refers to the later relation to Sparta (in the times before the Persian war; see c. 41. 15), which is thus expressed by Hdt.vii. 149. 17, oi( *)argei=oi/ fasi ou)k a)nasxe/sqai tw=n *spartihte/wn th\n pleoneci/hn. The opposition of these two relations is expressed by te, kai/.

dia\ panto/s : for ever. See on i. 38. 2.—steriskome/nous: supplementary partic. with a)ne/xesqai. GMT. 112, 1; H. 983. Cf. i. 77. 6, deino/tera tou/twn pa/sxontes h)nei/xonto; ii. 74. 2, h)nei/xonto kai\ gh=n temnome/nhn; vi. 16. 20.
kai\ a(/ma: as in 4.

a)mu/nasqai: aor., refers to the particular battle before them.—ei)=nai: the inf. depends, as does also the clause o(/ti . . . e(/cousi, upon the idea of indir. dise. introduced by paraine/seis e)gignonto.

e)n *peloponnh/sw| : is em
phatic: “on their own ground.” If the Lacedaemonians could be defeated there, the Athenians need never fear an attack from them in Attica, either by e)sbolai/ or e)piteixismo/s. This confident expectation is expressed here, as in iv. 95. 6, by the strongest form of the neg. fut. ou) mh/ pote with the aor. subjv. GMT. 89, 1; H. 1032. This clause is dependent upon o(/ti in 12.

kaq' e(ka/stous: refers to the various parts of the Lacedaemonian army as Herbst, Jahrbb. 1858, p. 712, has shown, who says, ‘for the Spartans regarded an army composed of Peloponnesian contingents as their own, as Lacedaemonian.’ Cf. ii. 39. 11. Opp. to the various contingents (kaq' e)ka/stous) stand the Lacedaemonians themselves (e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s). th\n parake/leusin e)poiou=nto belongs with both. But with kaq' e(ka/stous this conveys only the general notion of exhortation, while for the Lacedaemonians proper the characteristic manner of the exhortation is described. Among themselves with (the aid of) war-songs they made their exhortation of the memory (i.e. by awakening the memory) of those things which they knew. meta\ tw=n polemikw=n no/mwn: no/mous polemikou\s le/gei ta\ a)/|smata a(/per h)=|don oi( *lakedaimo/nioi me/llontes ma/xesqai, Schol. They sang the warsongs which arouse the courage. Cf. the fragments of Tyrt., Bergk, Poet. Lyr. Gr. II. p. 8 ff. no/mos is used in this sense by Plat. Legg. iii. 700 b See App.

e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s w(=n h)pi/stanto th\n parake/leusin th=s mnh/mhs e)poiou=nto , kte(.: parekeleu/onto a)llh/lois memnh=sqai w(=n memaqh/kesan kai\ h)pi/stanto, Schol. This consciousness, which they were to renew in their memory, is expressed in ei)do/tes . . . parai/nesin.
a)gaqoi=s ou)=sin : see App.
Both armies march into battle, the Lacedaemonians advancing to the music of flutes.

A. Gellius, Noct. Att. i. 11. 5 quotes this chap. with the remark: auctor historiae graecae grauissimus Thucydides Lacedaemonios summos bellatores non cornuum tubarumue signis, sed tibiarum modulis in proeliis esse usos refert.
h( cu/nodos h)=n, *)argei=oi me\n xwrou=ntes *lakedaimo/nioi de/: a decided anacoluthon, h( cu/nodos h)=n being treated as if it were cunh=lqon. See on ii. 53. 13.

o)rgh=|: summa alacritate
(Cl.). Cf. ii. 85. 9; vii. 68. 2.

u(po\ au)lhtw=n pollw=n no/mw| e)gkaqestw/twn: to the sound of many flute-players placed among them according to custom. This custom is freq. mentioned. Cf. Hdt.i. 17. 5 f., u(po\ suri/ggwn; Cie. Tuse. ii. 16. 37, Spartiatarum, quorum procedit mora ad tibiam; Plut. Lyc. 22, r(uqmw=| pro\s to\n au)lo\n e)mbaino/ntwn. See also Milton, Paradise Lost, i. 549 ff. See App.—e)gkaqestw/twn: i.e. kaqestw/twn e)n au)toi=s, referring to their position in the ranks: inter exercitum positi, Gellius.
ou) tou= qei/ou xa/rin: non prorsus ex aliquo ritu religionum neque rei diuinae gratia, Gellius.
proe/lqoien: see App.
filei=: solent. See on i. 78. 5.
poiei=n: almost in the sense of pa/sxein. So also in c. 71. 2.
Agis tries to extend his left wing and strengthen it by a detachment from his right.
cunio/ntwn: gen. abs. without a subst. Cf. c. 17. 11; i. 2. 9.

ta\ strato/peda poiei= me/n kte(.: the explanation of toio/nde, which begins with dei/sas de\ *)=agis, 14, is preceded by some observations on the disposition of all armies (const. kai\ a(/panta with ta\ strato/peda) before a battle. The application of these remarks to this particular battle explains the purpose of the movement undertaken by Agis. poiei= is used like poiei=n in c. 70. 7. tou=to, explaining what follows, is elsewhere in Thuc. followed by ga/r. See App.— 3. e)n tai=s cuno/dois: i.e. e)n tw=| cunie/nai: not in the battle itself, but in the advance to attack.—ma=llon e)cwqei=tai: i.e. beyond their original position, more toward the right. e)cwqei=tai, e)ktei/netai, Schol.

perii/sxousi: like perie/sxon, 12; outflank, extend further. Cf. iii. 107. 16, mei=zon ga\r e)ge/neto kai\ perie/sxe to\ tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn strato/pedon.—kata\ to\...eu)w/numon: opposite their opponents' left wing. See on i. 33. 22, kat) au)tou/s; 48. 12.
prosste/llein : see App.

eu)skepasto/taton: prob. neut., acc. to the usage of Thuc. Cf. i. 10. 1; 138. 27; iii. 37. 2; iv. 62. 3; 76. 15; vi. 39. 1. So far as the form is
concerned, it might also be fem. See on iii. 89. 21; 101. 9.—h(gei=tai th=s ai)ti/as: “is originally responsible” (Jowett).
o( prwtosta/ths: the man at the extreme right of the front rank. Cf. Poll. i. 127.
e)calla/sse...gu/mnwsin : mh\ kata\ do/ru tou= e)nanti/ou e)/xein ta\ gumna\ tou= sw/matos, toute/sti ta\ decia/, Schol. e)calla/ssein with gen., as here, means withdraw from.

kai\ to/te: and in this case. The special case illustrates the preceding general statements. One would expect here to/te de\ kai\ oi( *mantinh=s to correspond to ta\ strato/peda poiei= me\n kai\ a(/panta tau=ta in 2, but the clause with de/ corresponding to me/n of 2 has been so long deferred that it is at last omitted entirely, and a new sent. is begun.—oi( *mantinh=s...tw=n *)aqhnai/wn : cf. c. 67.

e)sh/mhnen: shmai/nein (cf. c. 10. 13; ii. 84. 5; vii. 50. 26) and paragge/llein (cf. c. 10. 14; 73. 11) are used esp. of military orders.—e)pecagago/ntas: advancing their line.—a)po\ sfw=n: from themselves, i.e. from their main body. Agis said “from us” (a)f' h(mw=n), which becomes in indir. disc. a)po\ sfw=n.—e)cisw=sai: is intrans. Cf. vi. 87. 23. They were to move to the left, that they might become equal to the Mantineans who form the enemy's right wing, i.e. in order to avoid being outflanked.
to\ dia/kenon tou=to: the gap formed by advancing the Sciritae and the Brasidean contingent toward the left.
tw=n polema/rxwn: is part. gen., depending immediately upon the proper names. Cf. i. 24. 5; 126. 7.

*)aristoklei=: perhaps the brother of King Pleistoanax, mentioned in c. 16. 23, if the reading a)delfou= is correct.—e)sbalo/ntas: i.e. throwing themselves into the space made vacant by the movement of the Sciritae and Brasideans toward the left.
plhrw=sai: sc. to\ dia/kenon.—periousi/an: cf. 14, o(/sw| mei=zon to\ stra/teuma ei)=xon.

to\ kata\ tou\s *mantine/as : the part opposed
to the Mantineans, i.e. the left wing, which was formed by the Sciritae. See on 4.—bebaio/teron teta/cesqai: e)n a)sfalei/a| e)/sesqai, w(s a)\n mh\ duna/menon kuklwqh=nai, Schol.
This order is disobeyed, consequently the left wing is defeated, but the centre and right wing gain a decisive victory.

cune/bh kte(.: the two clauses to/n te *)aristokle/a . . . mh\ qelh=sai parelqei=n and kai\ tou\s polemi/ous fqa/sai th=| prosmi/cei depend upon cune/bh. Between these is inserted a third clause, a)lla\ kai\ . . . malakisqh=nai, which is really parenthetical, but is formally dependent upon cune/bh because it is attracted by its surroundings into the acc. and inf. See on c. 48. 3. St. would like to read e)/feugon and do/cantes, but it is more likely that Thuc. employed this peculiar form of attraction than that it crept in as a later corruption.—a(/te: const. with paraggei/lanti, for a(/te is always joined with parties. in Thuc. Cf. iv. 94. 7; 130. 25; vii. 44. 30; 58. 20; 85. 15; viii. 52. 13. The two adv. expressions, e)n au)th=| th=| e)fo/dw| and e)c o)li/gou (at short notice) mutually explain one another.
feu/gein: they were exiled, doubtless after a trial. Cf. c. 26. 24.—do/cantas malakisqh=nai: because they were considered (either by the people or by their judges) to have acted like cowards.

fqa/sai th=| prosmi/cei: equiv. to prosmi/sgontas fqa/sai, they got ahead of them with their attack, i.e. they attacked them before the movement was carried out. The verb prosmignu/nai in the sense of attack occurs in i. 111. 13; ii. 39. 17; iv. 96. 6. The use of the dat. is peculiar. St. compares Dem. XXXI. 38, o)rgh=| kai\ tro/pou propetei/a| fqa/sas to\n logismo/n. See App.

e)pi\ tou\s *skiri/tas: this stands before the conj. w(s for emphasis. Cf. i. 19. 2; ii. 64. 17; iii. 56. 26; iv. 27. 2. As the two lochi did not move to fill the space left vacant (to\ dia/kenon tou=to) by the departure of the Sciritae, Agis commanded the latter to return to the main body of the army (sfi/si like a)po\ sfw=n in 17, and prosmi=cai as in c. 58. 3 and iii. 106. 14). This, however, they were unable to do, because the enemy were already between them and their friends. See App.
cugklh=|sai: intr. as in iv. 35. 2.
a)lla\ ma/lista dh/: the force of this is the same as that of ma/lista dh/ of c. 66. 6, except that it is strengthened by a)lla/.

e)mpeiri/a| : the
experience and the ease and accuracy in the execution of manoeuvres which result from experience. In this the Lacedaemonians were inferior throughout (kata\ pa/nta e)lasswqe/ntes). Indeed, this was the first great battle upon open ground in which they had engaged for many years (see MüllerStrübing, Thuc. Forsch. p. 12 f.), and at the very beginning of the battle they did not succeed in carrying out the movements commanded by Agis. Nevertheless they proved that they were superior in courage, and thereby won the victory. e)/deican perigeno/menoi, showed by the result that they were superior (const. as in c. 9. 40 and iv. 73. 8), is the expression of one who regards the battle from a later point of view; hence the aor. (not perigigno/menoi with Poppo and St.). The account of the actual events is introduced by the following ga/r. See App.
au)tw=n: i.e. tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn. The gen. of the pron. stands first as in i. 30. 14; iv. 199. 2.

oi( xi/lioi loga/des: cf. c. 67. 13.—ou) cugklh|sqe/n: cf. mh\ dunhqh=nai cugklh=|sai, 7.— 15. tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous: i.e. those who, acc. to c. 67. 5 f., had been placed next to (e(ch=s) the Sciritae and Brasideans, but had been separated from them by their movement toward the left (c. 71. § 3). The enemy now came in between the Sciritae and the Lacedaemonians, and attacked the flank of the latter.—die/fqeiron: impf., “they inflicted great losses upon them.” Cf. iii. 98. 12.—kuklwsa/menoi: since they had advanced into the dia/kenon.
e)s ta\s a(ma/cas : e)/sw tw=n a(macw=n, Schol. Among the baggage-wagons which stood behind the army. Near these the presbu/teroi were drawn up in reserve, e)pitetagme/noi.

oi( triako/sioi i(pph=s kalou/menoi: cf. Hdt.viii. 124. 13, trihko/sioi *spartihte/wn loga/des, ou(=toi oi(/per i(ppe/es kale/ontai (perhaps Kr., followed by St. and v. Herwerden, is right in inserting oi( before i(pph=s). These men who ‘were chosen from the flower of the Spartan youth, served as a royal bodyguard as well on foot as on horseback.’ Hermann, Griech. Staatsalt.
§ 29. 15 ff. They certainly served on foot, but of their use as cavalry there is no proof. See Gilbert, Griech. Staatsalt. I. p. 77.

tw=n *)argei/wn: see App.—toi=s presbute/rois kai\ pe/nte lo/xois w)nomasme/nois: a(/ma a)nagnwste/on pentelo/xois. Schol. Nothing is known of the relation of these divisions of the Argive troops to one another, or to the xi/lioi loga/des of 14, and c. 67. 13. w)nomasme/nois indicates that pe/nte lo/xoi or pente/loxoi was the conventional name of a division of troops, which seems, in conjunction with the presbu/teroi, to be identical with the a)/lloi *)argei=oi of c. 67. 15. See Arnold's note on this passage.— 23. *)aqhnai/wn toi=s paratetagme/nois: this is that part of the Attic contingent (cf. c. 61. 1; 67. 17) which stood next the Orneatae, furthest toward the right. The fortunes of the main body of the Athenians are related in c. 73. 4 ff.—ou)de\ e)s xei=ras u(pomei/nantas: i.e. ou)de\ me/xri tou= e)s xei=ras e)lqei=n u(pomei/nantas: “not waiting until they came to close quarters.” Similarly, mh/te e)s a)lkh\n u(pomei=nai, iii. 108. 5.
katapathqe/ntas: sc. u(p' a)llh/lwn, as Grote, VI. c. 56, p. 356 f., has shown.

th\n e)gkata/lhyin: correctly explained by Grote as subj. of mh\ fqh=nai. This is equiv. to tou= tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous mh\ fqh=nai e)gkatalabo/ntas au)tou/s. In their panic they fell under the feet of their own comrades, running away, that the enemy might not eatch them before they could escape. e)gkata/lhyin is very expressive: “the holding fast, while still on the spot” (e)n); Grote translates: “the actual grasp of the Lacedaemonians.”
tou= mh/: with inf. expressing purpose. See on i. 4. 6, tou= ta\s proso/dous ma=llon i)e/nai au)tw=|. GMT. 95, 1; H. 960.
The Athenians were saved from excessive losses by the assistance of their cavalry; nor did the Lacedaemonians pursue their defeated opponents very far.

parerrh/gnunto, e)kuklou=to: the two impfs., each with a(/ma, indicate the moment of the greatest peril. “The (defeated) Argives and their allies were on the point of being entirely severed from the rest of the army, and at the same time the right wing of the enemy was on the point of surrounding the Athenians.” Among the allies the body of Athenians mentioned in c. 72. 23 is included. oi( *)argei=oi kai\ cu/mmaxoi is to be supplied as subj. of parerrh/gnunto. Cf. iv. 96. 25; vi. 70. 10.—e)f' e(ka/tera: they were separated on the right from the victorious Mantineans, who were pressing forward, and on the left
from the main body of the Athenians, who composed the extreme left wing (see c. 67. 17), and were now in danger of being surrounded by the right wing of the Lacedaemonians and Tegeans.
tw=| perie/xonti sfw=n: cf. c. 71. 13.

au)tou/s: sc. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, refers to them all, so that their two divisions are designated in their situation at the moment, the one as kuklou/menoi (pres. pass. on the point of being surrounded), the other as h(sshme/noi acc. to c. 72. 23 ff.

oi( i(pph=s: i.e. the three hundred of c. 61. 2 and 67. 18.—paro/ntes: by their presence, because the enemy dared not come near them; or possibly we should read pario/ntes, by advancing to protect the foot-force.
kai\ cune/bh: then it happened.— to\ eu)w/numon sfw=n: cf. c. 71. 15.

paraggei=lai: see on c. 71. 17.—xwrh=sai e)pi\ to\ nikw/menon: to go to (assist) the defeated part of the army (the left wing). This movement is described in the following parh=lqe kai\ e)ce/kline a)po\ sfw=n(tw=n *)aqhnai/wn)to\ stra/teuma: they turned toward the left and moved away from the Athenians. This intr. use of e)kkli/nein does not occur elsewhere.

to\ h(sshqe/n: i.e. the part of the Argives which had been defeated in c. 72. 21. The aor. is used in reference to the action there described; the pf. h(sshme/nous (7), in reference to the condition resulting from that action.
pro\s to\ e)gkei=sqai: cf. c. 72. 16 ff.
e)piferome/nous: this results from the xwrh=sai e)pi\ to\ nikw/menon of 11.

kai\ plei/ous: these words are opp.
to the following tw=n *)argei/wn loga/dwn to\ polu\ e)sw/qh. Of these only a few fell, while a greater number of the Mantineans were cut down. kai/ is emphatic; not only did they take to flight, but a considerable number were killed (more than of the loga/des; 200, acc. to c. 74. 9). See App.— 22. ou) bi/aios: “not hotly pursued.” Cf. iv. 31. 15.—ou)de\ makra/: correctly explained by the Schol. as referring to distance: ou)de\ e)pi\ polu\ dia/sthma.— 23. xroni/ous (in i. 12. 3, with fem. ending xroni/a) kai\ bebai/ous: these are pred. adjs. with ta\s ma/xas poiou=ntai, corresponding to advs. with ma/xesqai. So braxei/as (temporal) belongs with ta\s diw/ceis, sc. poiou=ntai. Plut. Lyc. 22 makes a similar statement concerning the Lacedaemonian manner of fighting.
The number of slain on both sides.

toiau/th kai\ o(/ti e)ggu/tata tou/twn: cf. i. 22. 17, toiou/twn kai\ paraplhsi/wn; vii. 42. 10, i)/son kai\ paraplh/sion. Slightly different is vii. 86. 23, toiau/th| h)\ o(/ti e)ggu/tata tou/twn ai)ti/a|.
plei/stou dh\ xro/nou megi/sth dh/ : dh/ is repeated with the sups. on account of the special emphasis. On the gen. of time, see Kr. Spr. 47, 2, 3.
cunelqou=sa: see App.

proqe/menoi tw=n polemi/wn nekrw=n to\ o(/pla: i.e. pro\ tw=n polemi/wn nekrw=n ta\ o(/pla qe/menoi (see on ii. 2. 22): “they halted in front of the enemy's dead.” So const. by Haase, Lucubr. Thuc. p. 7. Herbst, Jahrbb. 1858, p. 693, shows, by comparison of this passage with Xen. Ages. ii. 15, that this was done ‘because then the enemy would certainly be compelled to ask for their dead,’ and thus own themselves defeated.

i(/stasan: impf. The erection of the tropai=on was not perfected until after the enemy owned their defeat. This they did u(pospo/ndous tou\s nekrou\s komizo/menoi (cf. ii. 79. 29) or a)nairou/menoi (cf. vii. 5. 10), which corresponds to the a)podido/nai of the victors.— e)sku/leuon: the remark of Aelian V.H. vi. 6, ou)k e)ch=n a)ndri\ *la/kwni ou)de\ skuleu=sai to\n pole/mion applies, then, only to the time of the actual battle.
cu\n *ai)ginh/tais: this shows that Cleruchi from Aegina (see ii. 27. 5 ff.) had also been called out.
oi( strathgoi\ a)mfo/teroi: Laches and Nicostratus. Cf. c. 61. 2.
oi( cu/mmaxoi: i.e. the allies from Arcadia, who are not mentioned in the account of the battle; hence ou)k e)talaipw/rhsan, they had not been exposed and had not suffered any considerable losses.

w(/ste kai\ a)cio/logo/n ti a)pogene/sqai: kai/ has the effect of adding to the assurance that something in itself improbable nevertheless really happened. See on i. 15. 7; iv. 48. 25. a)pogi/gnesqai, be missing, die, occurs also in ii. 34. 4; 51. 22; 98. 10.
Remarks on the battle of Mantinea. The hostilities between Epidaurus and Argos are renewed.
th=s de\ ma/xhs mellou/shs kte(.: the epexegetical de/ introduces the following aors. (e)boh/qhse and a)fi/keto, to be translated by the English plpf.), which go back to the time before the battle.

o( e(/teros basileu/s: either the law mentioned by Hdt.v. 75. 9 f., mh\ e)cei=nai e(/pesqai a)mfote/rous tou\s basile/as e)ciou/shs stratih=s, was neglected in this instance, or it did not apply to the sending of reinforcements.— tou/s te presbute/rous kai\ newte/rous: cf. c. 64. 10 ff.
kai\...a)pe/streyan : the narrative of the events succeeding the battle is resumed.
tou\s a)po\ *kori/nqou kte(.: see c. 64. 15.—a)pe/streyan: they caused them to turn back. Cf. iv. 97. 7.
*ka/rneia: on the time of this festival, see on c. 54. 8.
e)tu/gxanon o)/nta: on the pl., see on e)ph=lqon *)olu/mpia, i. 126. 13.
kai\...a)pelu/santo : “and so by this one deed they had done away with the accusation which was commonly brought against them at that time.”

to/te: taken in connexion
with th\n e)n th=| nh/sw| cumfora/n, evidently refers to the whole period since the capture of Sphacteria in 425 B.C.— e)piferome/nhn ai)ti/an: cf. ai)ti/an e)pife/rein, iii. 46. 26.—e)s malaki/an: cf. viii. 88. 8, e)s th\n fili/an diaba/llein.
e)s th\n a)/llhn a)bouli/an : general stupidity. On this use of a)/llos, see on i. 128. 21; ii. 14. 2.

kakizo/menoi: being ill-spoken of, having incurred disgrace. This is in accordance with the use of this word elsewhere in Thuc. (cf. i. 105. 26; ii. 21. 23) and with u(po\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn e)piferome/nhn ai)ti/an above. The dat. tu/xh| must then be taken to mean “by a mishap,” “through unfortunate circumstances.” (The explanation “hardly used by fortune” would be appropriate as regards the sense, but is not in accordance with the use of kaki/zesqai.) A similar idea is expressed in ii. 87. 7 ff.
prote/ra|: see App.—th=s ma/xhs: depends upon the comp. prote/ra| as, 19, upon u(/steron.
w(s e)rh=mon ou)=san : tou= strateu/matos, Schol. This is retaliation for the attack mentioned in c. 56. § 5.
tw=n *)argei/wn: const. with fu/lakas.
e)celqo/ntwn au)tw=n : “since the citizens fit for military service had gone away.” St. strikes out au)tw=n and takes tw=n *)argei/wn e)celqo/ntwn together.
pollou/s: const. as pred. in great numbers.
*)hlei/wn: the Eleans had delayed for a time on account of anger. See c. 62. 5.

toi=s prote/rois: cf. c. 61. 1 ff. Thuc. does not tell what general or generals took the command of the Athenian troops in place of those who had fallen (see c. 61. 2; 74. 10). Müller-Strübing, Aristoph. und die hist. Krit. p. 447 ff., suggests Demosthenes. This seems, in view of c. 80. 16, not improbable (though Cl. thinks otherwise).
dielo/menoi: used of like operations in ii. 75. 11; 78. 4; iv. 69. 10; vii. 19. 6.

e)cepau/santo: a)pe/kamon tou= peri-
teixi/zein. Schol. The mid. in Thuc. occurs here only; e)kpau/sw in Eur. Ion, 144.—th\n a)/kran to\ *(hrai=on: appos. ‘The Heraeum by the harbour, the site of which can be found on the small rocky height.’ Curtius, Pelopon. II. p. 428. Cf. Paus. ii. 29. 1, to\ de\ pro\s tw=| lime/ni e)pi\ a)/kras a)nexou/shs e)s qa/lassan le/gousin *(/hras ei)=nai.— 24. e)ceirga/santo: on this side the Athenians finished the wall of circumvallation which, with the outworks which may have belonged to it, formed the tei/xisma of 25.
In Argos the oligarchical party gains the upper hand, and brings about a peace with Sparta.
eu)qu/s: const. with a)rxome/nou. Cf. c. 13. 2; iv. 52. 1.
[e)peidh\ ta\ *ka/rneia h)/gagon]: see App.
lo/gous cumbathri/ous: proposals of peace. Not found elsewhere in Att. writers; later freq. used, esp. by Dion H. (ii. 45, etc.).
au)toi=s: const. grammatically with e)pith/deioi, but its position at the beginning of the sent. points to a general relation: “there had always been partizans of theirs there.”
to\n dh=mon: th\n dhmokrati/an. Schol. Cf. iii. 81. 20.

tou\s pollou/s: the many, the people (Cl. renders, a great number, and cites iv. 6. 6, which does not apply).—e)s th\n o(mologi/an: a rare const. with pei/qein which is defined by the Schol. h)/goun katapei=sai o(mologh=sai kai\ sunqe/sqai.

sponda\s poih/santes : after they had first made a truce (cf. c. 30. 26; ii. 29. 24); with cummaxi/an, 9, we must supply poih=sai (cf. c. 30. 26; ii. 29. 24; viii. 6. 10), depending, like the following e)piti/qesqai, upon e)bou/lonto.
au)=qis : denotes progress after prw=ton or pro/teron. Cf. c. 36. 11; 78. 5; iv. 73. 26; vi. 90. 5.
*li/xas o( *)arkesila/ou: see on c. 50. 14.

kaq' o(/ ti, w(s: the ellip
sis in these brief expressions (as in Lat. quaestio an or quomodo, etc.) cannot be supplied with certainty (polemh/sousi with kaq' o(/ ti and ei)rh/nhn a)/cousi with w(s would do). In case the Argives preferred war, the lo/gos probably contained threats, and in case of an agreement, the proposal of the terms given in c. 77.
e)/tuxe...parw/n : he was already present in c. 61. 8.
toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois: the dat. of advantage with pra/ssein as in iii. 4. 21; iv. 106. 10.
e)k tou= fanerou=: equiv. to fanerw=s. Cf. iv. 79. 10; 106. 11.—tolmw=ntes: abs. Cf. ii. 43. 11.
The terms of the treaty of peace between the Lacedaemonians and the Argives.

katta/de dokei= kte(.: the Dor. dialect in the two documents given in c. 77 and 79 does not agree in all respects with the rules laid down by Ahrens (de dial Dor. p. 480 ff.). Still, it does not seem best to depart from the reading of the Mss. in an attempt to reconstruct the original language of these chaps. See App.—katta/de: Att. kata\ ta/de; 2. pottw/s: Att. pro\s tou/s; 5. e)kbw=ntas: Att. e)kbai/nontas; 6. ai) de/ ka mh\ ei)/kwnti: Att. e)a
 de\ mh\ ei)/kwsi; 7. ei)=men: Att. ei)=nai; 10. e)/xonti: Att. e)/xousi; a)podo/men: Att. a)podou=nai; poli/essi: Att. po/lesi; tw= siw= su/matos: Att. tou= qeou= qu/matos; 11. ai) me
 lh=n: Att. ei) me
 bou/lesqai; 15. a)lece/menai: Att. a)le/cein; 18. e)nti: Att. ei)si; e)ssou=ntai: Att. e)/sontai; 22. a)pia/llhn: Att. a)pope/mpein. For details, see the notes in St.'s edit.—ta=| e)kklhsi/a|: acc. to Hdt.vii. 134. 9, the proper designation of the popular assembly at Sparta is a(li/a, which Ahrens wished to insert in the text; but it seems more likely that this assembly was properly called a)pe/lla. See Gilbert, Griech. Staatsalt. I. p. 53 f.
tw\s pai=das: i.e. the hostages mentioned in c. 61. 22.

tw\s a)/ndras: these must be the o(/mhroi e)k th=s *)arkadi/as au)to/qi u(po\ *lakedaimoni/wn kei/menoi of c. 61. 18, although no mention of the Maenalians is made there. Why the distinction between pai=des and a)/ndres is made is not clear. pai=s seems to be used here and in 9 to designate those who are not of military age.
to\ tei=xos: the tei/xisma of c. 75. 25.
toi\ *)aqhnai=oi: the Athenians had been most active in the operations against Epidaurus. Cf. c. 75. 25.

peri\ tw= siw= su/matos: on the forms, see above. This refers to the cause of the quarrel between Argos and Epidaurus. See c. 53. 2 f. tw= siw=, i.e. tou= *)apo/llwnos tou= *puqae/ws. Perhaps van Herwerden is right in inserting tw= (i.e. tou=) before su/matos, though the omission of the art. may be explained on account of the preceding gen.

ai) me
 lh=n, toi=s *)epidauri/ois o(/rkon do/men, ai) de/, kte(.: if they wish, they shall impose an oath upon the Epidaurians; but if not, they shall swear it themselves. lh=n is inf. The inf. after ei) occurs also in iv. 98. 12, kai\ au)toi\ ei) me
 e)pi\ ple/on dunhqh=nai th=s e)kei/nwn krath=sai, tou=t' a)
 e)/xein. This is not unlike the inf. in rel. clauses. Cf. c. 28, 4; 46. 17. ai) de/ is for ei) de\ mh/. Cf. Plat. Conv. 212 c, ei) me
 bou/lei, w(s e)gkw/mion ei)s *)/erwta no/mison ei)rh=sqai, ei) de/, o(/ ti kai\ o(/ph| xai/reis o)noma/zwn, tou=to o)no/maze. See App.
au)tono/mws ei)=men pa/sas: the Lacedaemonians always endeavoured to prevent other cities from establishing empires or hegemonies.
a(mo/qi: is another Dor. form for a(ma=|, i.e. koinh=|. See App.
o(/pa| ka: equiv. to w(s a)/n with subjv.
e)ssou=ntai: see App.
e)nti kte(.: see App.
