cumbale/sqai: this repeats the cumbale/sqai of 2 with the added conditions e)pidei/cantas toi=s cumma/xois and ai)/ ka au)toi=s dokh=|: “they were to communicate (the conditions) to their allies, and then conclude the peace if they (the Argives and Lacedaemonians) thought best.” (Cl. takes au)toi=s to refer to the allies. But in that case there is no distinction between
ai)/ ka au)toi=s dokh=| and the following ai) de/ ti dokh=| toi=s cumma/xois). Then follows ai) de/ ti dokh=| (subj. after the simple ai) as in c. 79. 11 and 13) without a)/llo (which only the inferior Mss. offer): “if the allies saw fit, they might send the treaty home” (oi)/kad' a)pia/llhn), i.e. refer it to the governing bodies of their respective cities.
Soon after the oligarchical party at Argos induces the Argives to relinquish their previous alliances and make an alliance with Sparta.
prw=ton: pred. agreeing with lo/gon. prw=ton is in contradistinction to meta\ de\ tou=to kte(. in 3.
e)pimici/as: cf. c. 35. 3.
par' a)llh/lous: const. with e)pimici/as ou)/shs, as with the verb e)pimi/sgein in i. 13. 19.—e)/pracan: aor. This expresses the result of pra/ssontes in c. 76. 15.
sponda\s kai\ cummaxi/an: see App. on c. 27. 2. The same reading must be adopted in c. 79. 2 and 80. 1.
The terms of the treaty of alliance between the Lacedaemonians and the Argives.
e)pi\ toi=s i)/sois kai\ o(moi/ois: cf. c. 27. 12.

dido/ntas: as if tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous kte(. preceded instead of the dat. Cf. i. 31. 9; 53. 1; 72. 3, e)/docen au)toi=s parithte/a e)s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous ei)=nai, tw=n me\n e)gklhma/twn pe/ri mhde\n a)pologhsome/nous kte(.
koinaneo/ntwn : Att. koinwnou/ntwn. An excellent emendation of Valckenaer for koina\n or koina=n e)o/ntwn of the Mss.

ta=s cummaxi/as: the Mss. give ta=n cummaxia=n (or more freq. cummaxi/an). See App. on c. 27. 2.—au)topo/lies: this does not occur elsewhere. Cf. au)topoli=tai, Xen. Hell. v. 2. 14. It cor
responds to au)totelei=s kai\ au)to/dikoi of c. 18. 7.

toi=s au)toi=s: it is difficult to see why this is pl. Cf. c. 77. 18. Kirchhoff (Sitzungsber. d. Berl. Akad. 1883, p. 860) may be right in reading tw=| au)tw=| and tw=|per.—toi=sper: (or tw=|per) is used without the repetition of e)n. Cf. c. 42. 2.
stratei/as: so Portus for stratia=s of the Mss.

o(/pa| ka: sc. kri/nwnti. Cf. c. 77. 16.—kri/nantas toi=s cumma/xois: adjudging (i.e. allotting) to the allies what part of the burden of the war each shall bear. The aor. partic. may refer to time preceding the execution of the plan expressed in bouleu/esqai. GMT. 24, N. 3; Madvig, Philol. Suppl. Vol. 2, p. 46. Perhaps, as Kr. suggests, Thuc. wrote kri/nwnti.
a)mfi/loga: neut. pl. Cf. a)nti/pala, c. 8. 6; a)du/nata, iii. 88. 4; e(toi=ma, ii. 3. 15.

diakriqh=men: like all the preceding infs. this and the two which follow depend upon e)/doce: they shall come to an agreement about it. This accounts for the opts. e)ri/zoi and dokei/oi. GMT. 77; H. 937. The sent. ai) de/ tis tw=n cumma/xwn po/lis po/lei e)ri/zoi does not introduce new subjs., but assumes that there has been a failure to come to an agreement: “but if one of the allied cities should get into a (real and open) quarrel with another,” they shall have recourse to arbitration.
i)/san: aequam, fair, impartial.

dokei/oi: (Kirchhoff, doki/oi) Dor. for the Att. dokoi/h.—tw\s de\ e)/tas: (Poppo and St. for toi=s de\ e)/tais of the Mss.) tou\s de\ politeuome/nous e)n mia=| e(ka/sth| po/lei di) a)llh/lwn lu/ein ta\ dia/fora, Schol. Acc. to Hesych. e)/tai are e(tai=roi, sunh/qeis poli=tai, dhmo/tai, and in an inscription from Olympia (Corp. Inscr. Gr. I. p. 30 f.) they are opp. to the telestai=s, i.e. to toi=s e)n te/lei. The sense of the passage then is: “the citizens (i.e. private individuals as opp. to the cities) shall conduct their legal business according to the laws of their respective states.” See App.

p.title: The Lacedaemonians and Argives acting together induce Perdiccas and the Chalcidian cities to join their

div2.p: h)\ ei)/ ti a)/llo ei)=xon: with the indefinite sense, or whatever else they had to find fault with in their relations with one another, and in accordance with this the expression dielu/santo is chosen; they came to an agreement about it. From this we must supply a)pe/dosan with o(po/sa a)llh/lwn pole/mw| (sc. ei)=xon). Cf. c. 17. 12.
tiqe/menoi: diatiqe/menoi, dioikonomou=ntes, Schol. See on i. 25. 2.

ta\ tei/xh: i.e. the tei/xisma at the Heraeum near Epidaurus. See c. 75. 25; 77. 5. Perhaps Pylos also is meant (cf. c. 39. 6 and 14; 56. 11), as the pl. tei/xh would naturally include all fortifications held by the Athenians in Peloponnesus.
qumw=| e)/feron: “they were very energetic.” Cf. i. 31. 2, o)rgh=| fe/rontes. 10. dienoei=to: sc. a)posth=nai. See on i. 1. 7.

e(w/ra: sc. a)festhko/tas. See on i. 78. 10; 80. 2.—to\ a)rxai=on e)c *)/argous: cf. iii. 99. 8, where his family is said to be *thmeni/dai. The oldest account of this relation is given by Hdt. viii. 137. ff.

tou\s palaiou\s o(/rkous: cf. c. 31. 26 as regards the Argives. The Chalcidians had doubtless had treaties of some kind with the Lacedaemonians ever since they left the Athenian alliance. See i. 58. 10.
to\ e)c *)epidau/rou tei=xos: the proleptic use of e)c (see on i. 8. 9) is here admitted with e)klipei=n. Cf. i. 105. 19, tw=n d) e)k th=s po/lews u(poloi/pwn.

o)li/goi o)/ntes : corrected by Abresch for o)/ntas of the Mss. This is opp. to pro\s plei/ous tou\s cumfu/lakas, i.e. the Argives, Eleans, and Mantineans, who far outnumbered the 1000 Athenians. Cf. c. 75. § 5 and 6. See App.

*dhmosqe/nhn: this form of the acc. seems to have the best authority. This Demosthenes is the well-known general. See iii. 91. 2;
iv. 3. 8; 66. 14.

pro/fasin: see on c. 53. 2. u(pokri/nas (read u(pokrina/menos)poiei=n a)gw=na/ tina gumniko/n, Schol. Under this pretence he enticed the garrison out of the fortification, and prevented their return (a)pe/klh|se ta\s pu/las). Afterwards he surrendered the place to the Epidaurians.

frou/rion: this word, which is found in the most and best Mss., must be used in the sense of froura/. Cf. c. 75. 25. St. cites (besides some doubtful passages of Aesch.) Xen. An. i. 4. 15, u(mi=n xrh/setai kai\ ei)s frou/ria kai\ ei)s loxagi/as. See App.
a)nanewsa/menoi: see App.
Mantinea joins the Lacedaemonian alliance. Oligarchies are established at Sicyon and Argos.
a)po/stasin e)k th=s cummaxi/as: i.e. a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn.
ou) duna/menoi : sc. a)nte/xein.

th\n a)rxh\n a)fei=san tw=n po/lewn : some of these cities had been subject to them before they joined the Argive alliance (see c. 29. 3); and they had extended their power since that time. See c. 33. 3 and 10; 62. 1. They were obliged to give up their sovereignty in compliance with the provision of the treaty in c. 79. 3 ff., tai\ de\ po/lies koinaneo/ntwn ta=n sponda=n kai\ ta=s cummaxi/as au)to/nomoi kai\ au)topo/lies kte(.
*lakedaimo/nioi kai\ *)argei/oi, au)toi\ oi( *lakedaimo/nioi, cunamfo/teroi: the subj. changes from the whole to one of its parts and back again to the whole within the same period. Cf. c. 10. 47 ff.

e)s o)li/gous: this is Thuc.'s regular expression for an oligarchy. Cf. viii. 53. 22; 89. 18, and see on ii. 37. 2; viii. 38. 11.—ma=llon: i.e. ma=llon h)\ pro/teron, intimating that the Sicyonian government was not thoroughly democratic before.
kate/lusan: cf. c. 76. 6. Diod. xii. 80. 42 reports that this revolution was not accomplished without bloodshed: sullabo/ntes tou\s dhmagwgei=n ei)wqo/tas a)pe/kteinan.

e)pith/deia toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois : cf. i. 19. 1, kai\ oi( me\n *lakedaimo/nioi ou)x u(potelei=s e)/xontes fo/rou
tou\s cumma/xous h(gou=nto, kat' o)ligarxi/an de\ sfi/sin au)toi=s mo/non e)pithdei/ws o(/pws politeu/sousi qerapeu/ontes.
But the next summer the democratic party comes again into power at Argos, and tries to secure itself by making an alliance with Athens and building long walls to the sea.

*dih=s: they were the inhabitants of the town of Dium (see iv. 109. 10), the same who had already (see c. 35. 1) engaged in hostilities toward Athens, and who now openly joined her enemies. Here, as in c. 35. 2, some inferior Mss. read *diktidih=s.— 3. ta\ e)n *)axai/a| ou)k e)pithdei/ws pro/teron e)/xonta: cf. i. 19. 1 ff. At the beginning of the war only the Pelleneans were on the side of the Lacedaemonians. See ii. 9. 6.—kaqi/stanto: sc. e)pithdeio/teron or e)pi\ to\ sfi/sin w)fe/limon. Cf. i. 76. 2.

o( dh=mos a)naqarsh/sas e)pe/qento: dh=mos with adjs. in the sing, and the verb in the pl. occurs also in iii. 80. 1 f. G. 135, 3; H. 609.—kat' o)li/gon cunista/meno/s te kai\ a)naqarsh/sas: the oligarchy which was established in Argos pro\s e)/ar, say in March (see c. 81. 10), lasted until the time of the gymnopaediae, a period of about five months, since this festival took place in Hecatombaeum (about July; see Schoemann, Griech. Alt. II. p. 460. Diod., xii. 80. 45, wrongly says that the oligarchy lasted eight months). During this period the secret meetings and deliberations (cuni/stasqai, as in ii. 88. 4; iii. 70. 24; viii. 65. 6) of the popular party were held, until sufficient confidence for a rising had been gained (a)naqarsh/sas in the aor. denotes the conclusion of the deliberations expressed by the pres. cunista/menos). —kat' o)li/gon: gradually, in continuous progress toward completion. Cf. i. 61. 18; 69. 13. (Cl. now adopts this explanation by St.) Paus., ii. 20. 2, says that this fierce insurrection broke out because the leader of the xi/lioi loga/des (cf. c. 67. 13; 72. 14) outraged the betrothed bride of a man of the common people, and this may have been the immediate occasion of the outbreak.

ta\s gumnopaidi/as: ‘this was a festival somewhat resembling the Lupercalia at Rome, in which boys and men danced naked, each arranged in distinct chori, the movements expressing warlike and gymnastic contests; while at the same time coarse and licentious
language was interchanged, as in the Roman triumphs.’ Arnold. The festival was mainly in honour of Apollo. See Schoemann, Griech. Alt. II. p. 460.

ou)k h)=lqon e)k plei/onos: the sense of this passage evidently is: “while their friends were sending for them, they failed to come for a very long (or too long) time; but at last they postponed the festival and started on the march” (e)boh/qoun impf.). The fact that they only went as far as Tegea before hearing of the revolution at Argos seems to show that they were in no great hurry. See App.— 11. proelqei=n me/n, a)naxwrh/santes de/: the opposition of these two parts of the sent. is very effective: “as to advancing, they had no idea of such a thing (ou)k h)qe/lhsan); on the contrary, they went home and celebrated their festival.”
tw=n diapefeugo/twn: i.e. the members of the oligarchical party of Argos.
kai\ a)gge/lwn: see App.

a)f' e(kate/rwn: see on iii. 36. 24. This prep. is freq. used with le/gesqai and similar words. In these speeches each party doubtless tried to justify itself and make its opponents seem completely in the wrong.

fobou/menos, prosago/menos, nomi/zwn: these parties. all interpret teixi/zei makra\ tei/xh. The chief reason is expressed in fobou/menos tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous, which is further enlarged by pa/lin prosago/menos th\n tw=n *)aqhnai/wn cummaxi/an and nomi/zwn me/giston a)\n sfa=s w)felh/sein, these two expressions being closely connected by te and kai/. “The Argives undertook the building of long walls because they were afraid of the Lacedaemonians and (therefore) embraced the alliance of Athens and thought they should be greatly the gainers.”

prosago/menos: oi)keiou/menos, Schol. This act was a declaration in favour of the A thenian policy (and political ideas) and therefore in itself a renewal of the alliance
with Athens, which remained in force from this time.

w)felh/sein: the subj. is not th
 tw=n *)aqhnai/wn cummaxi/an, but is, as Herbst (Hamburg Progr. 1867, p. 32 f.) rightly observes, to be supplied from the following teixi/zei makra\ tei/xh. This is further explained in o(/pws . . . w)felh=|: for h( kata\ qa/lassan e)pagwgh\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn is the advantage derived from the long walls. meta\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn is a secondary and necessary consequence. a)
 w)felh/sein is equiv. to o(/ti w)felh/sei a)/n with the suppressed prot. h)
 tou=to ge/nhtai. GMT. 37, 2; 53; H. 845; 861; 946. Cf. ii. 80. 40; vi. 66. 4; viii. 25. 28; and 71. 12 with App. See App.

cunh/|desan to\n teixismo/n: if this reading is correct, the knowing about or being privy to this project shows an inclination toward the philo-Athenian policy of Argos which was exhibited by the building of the long walls. See App.
tines: interposed between the gens., as in i. 45. 8, e)s tw=n e)kei/nwn ti xwri/wn.
liqourgoi/ : so masons had been brought from Athens to assist in the circumvallation of Nisaea. See iv. 60. 6.
The Lacedaemonians attack the Argives, take and tear down the long walls, and take Hysiae. The Argives make an incursion into the territory of Phlius. The Athenians blockade the coast of Macedonia.

w(s h)/|sqonto teixizo/ntwn: the gen. with ai)sqa/nesqai occurs also in i. 57. 14; 72. 3; ii. 81. 31; iv. 108. 31, the partic. in the gen. here only, but freq. in the acc. Cf. c. 37. 15; i. 47. 1. The Lacedaemonians must have heard at once of the doings at Argos; so that w(s h)/|sqonto must not be taken too strictly.

u(ph=rxe/ ti au)toi=s prasso/menon: the use of pra/ssein in kai/ ti au)tw=| e)pra/sseto e)s ta\s po/leis (iv. 121. 12) is here combined with that of u(pa/rxein in a)sfa/leia/n tina u(pa/rxousa/n oi( in vi. 59. 7, “there was also a party acting from Argos itself in their interest.”
e)k tou= *)/argous au)to/qen: an emphatic combination. Cf. ii. 25. 18, au)to/qen e)k th=s perioiki/dos *)hlei/wn. See Herbst, gegen Cobct, p. 58 ff.
ou) prouxw/rhsen e)/ti: it made no further progress, it failed them.
ta\ oi)kodomou/mena tei/xh: the walls which were building, not ta\ kateskeuasme/na, as Diod. (xii. 81. 76) wrongly says.
*(usi/as: Hysiae was near the Arcadian frontier on the road from Argos to Tegea, where its ruins may still be seen. See Curtius, Pelopon. II. p. 367.

o(/ti sfw=n tou\s fuga/das u(pede/xonto: const. with e)stra/teusan and dh|w/santes, not with a)ph=lqon. sfw=n stands before tou\s fuga/das with almost the effect of the ethical dat. See on e)pei\ sfw=n oi( cu/mmaxoi e)po/noun, i. 30. 14.
*makedo/nas, *perdi/kka|: see App.

th\n cunwmosi/an: cf. c. 80. 9.— 19. e)/yeusto: violated, “did not preserve.” Cf. iii. 66, 17, th\n mh\ ktei/nein yeusqei=san u(po/sxesin.—h( stratei/a: see App.—ma/lista: implies that there were also other reasons.
dielu/qh: as in iii. 114. 21, die/lusan to\n po/lemon.—a)pa/rantos: this reading of the Mss. is certainly wrong. For emendations, see App.

Alcibiades places three hundred Argives of the oligarchical party under custody upon the neighbouring islands. The Athenians send an expedition against the island of Melos, but try negotiations before proceeding to actual hostilities.

*)alkibia/dhs te, kai\ e)pi\ *mh=lon: the doings of Alcibiades at Argos and the expedition against Melos are thus (by te and kai/) brought together as the two most important events of
the summer.
e)/ti: still, after tou\s me\n a)pe/kteinan, tou\s de\ e)ch/lasan, as mentioned in c. 82. 7.—ta\ *lakedaimoni/wn fronei=n: cf. iii. 68. 18; vi. 51. 7; viii. 31. 7.
kate/qento: deposited. The mid. is always used in the sense of “place under custody.” See on iii. 72. 2.

e)s ta\s e)ggu\s nh/sous: so they had once before confined the suspected Corcyreans on Aegina. See iii. 72. 1 ff.—e)pi\ *mh=lon: a previous attempt under Nicias to subjugate the island had been unsuccessful. See iii. 91. § 1 f. and 94. 2. Yet from Ol. 88, 3 (426 B.C.) on, the Melians are found, and the amount of their tribute is specified, on the lists of tributaries of Athens. See U. Köhler, zur Geschichte des delischattischen Bundes in Abhh. d. Berl. Akad. 1869, p. 146.

*lesbi/ain: these were ships of the Methymnaeans, for the rest of Lesbos was now held by Athenian Cleruchs to whom the Lesbians paid rent in lieu of tribute. See iii. 50. 5 ff.; vi. 85. 8. Wecklein, cur. epigr. p. 16, shows from inscriptions that this reading is preferable to *lesbi/ais of most Mss.

cumma/xwn kai\ nhsiwtw=n: cf. vi. 85. 6 ff., kai\ ga\r toi=s e)kei= cumma/xois w(s e(/kastoi xrh/simoi e)chgou/meqa, *xi/ous me\n kai\ *mhqumnai/ous new=n parokwxh=| au)tono/mous, tou\s de\ pollou\s xrhma/twn biaio/teron fora=|, a)/llous de\ kai\ pa/nu e)leuqe/rws cummaxou=ntas, kai/per nhsiw/tas o)/ntas kai\ eu)lh/ptous, dio/ti e)n xwri/ois e)pikai/rois ei)si\ peri\ th\n *pelopo/nnhson. From this it appears, as Herbst (Philol. 42, p. 724) observes, that the “islanders” here mentioned are different from the cu/mmaxoi. Cf. vii. 57. 32 ff., where Cephallenians and Zacynthians are mentioned as nhsiw=tai and au)to/nomoi.
*lakedaimoni/wn a)/poikoi: see Hdt.viii. 48. 3.

ou)dete/rwn o)/ntes: gra/fetai meq' e(te/rwn, Schol. This means ou)de\ meq' e(te/rwn. Thuc. uses, however, both forms. Cf. cumma/xous mhdete/rwn, c. 94. 2; mhdete/rwn o)/ntas, i. 35. 2; tou\s mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn, ii. 67. 34; e)/ste mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn, ii. 72. 11.
e)s po/lemon fanero\n kate/sthsan: so also in c. 25. 15.
stratopedeusa/menoi e)s th\n gh=n: is elliptical for e)sbalo/ntes e)s th\n gh=n kai\ stratopedeusa/menoi.
*tisi/as o( *tisima/xou : see App.

toi=s o)li/gois: the o)li/goi appear here and in c. 85. 4 as the chief governing body, a small senate or assembly, to which the holders of important offices (ai( a)rxai/, cf. c. 28. 2; 47. 52 and 55; i. 90. 27) belong.

div2.head: Chapters 85-113: Negotiations between the envoys of the Athenians and the council of the Melians.
div2.p: (On the course of the dialogue, see App. fin.)

o(/pws dh/: evidently in order that. Cf. vii. 18. 5.—r(h/sei: cf. c. 111. 15, r(h/matos. These words occur in Thuc. only in these two places.—a)ne/legkta: untested, “against which no argument is advanced.” In vi. 53. 14, a)ne/legkton, used of a person, means “not subjected to trial.”

fronei=: bou/letai, Schol. du/nasqai is elsewhere (cf. i. 141. 5; vi. 36. 9) used in this sense of mean, have for its object.— u(mw=n: subj. gen. with a)gwgh/. St., followed by Cl., writes h(mw=n as obj. gen.

oi( kaqh/menoi: who are sitting there to listen to us. This has a slight shade of mockery. Cf. iii. 38. 32, sofistw=n qeatai=s e)oiko/tes kaqhme/nois ma=llon h)\ peri\ po/lews bouleuome/nois, and vi. 13. 2.—e)/ti a)sfale/steron poih/sate: act in a still safer way. a)sfale/steron is adv.

e(ni\ lo/gw|: the only correct reading for e)n o)li/gw| of most Mss. The meaning is the same as that of cunexei= r(h/sei. “As you feared that the polloi/ would be misled by a cunexh\s r(h=sis, do not you either (mhd' u(mei=s) form your judgment from one speech.”

u(polamba/nontes: cf. c. 49. 17.—kri/nete: “form (and deliver) your judicial
decision.”
w(s le/gomen: as we propose.
e)piei/keia: esp. consideration on the part of the powerful for subjects or inferiors, as opp. to u(/bris; equity with a touch of clemency. See on iii. 40. 7.
au)tou=: i.e. tou= dida/skein kaq) h(suxi/an a)llh/lous.—fai/netai: see App.

e)c au)tou=: this refers again to tou= dida/skein kaq' h(suxi/an a)llh/lous. “If this is agreed to, then the result brings to us,” etc.—perigenome/nois: “if we prove ourselves to be in the right.”—tw=| dikai/w|: “by the justice of our cause.”

toi/nun: forms a vigorous and almost impatient beginning: well, then, if you, etc. toi/nun occurs in Thuc. only in direct address. Cf. c. 89. 1; 105. 1; iii. 45. 14; viii. 53. 20.—u(ponoi/as logiou/menoi: used somewhat ironically: to consider hidden thoughts, and hence to argue from suspicious fancies about the future.

a)/llo ti h)/: cf. iii. 85. 13, o(/pws a)po/gnoia h)=| tou= a)/llo ti h)\ kratei=n th=s gh=s, where the Schol. supplies pra=cai after a)/llo ti. A similar expression is ti/ a)/llo h)/ in iii. 39. 10 and 58. 24.—w(=n o(ra=te: this is still dependent upon e)k. Cf. c. 42. 2. Here, however, the rel. is attracted into the case of an omitted indef. antec.
e)pi\ tou=to: sc. cunh/kete.

ei)ko\s kai\ cuggnw/mh: like di/kaia kai\ pre/ponta a(/ma in i. 144. 16, this alludes to both the objective and the subjective aspect of the matter, to its intrinsic naturalness and propriety as well as to the judgment of others respecting it.—cuggnw/mh: (sc. e)sti) occurs with inf. in iv. 61. 17, with ei) in i. 32. 24.—kaqestw=tas: the expression is a general one: “men in such a position.”

e)pi\ polla\ tre/pesqai: cf. i. 20. 21, e)pi\ ta\ e(toi=ma tre/pontai, and iv. 104. 6, e)f) a(rpagh\n trape/sqai.—kai\ le/gontas kai\ dokou=ntas: “in words as well as thoughts.” dokou=ntas is a less invidious expression than u(ponoi/as, which the Athenians
used in c. 87. 1.

me/ntoi: forms the transition from their excuse to the question in hand: “but we admit that.”—kai\ peri\ swthri/as: these words admit the right of the Athenians to remind them of their position, and the following words kai\ o( lo/gos . . . gigne/sqw express their reluctant assent to the proposal of the Athenians.
w(=| prokalei=sqe tro/pw|: i.e. tou/tw| tw=| tro/pw| w(=| to\n lo/gon gi/gnesqai prokalei=sqe.
toi/nun: here again this particle urges the point at issue: “very well; but let us both give up fine words.”
dikai/ws: const. with a)/rxomen.

a)dikou/menoi, ou)de\n h)dikh/kate : these words express the meaning of the o)no/mata kala/ which are to be given up.—e)pecerxo/meqa: “press our just right,” “insist upon punishment,” as in vi. 38. 10.—lo/gwn mh=kos: equiv. to pollou\s kai\ makrou\s lo/gous, and with this is joined a)/piston, “not carrying conviction.”
ou)q) u(ma=s a)ciou=men kte(.: const. ou)k a)ciou=men u(ma=s oi)/esqai pei/sein le/gontas, upon which o(/ti . . . ou) cunestrateu/sate and w(s . . . h)dikh/kate depend.
ou) cunestrateu/sate: sc. h(mi=n. “That you did not join with us in the war because you as colonists of the Lacedaemonians were under no obligation to do so.”

ta\ dunata\ de\...diapra/ssesqai : this also depends upon a)ciou=men, the meaning of which is somewhat modified: “we think it right (for both of us) to aim at accomplishing what is possible according to the real opinion (i.e. without any misleading fine phrases) of both of us.” The subj. of diapra/ssesqai is no longer u(ma=s, but e)kate/rous, the expression of which is rendered needless by the presence of e)ka/teroi.
e)pistame/nous pro\s ei)do/tas : “since we both equally know,” e)pistame/nwn kai\ u(mw=n kai\ h(mw=n, Schol.

tw=| a)nqrwpei/w| lo/gw|: the Schol. explains this by a)nqrw/pinos logismo/s. This is not philosophical speculation, but the reasoning of practical life, in which, acc. to the thoroughly realistic point of view here adopted, justice is regarded (kri/netai) only when the pressure of necessity is the same on both parties. If that is not the case, the only thing to be considered is what is possible, and this the stronger party accomplishes, while the weaker party must make the best of it.

dunata/: stands first for emphasis. It is the obj. of pra/ssousi and also of cugxwrou=sin in accordance with the free use of neut. adjs. and prons., as in c. 41. 11 and 20; viii. 45. 21. Cobet, V. L. p. 271 and 454, proposes (after Dobree) prosta/ssousi for pra/ssousi.

h(=| me\n dh\ nomi/zome/n ge: these words introduce in an almost timid way an attempt to aid the cause of the weaker party by saving the di/kaion in the form of the ei)ko/s. ge after nomi/zomen has its full force, as we think at any rate. See App.
a)na/gkh ga/r: sc. to\ cumfe/ron le/gein.—ou(/tw...le/gein: is the obj. of u(pe/qesqe: “to talk so (as you have just been doing) not about justice, but about what is advantageous.”

u(pe/qesqe: i.e. u(po/qesin e)poih/sasqe, “you have made it the foundation (or the startingpoint) of the discussion.” This use occurs in Thuc. only here, but freq. in Plat. (e.g. Charm. 171 d, o(\ e)c a)rxh=s u(petiqe/meqa; Rep. iv. 437 a) and later writers. A similar use with added dat. is found in Hdt.i. 156. 2, tau=ta/ oi( u(peti/qeto; iv. 135. 12; v. 98. 10; vii. 237. 10.—to\ koino\n a)gaqo/n: what is meant is to\ di/kaion as the foundation of human society (see on c. 104. 4), which has, however, been excluded from the discussion.—a)lla\ tw=| kte(.: “yetitis expedient (xrh/simon embraces tw=| a)ei\ . . . di/kaia as well as the other infs.) that to every one in peril what is reasonable be accounted right”; i.e. even if we must not call it a right (di/kaion), still it should have the effect of a right. St. strikes out di/kaia in 5, but by so doing he loses the point of the subtle and artificial argumentation of the Melians by which, as they dare not openly oppose the Athenians, they try to substitute ei)ko/ta for di/kaia. (kai/, which some Mss. insert before di/kaia, is inappropriate.)

e)nto\s tou= a)kribou=s pei/santa: the aor. for pei/sonta of most Mss. seems necessary; for it must refer to time antecedent to w)felhqh=nai, “even if one has not entirely proved his point, even if one has not attained to the a)kribe/s(e)nto/s, like Lat. citra and sometimes intra, denotes that a missile has fallen short of the mark), still it is expedient (xrh/simon) that one derive some advantage.” See App.

pro\s u(mw=n: in your interest. Cf. ii. 86. 19; iii. 38. 3. The reason for this is very cautiously expressed. Instead of saying: your contempt of justice will sometime cost you dear; for if those whom you now oppress ever come into power, they will take such revenge upon you that your fate will be a warning example to other ruling states, the Melians express
the same idea in the intentionally obscure form, inasmuch as you, if you should ever fall, would, by the heaviest vengeance (which you will then incur), be a (warning) example to others.— e)pi\ megi/sth| timwri/a|: the prep. prop. denotes the accompanying circumstances or conditions. Cf. e)pi\ toi=s deinoi=s eu)e/lpides, i. 70. 10; 143. 8; iii. 67. 33; iv. 22. 13.

pauqh=|: kataluqh=|, Schol.— 2. ou)k a)qumou=men th\n teleuth/n: we do not look forward to the end with dismay. The adv. acc. is used with a)qumei=n as in c. 40. 13 with a)porei=n. Elsewhere we find the dat. (cf. vii. 60. 27) or pro/s (cf. ii. 88. 11).
w(/sper kai/: cf. c. 44. 9; i. 74. 25; ii. 55. 7.—ou(=toi: on the emphatic repetition of a preceding word by ou(=tos, see on iv. 44. 15.

e)/sti de\ kte(.: “with the Lacedaemonians, however, we are not contending.” This parenthetical remark, introduced by the adversative de/, is directed against the implied meaning of the last part of c. 90.— 5. a)ll) h)\n...krath/swsi : sc. ou(=toi deinoi/ ei)si.—au)toi\ e)piqe/menoi: the unexpected or surprising nature of such an attack is indicated by au)toi/. Those very ones who had been oppressed now assume the offensive themselves.

a)fei/sqw: “it may be left to us”; imv. pf. pass. Cf. ei)rh/sqw, Xen. Mem. iv. 2. 19; Isocr. IV. 14.—kinduneu/esqai: “to support this peril,” impers. pass. Cf. i. 73. 15, kai\ ga\r o(/te e)drw=men, e)p) w)feli/a| e)kinduneu/eto.
tou\s lo/gous : i.e. the proposals or conditions to be offered.
a)po/nws: without trouble. They hoped to induce the Melians to come to terms without resorting to force.
a)/rcai: aor., to acquire dominion.—xrhsi/mws: followed by the dat. a)mfote/rois. This expresses the result of swqh=nai; “so that it will be advantageous to both of us.”

xrh/simon a)\n cumbai/h: like gi/gnesqai, cumbai/nein is sometimes
const. with adjs. Cf. i. 74. 1, toiou/tou me/ntoi cumba/ntos tou/tou; vi. 34. 60; 90. 1; vii. 30. 21.—douleu=sai: like a)/rcai (c. 91. 10), denotes the beginning of the relation.
kai\ u(mi=n: cf. c. 91. 3.

pro\ tou=...paqei=n : before suffering the worst. Cf. c. 100. 4.— 2. u(pakou=sai: this is the voluntary act which would lead to subjection, and is therefore substituted as a milder word for douleu=sai in c. 92.— mh\ diafqei/rantes u(ma=s: i.e. by not robbing ourselves of the strength you would bring us.
w(/ste de/: see App.
de/caisqe: see App.
ga\r: this introduces the reason for the unexpressed denial, equiv. to ou)k a)\n decai/meqa: ou) ga/r. Cf. c. 97. 1; 99. 1.

o(/son h( fili/a...dhlou/menon : the simple expression h( fili/a (opp. to h( e)/xqra) is developed, by the addition of the reasons for the assertion that the friendship of the Melians is worse than their enmity, into an ungrammatical form of sent. which is inadmissible in English. This complex expression is equiv. to two independent clauses: “your hostility does not injure us so much as your friendship; for your friendship appears to our subjects a proof of our weakness, whereas your hostility seems to them a proof of our power.”

oi( u(ph/kooi: i.e. the a)rxo/menoi of c. 95. It has just been stated that they would regard the friendship of the Melians as a proof of weakness on the part of Athens. In reply to this, the question is asked whether the subjects of Athens regard all relations between stronger and weaker states in the same way; whether a small state which has no special connexion with a more powerful one could not remain on friendly terms with it, and yet preserve its own independence. “Do your subjects really look at equity in this way so that they put all in the same category?”

o(/soi: these fall naturally under the two categories: that of simple a)/poikoi (these are the majority, oi( polloi/) and that of those who have revolted
and been subdued (tines, e.g. the Lesbians). The parts are in the same case as the whole. Cf. c. 10. 47 ff.

dikaiw/mati: a claim based upon justice, as in i. 41. 1.—ga/r: this introduces the reason for the unexpressed affirmative answer, as in c. 99. 1 for the neg.—ou)dete/rous: i.e. neither tou\s mh\ prosh/kontas nor tou\s a)poi/kous o)/ntas kai\ a)posta/ntas.
tou\s me/n : i.e. tou\s mh\ prosh/kontas, who should, acc. to the opinion just expressed by the Melians, be allowed to retain their independence; and this is the meaning of perigi/gnesqai.

to\ a)sfale\s a)\n para/sxoite : because our subjects will no longer believe that we are afraid of you. The expression, “you will, by the loss of your independence, increase our security,” is not without a sort of bitter irony, which is still sharper in a)/llws te kai\ . . . ei) mh\ perige/noisqe. Just because you are islanders, and insignificant islanders at that, you have all the less reason for claiming the right to retain your independence.
naukrato/rwn: the gen. depends upon perige/noisqe. Cf. i. 55. 10, *ke/rkura perigi/gnetai tw=| pole/mw| tw=n *korinqi/wn. G. 175, 2; H. 749.
e(te/rwn: than others, i.e. other islanders.

e)n e)kei/nw|: i.e. in the relation proposed in c. 94, w(/ste h(suxi/an . . . mhdete/rwn, or, as the Schol. explains, e)n tw=| mh\ peira=sqai tou\s mh\ prosh/kontas katastre/fesqai. The chief emphasis of the interr. sent. rests upon e)n e)kei/nw|. a)sfa/leian refers back to to\ a)sfale/s in c. 97. 4. The Melians ask, “doesn't that proposal of ours seem to you to be a safe one?” The following sent., dei= ga\r peira=sqai . . . pei/qein, is inserted parenthetically (with au)= kai\ e)ntau=qa referring to c. 90. 1), to give a reason for recurring to the proposal which the Athenians have already rejected in c. 95. The argument in support of this proposal is contained in the next sent., o(/soi ga/r . . . au)tou\s kte(., where it is expressed in negative form: “if you do not follow our advice, you will make enemies of all who are now neutral.”

e)kbia/santes: force out. See App.—tw=| u(mete/rw| cumfo/rw|, to\ h(mi=n xrh/simon: “what is for your interest, what is for ours.” The Melians hope to make their own interest acceptable to the Athenians (pei/qein) only if it coin
cides (tugxa/nei cumbai=non, sc. to\ h(mi=n xrh/simon) with that of the Athenians themselves.
polemw/sesqe: mid., make enemies of. The pass. of this occurs in i. 36. 10; 57. 5, 6.
e)s ta/de: at this which is going on here, i.e. at our fate.
ka)n tou/tw|: opp. to e)n e)kei/nw| of 1.—ti/ a)/llo h)/: cf. c. 87. 2; ii. 16. 10; iii. 39. 10.
mellh/santas: see App.

ou) ga\r: see on c. 97. 1.— 2. o(/soi h)peirw=tai poih/sontai, tou\s nhsiw/tas parocunome/nous: the inhabitants of the mainland are opp. to the islanders. The Athenians wish to show that they are in danger not so much from the former as from the latter. “The people of the mainland will in their freedom (the dat. tw=| e)leuqe/rw| denotes not so much cause as merely an attendant circumstance, and is nearly equiv. to e)leu/qeroi o)/ntes) defer indefinitely any measures of precaution they may take against us, which is not the case with the islanders, whether they are, like you, free from restraint, or irritated by the necessity of submission to our rule.” For other explanations, see App.— 6. tw=| a)logi/stw|: rash or ill-considered action, in consequence of parocu/nesqai.

e)s ki/ndunon katasth/seian : so also in ii. 100. 25. Similarly e)s a)pori/an, ii. 81. 37; vii. 75. 14; e)s taraxh/n, iv. 75. 10; e)s e)/kplhcin, vi. 36. 7. The Schol. explains this chap. as follows: ou) ga nomi/zomen tou\s e)leuqe/rous tw=n h)peirwtw=n h(mi=n e)/sesqai polemi/ous: mh\ dedio/tes ga h(ma=s, w(s a)
 kata\ gh=n ou) me/llontas au)toi=s e)pistrateu/ein, pollh
 me/llhsin tou= fula/ttesqai/ te h(ma=s kai\ polemei=n poih/sontai. tou\s de\ e)n tai=s nh/sois e)leuqe/rous w(/sper u(ma=s, kai\ tou\s u(pakou/ontas me
 h)/dh, dia\ de\ to\ e)c a)na/gkhs kai\ mh\ e(konti\ u(pakou/ein parocunome/nous kai\ tarattome/nous tou/tous h(gou/meqa, ei) perii/doimen u(ma=s e)leuqe/rous (so Cl. for h(ma=s: “if we should permit you to be free”), e)parqe/ntas a)logi/stws kai\ a)ntista/ntas h(mi=n au)tou/s te kai\ h(ma=s au)tou\s e)s ki/ndunon katasth/sein.

h)= pou a)/ra: surely then. An emphatic asseveration followed by a confident conclusion. Both belong
with pollh\ kako/ths, sc. a)\n ei)/h.

parakindu/neusin poiou=ntai : equiv. to parakinduneu/ousi (cf. iii. 36. 11), with the emphatic signification of para- implying excess. See on iii. 32. 15. The aor. infs. pauqh=nai and a)pallagh=nai, both const. with a)rxh=s, express the purpose of parakindu/neusin poiou=ntai.
pro\ tou= douleu=sai : cf. c. 93. 1.—pa=n e)pecelqei=n: try (cf. c. 9. 41) everything (cf. iii. 45. 20), even the most extreme measures.
ou)/k: this refers, not to any particular words, but to the whole idea of what precedes; equiv. to ou) poih/sete tou=to. Cf. iii. 66. 19.
a)po\ tou= i)/sou: this belongs with o( a)gw/n, and is opp. to pro\s tou\s krei/ssonas pollw=|: “with equal forces.” See on i. 77. 8.

o)flei=n: with Bekker and others against the authority of the Mss., which read o)/flein. The sense (“not to fall into disgrace”) demands the aor. (of pres. o)fliska/nw).—h( boulh/: this is substituted for o( a)gw/n as if to exclude the notion of a decision by violence.
a)lla/: this does not, like de/, introduce an objection or direct reply, but a new observation or point of view. Cf. c. 108. 1.—pole/mwn: see App.

koinote/ras: this is to be explained from the meaning of koino/s, impartial (cf. iii. 53. 8; 68. 7), “the fortunes of war sometimes turn out more impartially (i.e. more in accordance with justice) than the difference in the forces on the two sides would lead one to expect.”—ta\s tu/xas lamba/nonta: cf. o(/tan kairo\n la/ bwsin, vi. 86. 13.—h)\ kata/: cf. i. 76. 17; ii. 50. 2.

tou= drwme/nou: this is, as in c. 66. 18, prop. pass., but since it refers directly to the agent, it is used here and in vi. 16. 12 as a general expression for independent action. On the use of the partic. for the inf., see on c. 9. 18.—e)/ti: const. with e)lpi/s, and o)rqw=s with sth=nai. So Polyb., xxxiii. 12. 3, has o)rqw=s i(/stanto. Van Herwerden's proposal, o)rqoi=s, is needless. Cf. also Soph. O. T. 50, sta/ntes t' e)s o)rqo/n.

e)lpi\s de/: in introducing a reply, de/ throws special emphasis
upon one word, whether it be (as here; c. 91. 1; 96. 1; 106. 1) the preceding or (as in c. 94. 1; 98. 1; 100. 1) the following word.—paramu/qion: the concrete means of paramuqi/a. The two are not so entirely equiv. as Lobeck (ad Phryn. p. 517) thinks, but differ as do the Lat. nouns in -mentum and -io.

a)po\ periousi/as: cf. e)k tou= perisseu/ontos, of their abundance, St. Mark, XII. 44.—ou) kaqei=le: the gnomic aor., drawing a general inference from special cases. Cf. i. 69. 31. GMT. 30, 1; H. 840; Kühn. 386, 7.

toi=s d' e)s a(/pan to\ u(pa/rxon a)narriptou=si: those who cast (the die) for all their possessions. With a)narriptou=si supply ki/ndunon, i.e. the die. Cf. iv. 85. 13; 95. 5; vi. 13. 8. e)s a(/pan to\ u(pa/rxon must be taken together. Those who, on account of their poverty, are obliged to risk their all are opp. to those who, like rich men buying lottery tickets, risk only what they can afford to lose. See App.

a(/ma: const. with gignw/sketai sfale/ntwn. “When misfortune has come upon them the true nature of Hope is recognized; but then she does not leave (ou)k e)llei/pei, trans.; cf. Eur. El. 609) anything in which (i.e. in respect to which) one can be on his guard against her now that she is known.”

o(/: but this, expressing a strong opposition. Cf. c. 107. 3; 109. 3, and see on iv. 17. 18.—e)pi\ r(oph=s mia=s: this is a stronger expression than e)pi\ r(oph=s mikra=s in Eur. Hipp. 1163. The meaning is not “only a little is needed to turn the scale,” but, corresponding to e)s a(/pan to\ u(pa/rxon a)narriptou=si, “everything is at the mercy of a single turn.”—mh\ bou/lesqe: this resembles the Lat. nolite, but partakes of the nature of a benevolent warning: “pray do not be willing.” Thuc. uses this expression in one other place, iv. 10. 2, mhdei\s cuneto\s boule/sqw dokei=n ei)=nai.
oi(=s paro/n, kaqi/stantai : the rel. pron. stands in the dependent clause, but must be supplied as subj. of the main verb.—a)nqrwpei/ws: by human means.

e)pili/pwsin: deficiant, fail. Cf. ii. 70. 4, o( si=tos e)peleloi/pei.—a)fanei=s: sc. e)lpi/das, hopes with no visible foundation. The explanation, which is added in appos., mentions such unstable objects of
hope, which, in conjunction met' e)lpi/dwn, effect men's ruin.

th\n tu/xhn: this is the ruling power which affects men's lives without their own action, and is believed by the pious to be dependent upon to\ qei=on. Its special manifestations are the tu/xai. Cf. c. 102. 2. See Introd. to Book I., p. 29. What is, in c. 102. 2, expressed by koinai/ in connexion with tu/xai is here, with tu/xh itself, denoted by a)po\ tou= i)/sou: “not preferring either of the contending parties.”

e)k tou= qei/ou: cf. c. 112. 7.—o(/sioi: this is the only instance of the pers. use of this word in Thuc., god-fearing, observant of the divine ordinances (the o(/sia of i. 71. 25; ii. 52. 11, and the o(/sion of iii. 84. 14) upon which human society is based, and the chief of which is the di/kaion which the Melians have called (in c. 90. 3) to\ koino\n a)gaqo/n. The opposites of the o(/sioi are therefore plainly called ou) di/kaioi, although the Athenians are not mentioned by name.

i(sta/meqa: this word is used esp. of warlike opposition. Cf. i. 33. 22; 53. 6; iii. 39. 13.—tw=| e)llei/ponti: const. with prose/sesqai, and take h(mi=n as dat. of interest, nearly equiv. to the possessive gen., “their alliance will supplement our deficiency.”
ai)sxu/nh|: from a feeling of honour. Cf. iv. 19. 15.—ou) panta/pasin ou(/tws a)lo/gws: “not altogether so foolish as you may suppose.” See on c. 59. 17 and ii. 11. 24.

toi/nun: see on c. 87. 1.— pro\s to\ qei=on: this in conjunction with eu)me/neia denotes a good relation in the widest sense; not only that the Athenians hope for the favour of the gods, but also that they fulfil their obligations toward them. It is an indirect reply to the o(/sioi pro\s ou) dikai/ous of the Melians. pro\s to\ qei=on is not to be changed with Kr. to pro\s tou= qei/ou, nor with Meineke to peri\ to\ qei=on.

lelei/yesqai : equiv. to e)lassw/sesqai of 12, “that we shall be inferior therein.”—th=s a)nqrwpei/as: this belongs to both the following substs. (nomi/sews and boulh/sews), and is therefore placed before both in the sent. Cf. ii. 44. 4.

nomi/sews: this is here used not so much of opinion or belief as of the exercise of religious customs and cer
emonies, ta\ nenomisme/na, ta\ ei)qisme/na peri\ tou\s qeou/s, Schol.—e)s sfa=s au)tou\s boulh/sews: i.e. e)s tou\s a)nqrw/pous, which is suggested by the preceding a)nqrwpei/as. Like Lat. voluntas, bou/lhsis denotes one's state of mind toward others.
dikaiou=men, pra/ssomen: the first refers to boulh/sews: “we put forward no unwarranted pretensions,” the second to both nomi/sews and boulh/sews.

do/ch|, safw=s: these words, placed respectively after the substs. to\ qei=on and to\ a)nqrw/peion, denote the degree of certainty of h(gou/meqa as applied to these substs., and are not to be const. with a)/rxein: “for of the gods we believe, and of men we know, that by a law of their nature, wherever they have power (i.e. throughout the realm of their power), they always rule.” Greater stress is laid upon a)nqrw/peion, as is evident from its position before te.—dia\ panto/s: this is temporal, as usual. See on i. 38. 2. Like u(po\ fu/sews a)nagkai/as, it belongs with a)/rxein. The Athenians leave it to the Melians to give the general proposition to\ a)nqrw/peion ou(= a)\n krath=| a)/rxein its application to the case in hand: ou(/tw kai\ toi=s *)aqhnai/ois prosh/kein w(s kata\ qa/lassan kratou=ntas u(mw=n nhsiwtw=n o)/ntwn a)/rxein. But the proposition itself, a)/rxein tina\ ou(= a)\n krath=|, or “might makes right,” is the no/mos to which reference is made in the subsequent words.
u(ma=s a)/n, drw=ntas a)/n: the repetition of a)/n with subj. and verb adds clearness as well as emphasis. Cf. c. 9. 16.
tau)to/: see App.—e)k tou= ei)ko/tos: in accordance with probability. This refers to the statement of 2, ou)de\n e)/cw th=s a)nqrwpei/as e)s to\ qei=on nomi/sews pra/ssomen.

fobou/meqa: is here followed by the fut. inf. on account of the implied notion of iudir. disc. GMT. 46, N. 6 (b); H. 948 a.—th=s do/chs: const. with to\ a)peiro/kakon, 14, and to\ a)/fron, 15.—e)s *lakedaimoni/ous: cf. iii. 14. 1, ta\s e)s u(ma=s e)lpi/das, and iv. 81. 12, e)piqumi/a e)s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous.— 13. h(/n: cognate acc. with pisteu/ete, since do/ch is here nearly equiv. to pi/stis. See App.—dia\ to\ ai)sxro/n: equiv. to ai)sxu/nh| of c. 104. 8. ai)sxro\n nomi/zontas tou\s a)poi/kous polemoume/nous, Schol.
u(mw=n to\ a)peiro/kakon: your simplicity, which arises from inexperience of evil.
plei=sta: adv. See on i. 3. 23.
polla\ a)/n tis e)/xwn ei)pei=n: a common rhetorical expression. Cf. Dem. III. 27; VIII. 52.

cunelw/n: freq. used by Thuc. to introduce a brief summing up, esp. in speeches. Cf. ii. 41. 1; iii. 40. 16; vi. 80. 14.— 20. kai/toi: and yet (see on ii. 60. 16; iv. 18. 5) this selfish character of the Lacedaemonians is not favourable to the fulfilment of your present foolish hope of deliverance. The a)/logos swthri/a is here intentionally opp. to the ou)k a)lo/gws qrasuno/meqa of c. 104. 9.
kat' au)to\ tou=to: precisely because the Lacedaemonians nomi/zousi ta\ cumfe/ronta di/kaia.

tw=| cumfe/ronti au)tw=n : const. with mh\ boulh/sesqai (not with pisteu/omen). dia\ to\ i)/dion cumfe/ron, Schol. We should, as St. observes, expect tw=| au(tw=n cumfe/ronti or tw=| au)tw=n cumfe/ronti, but au)tw=n, even in the position in which it stands here, may have the sense of i)/dion (Lat. ipsorum). Still we should naturally translate it of them (Lat. corum, i.e. of some other people), which is here plainly impossible. See App.
katasth=nai: an emphatic gene/sqai. Cf. i. 70. 3; iii. 102. 26; iv. 92. 15; vi. 82. 13.

ou)k ou)=n kte(.: this is the ordinary neg. introduction of a question expecting an affirmative answer: don't you think then? i.e. “of course you understand.” This sense would appear more plainly if we were to read ou)k ou)=n i)/ste instead of oi)/esqe, as the Schol. may perhaps have done, who explains: a)ll) ou)=n, w(/sper i)/ste, sumfe/rei kte(.
dra=sqai : see App. —o(/: “but just that.” Cf. c. 103. 6; 109. 3.

kai\ tou\s kindu/nous: the dangers which are connected with the di/kaion and kalo/n. “The Lacedaemonians will be more ready to face them for our sake, and will consider them less dangerous (bebaiote/rous with kindu/nous; cf. iii. 39. 5, to\n meta\ tw=n o)li/gwn ki/ndunon h(ghsa/menoi bebaio/teron) than in relation to others (e)s a)/llous),” i.e. than if they were to face them for the sake of others. e)s expresses a general relation, as in c. 105. 12.— te: const. not with kindu/nous alone, but as the connective of the first clause, a)lla/ . . . e)gxeiri/sasqai au)tou/s with the second, kai\ bebaiote/rous nomiei=n.
e)gxeiri/sasqai : the mid. does not occur elsewhere in Attic Greek.

o(/sw|: inasmuch as.—pro\s ta\ e)/rga: ad res gerendas, “when anything is to be done.” Melos is so near the coast of Peloponnesus that it could easily send troops or supplies to the Lacedaemonians.— 4. kei/meqa: equiv. to h( h(mete/ra nh=sos kei=tai. The application of the word is transferred from the island to its inhabitants.—th=s gnw/mhs tw=| cuggenei=: “on account of the likeness of our views which arises from our relationship.” This is indirectly an explanation of th=s cuggenei/as e(/neka, of c. 104. 7. gnw/mh is used of views on political matters, as in i. 113. 10; iii. 70. 27; iv. 56. 17.
e(te/rwn: than any others. See on i. 84. 7.

to\ e)xuro/n: stands in the relation of pred. to to\ eu)/noun after fai/netai, and the art. is added to emphasize the subst. use of e)xuro/n (cf. ii. 43. 22 f.): “the thing which inspires confidence is not the good will,” etc.; the positive side is then expressed by the cond. sent. a)ll) h)/n tis prou/xh|.— 5. kai\ meta\ cumma/xwn pollw=n: a similar idea is expressed in ii. 39. § 2.— 6. ou)k ei)ko\s au)tou\s peraiwqh=nai: ei)ko/s regularly takes the inf. aor. (never the fut.) where the probability of the occurrence of a fut. action is to be expressed. See on i. 81. 13.

kai\ a)/llous: i.e. the allies, a list of whom is given in ii. 9. § 2. The Corinthians would be esp. fitted
for such service.—polu/: cf. pollh\ h( *sikeli/a, vii. 13. 16.

to\ *krhtiko\n pe/lagos: the sea to the south and southeast from Peloponnesus. See on iv. 53. 13.—di) ou(=: per quod, i.e. on account of its greatness.—tw=n kratou/ntwn, tw=n boulome/nwn: subjective gens.—a)porw/teros: on the masc. ending in the comp. of compound adjs., see on iii. 89. 21 and iv. 31. 15. Kr. Spr. § 23, 1, Rem.
lh=yis: in the sense of lamba/nein, as in c. 115. 5; vii. 25. 16.
tou=de: sc. tou= kata\ qa/lassan bohqh=sai h(mi=n.

tou\s loipou\s tw=n cumma/xwn : esp. those on the Thracian coast. This, as the most important part of the Athenian empire, may be particularly referred to in th=s oi)keiote/ras cummaxi/dos of 7.—o(/sous mh\ e)ph=lqe: such as he did not reach. The cond. rel. (with mh/, not ou)) is equiv. to ei)/ tinas mh\ e)ph=lqe. GMT. 61, 1; H. 913.
ou) ma=llon h)/: not so much as. See on i. 73. 17.

oi)keiote/ras: this is opp. to th=s mh\ proshkou/shs (not th=s ou) prosh/koushs, and therefore a general expression applicable to other places besides Melos; G. 283, 4; H. 1025 a), and belongs with both cummaxi/dos and gh=s. With proshkou/shs we should supply cummaxi/dos rather than gh=s, for it was as cummaxi/s that new territory was added to the Athenian empire. gh=s is then added as an afterthought: “not about territory which you hope to add to your empire without any right, but about your own empire and, for that matter, your own country.” Cl. supplies gh=s with mh\ proshkou/shs, and cites i. 13. 18; ii. 11. 20; 20. 17. Cf. also c. 111. 20. There is no difficulty in supplying gh=s, but the above explanation seems better. See App.

tou/twn me\n kai\ pepeirame/nois kte(.: the point of this reply to the threatening language of the Melians lies in the proud assurance that such a double attack was nothing new for the Athenians. It is, therefore, certain that, as St. observes, pepeirame/nois refers to the Athenians only. In the litotes (ou)k a)nepisth/mosin, i.e. eu)= ei)do/sin) the Athenians express with self-conscious irony the confident belief that “the fame of our campaigns has probably come to your ears.” The effect of tou/twn ti is somewhat similar: “some of these things (with which you threaten us) would not come upon us without our having experienced the like before,” i.e. “nothing of all this is new to us.” On the pers. const. of pepeirame/nois, see on ii. 3. 9. This const. occurs with gi/gnesqai also in ii. 60. 1. See App.
e)nqumou/meqa: in the freq. occurring sense of sympathetic interest (cf. c. 32. 5); here “we observe with regret.”—fh/santes: see c. 87; 88.

a)/nqrwpoi: is used with reference to what is said in c. 105. 4 ff. about the qei=on and the a)nqrw/peion.— 6. nomi/seian: see App.—u(mw=n ta\ i)sxuro/tata e)lpizo/mena me/lletai: your strongest (grounds of confidence), being (mere) hopes, are held in abeyance. ta\ me\n i)sxuro/tata u(mw=n e)lpi/des ei)si\ me/llousai, Schol. The sense is expressed in a characteristic manner by the pass. me/lletai (in Xen. An. iii. 1. 47 it is different, where me/llesqai means be put cff).
braxe/a: const. perigi/gnesqai with this. Cf. i. 50. 25, o)li/gai a)mu/nein; ii. 61. 12, tapeinh\ e)gkarterei=n.—pollh/n te: a final conclusion: “and so you exhibit great want of sense.”
metasthsa/menoi: causing to withdraw. See on i. 79. 3, and compare with this trans. aor. partic. the corresponding intrans. metasta/ntwn in 25.
gnw/sesqe: come to a conclusion. Cf. c. 36. 10; i. 70. 7; ii. 61. 12; iii. 40. 18.

ou) ga\r dh\...tre/yesqe : a similar expression is used in i. 122. 23, ou) ga\r dh\ pefeugo/tes tau=ta e)pi\ th\n plei/stous dh\ bla/yasan katafro/nhsin kexwrh/kate. In both passages an urgent warning is expressed; but here the danger is in the future, and therefore may still be avoided, while in the other case the fault is regarded as already committed.

polloi=s ga/r kte(.: this sent. contains, in chiastic order, an explanation of the two epithets in the preceding sent.: proorwme/nois e)/ti(e)/ti with pro-, while it is still time to avoid them) corresponds to prou/p tois kindu/nois and to\ ai)sxro\n kalou/menon to ai)sxroi=s. This explains the unusual ai)sxroi=s kindu/nois (for which e)sxa/tois, a)/krois, i)sxuroi=s have been proposed), i.e. “in dangers which threaten disgrace,” by which the loss of political independence is here meant. The Schol. renders: to\ a)prepe\s tou= o)no/matos, and adds: toute/sti to\ u(pakou/ein e)/xon ti poihtiko\n ai)sxu/nhs. Cf. Dem. XVIII. 178, mh\ dei=sqai *qhbai/wn mhde/n: ai)sxro\s ga\r o( kairo/s, “it would bring you disgrace.”

a)pa-
gwgou=: seductive, misleading. Cf. c. 85. 2; vi. 8. 7.

e)pespa/sato: aor. as in c. 103. 3. The mid. of this verb is used in iii. 44. 15; it is therefore not necessary to write, with v. Herwerden, Stud. Thuc. p. 80, e)pe/spase to/. Even without the art., peripesei=n (16) and proslabei=n (17) contain the obj. of polloi=s e)pespa/sato: “so-called baseness by the power of a seductive word brings upon many (the misfortune) to fall into real troubles,” etc. —r(h/matos e)/rgw|: the juxtaposition makes the opposition in meaning all the more noticeable.

e(ko/ntas: acc. as subj. of peripesei=n in spite of the preceding dats. polloi=s, proorwme/nois, and h(sshqei=si.—ai)sxu/nhn ai)sxi/w meta\ a)noi/as h)\ tu/xhs: a disgrace which is more disgraceful when incurred through folly than (it would be if incurred through) fortune. See App.
proslabei=n: “incur disgrace in addition to their misfortunes.” Cf. iii. 82. 50.
po/lews th=s megi/sths: the order is like that in ii. 61. 17; iv. 10. 7; 86. 2 and 8, with emphasis upon the adj. placed after the subst. and art.
me/tria prokaloume/nhs: cf. c. 37. 23, ta\ ei)rhme/na prokalou/menoi=. The substance of these proposals follows in the inf. gene/sqai kte(.

u(potelei=s : sc. fo/rou (cf. i. 19. 1; 80. 14). With the exception of the few au)to/nomoi (cf. i. 97. 1) this was the regular condition of the Athenian cu/mmaxoi, in which respect they differed from those of the Lacedaemonians, acc. to i. 19. 1.— 21. kai\...filonikh=sai : const. with ou)k a)prepe\s nomiei=te. filonikh=sai (on the spelling, see St. Quaest. Gram. p. 13) with the neut. obj. ta\ xei/rw as in Plat. Prot. 360 e.
kalw=s prosfe/rontai: behave properly; a euphemism for submit.
e)nqumei=sqe: consider earnestly. Cf. 4.

h(\n mia=s pe/ri...e)/stai : the expianation of the Schol. polla/kis pro\ o)fqalmw=n la/bete o(/ti peri\ patri/dos h( ske/yis mia=s ou)/shs, peri\ h(=s e)n mia=| bou-
lh=| h)\ katorqw/sete h)\ sfalh/sesqe undoubtedly gives the meaning intended; but the sent. is certainly corrupt, and the difficulties are not overcome by the various emendations proposed. See App.
tuxou=sa/n te kai\ katorqw/sasan: the alternatives are expressed in the same way, as in ii. 35. 8, eu)= te kai\ xei=ron ei)po/nti.
metexw/rhsan: corresponds to metasta/ntwn of c. 111. 25.
kata\ sfa=s au)tou/s: by themselves alone; kata/ as in ii. 39. 11.
paraplh/sia kai/: similia atque: about the same as. Cf. ii. 60. 20; iii. 14. 2.—a)nte/legon: the impf. because the negotiations were not yet at an end. We should, however, use the plpf. in English.

ou)/te a)/lla dokei= h(mi=n, ou)/te a)fairhso/meqa: “neither our opinion nor our intention has changed.” The theoretical and the practical aspects of the affair are placed side by side.— a(/per kai/: see on c. 13. 7, w(=n ka)kei=nos e)peno/ei.

e(ptako/sia e)/th : this statement, which is evidently not intended to be exact, carries us back to the time of the Dorian invasion. Conon, narrat. 36, mentions the Spartan Philonomus as founder of Melos soon after the Dorians took possession of Sparta. See Müller, Orchomenos, p. 317.

e)k tou= qei/ou: opp. to a)po\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn, with reference to c. 105. 5 ff.; 11 ff. to\ qei=on is further explained by tu/xh, and oi( a)/nqrwpoi by *lakedaimo/nioi, the whole being arranged in chiastic order. kai\ *lakedaimoni/wn, which St. rejects, should therefore be retained. kai/ introduces the specification of a)nqrw/pwn, and is equiv. to et—quidem.

parakalou/meqa kte(.: first comes the proposal of the Melians as it affects themselves (fi/loi . . . mhdete/rois), then as it affects the Athenians. This is equiv. to h(mw=n fi/lwn o)/ntwn u(mi=n, polemi/wn de\ mhdete/rois, u(ma=s e)k th=s gh=s h(mw=n a)naxwrh=sai.
fi/loi : nom. referring to the subj. of prokalou/meqa. G. 136, N. 3 (a); H. 940.— 12. e)pith/deioi: elsewhere this adj. has three terminations. Cf. c. 21. 7; 81. 9; viii. 11. 12.

dialuo/menoi h)/dh: as they were on the point of leaving. dialu/esqai as in ii. 12. 13; vi. 41. 16, dielu/qhsan e)k tou= cullo/gou. e)k tw=n lo/gwn (cf. c. 112. 1) is the opposite of e)s lo/gous (cf. iii. 8. 6; iv. 38. 4; 73. 33).—a)ll' ou)=n: well then. This introduces the final summing up of the result of the conference.
a)po\ tou/twn tw=n bouleuma/twn: judging from the conclusion at which you have arrived.
ta\ o(rw/mena: that which lies before your eyes. Cf. ii. 42. 21; iii. 45. 23.
tw=| bou/lesqai: equiv. to boulh/sei a)safei= in iv. 108. 21.

parabeblhme/noi kai\ pisteu/santes: with these words plei=ston (6) is to be taken adv. being most entirely given over to (the Lacedaemonians, etc.) and having trusted them most entirely. parabeblhme/noi is pass., as in Ar. Pl. 243, po/rnaisi kai\ ku/boi/si parabeblhme/nos. The pf. partic. is used because this expresses a trait of the character of the Melians; the aor. partic. pisteu/santes is used to refer to the action of the Melians in putting their faith in the Lacedaemonians, etc., in this particular instance. Cf. e)lqo/ntas kai\ kekthme/nous, vii. 66. 6. Kr. Spr. § 56, 14. This explanation of St. makes it unnecessary to strike out either kai\ pisteu/santes (with v. Herwerden) or kai/ (with Cl., who takes parabeblhme/noi as mid., having risked, with plei=ston as its obj.).
After the conference has come to an end, the Athenians invest the town, and begin the siege with part of their army.
ou)de\n u(ph/kouon: a common expression. Cf. i. 26. 16; 29. 1.

e)tre/ponto: the impf. denoting the beginning of the new course of action is the reading of the best Mss. though many editt. read e)tra/ponto. Cf. vii. 71. 13. In i. 5. 4 and ii. 52. 11, e)tra/ponto denotes also the accomplishment; hence the aor.—dielo/menoi perietei/xisan: cf. c. 75. 22, where the impf. perietei/xizon is used because the building of the wall was a work of some time, and was, in fact, never finished.
fulakh\n katalipo/ntes...a)nexw/rhsan : so also in ii. 78. 6 ff.
kai\ kata\ gh=n kai\ kata\ qa/lassan: const. with fulakh\n katalipo/ntes.
Hostilities in various parts of Peloponnesus. The Melians make a successful sally against the Athenians.
kai\ *)argei=oi kte(.: they had done the same thing the previous year. See c. 83. 10 ff.—to\n xro/non to\n au)to/n: the order of words as in th=| e)pixeirh/sei th=| au)th=|, vii. 39. 2.
loxisqe/ntes: falling into an ambuscade, pass. of loxi/zein, the act. of which is used in iii. 107. 18, where, however, the troops employed in the ambush are the dir. obj. of the action of the verb.
diefqa/rhsan w(s o)gdoh/konta: the general subj. *)argei=oi is limited in the course of the period. Cf. c. 10. 47 ff.; 59. 1 ff.
oi( e)k th=s *pu/lou *)aqhnai=oi: cf. c. 56. 11, where the sending of fresh forces is mentioned.

a)fe/ntes ta\s sponda/s: cf. a)fe/ntes th\n cummaxi/an, c. 78. 6; i. 102. 19.—ou)d' w(/s: const. with e)pole/moun, not merely with a)fe/ntes. There was as yet no renewal of the war, for this is not recorded until vi. 105. 5.
ei)/ tis bou/letai...lh/|zesqai : on the ellipsis, see on i. 27. 4; iii. 52. 11; iv. 37. 8.—para\ sfw=n: cf. ii. 41. 3.
diaforw=n: see App.
to\ kata\ th\n a)gora/n: this must refer to that part of the Athenian camp which was used as a market. Cf. i. 62. 4; iii. 6. 12.
e)senegka/menoi: equiv. to e)skomisa/menoi. Cf. i. 117. 5; vi. 22. 6.
xrh/sima: see App.
to\ e)/peita: after this. Cf. iv. 54. 14; 170. 2.

Prosecutions at Argos for political reasons. The Melians make another sally, but the Athenians, having received reinforcements, oblige the town to surrender, and treat the inhabitants with great severity.
mellh/santes: aor., when they had prepared everything for the expedition. Cf. i. 134. 16; viii. 23. 28.
i(era\ e)n toi=s o(ri/ois: see App.
dia\ th\n e)kei/nwn me/llhsin: this corresponds to mellh/santes of 2, “because of this plan of the Lacedaemonians, of which they had heard.” See Grote, VI. c. 56, p. 372.
u(popteu/santes: see App.
kaq' e(/tero/n ti: at another point (than that kata\ th\n a)gora/n; cf. c. 115. 11). ti is limited by tou= perteixi/smatos.
w(s tau=ta e)gi/gneto: this is a superfluous and awkward addition, and Cl. and others are prob. right in rejecting it.
genome/nhs kai\ prodosi/as: when treason had also made its appearance. Cf. iv. 103. 20, a(/ma th=s prodosi/as ou)/shs.
a)f' e(autw=n: from among themselves.
w(/ste: on condition that. See on i. 28. 18; 29. 22. GMT. 98, 2; H. 953 b.

a)pe/kteinan: at the instigation of Alcibiades, acc. to Andoc. IV. 22 and Plut. Alc. 16, who uses the expression a)posfagh=nai, i.e. they were killed by the sword. So Diod. xii. 80. 55 says a)posfa/cai.
w)/|kisan : with good Mss. instead of w)/|khsan. For such a new settlement w)/|kisan is the proper expression. See on i. 98. 4; ii. 70. 21.
